Authors: Brewer R.A., Wendenburg C.A., Vache J.-C.
Title: A retrievable offshore complex for marginal fields
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - European Offshore Technology Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Combustion Engineering. Inc., United Kingdom; Marathon Marine Engineering Co., United Kingdom; Sea Tank Co., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Brewer, R.A., Combustion Engineering. Inc., United Kingdom; Wendenburg, C.A., Marathon Marine Engineering Co., United Kingdom; Vache, J.-C., Sea Tank Co., United Kingdom
Abstract: The ongoing need for improving both the techniques and economcis relating to the development of small offshore fields continues to be a leading priority of the offshore oil industry everywhere. As the cost of energy increases, so increases the desirability to place these marginal fields on stream. This paper presents the Sea Plex, a conceptual design that offers the offshore industry a new and innovative drilling/production/storage system complex that can be retrieved once the reservoir is depleted... and then, can be towed to another site for reuse after meeting any inspection and recertification requirements. It combines the proven technologies of the concrete storage caisson with that of the jackup to form a stable offshore structure. Also, it is capable of safely storing several days' production, thereby offering continuous on-station operation. Initial results of development studies indicate this concept to be feasible for worldwide applications in water depths ranging from 30 to 150 m (98-492 ft) and for severe sea states and environments such as those found in the North Sea. Design evaluations are continuing. © Copyright 1980, European Offshore Petroleum Conference and Exhibition.
Index Keywords: Conceptual design; Ocean currents; Offshore oil well production; Offshore oil wells; Offshore structures; Oil field development; Petroleum reservoir evaluation; Cost of energies; Design evaluation; Development study; Off-shore oil industry; Offshore complex; Offshore fields; Offshore industry; Station operations; Offshore oil fields

Authors: Eson R.L., Fitch J.P., Shannon A.M.
Title: North kern front field steam drive with ancillary materials
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE/DOE Enhanced Oil Recovery Symposium, EOR 1981
Affiliations: Chemical Oil Recovery Company, United States; Petro-Lewis Corporation, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eson, R.L., Chemical Oil Recovery Company, United States; Fitch, J.P., Chemical Oil Recovery Company, United States; Shannon, A.M., Petro-Lewis Corporation, United States
Abstract: Since steam injection became a viable recovery technique nearly three decades ago, the problems of gravity segregation and poor areal and vertical sweep efficiencies have limited recoveries in many heavy oil reservoirs. In many instances the injected steam prematurely breaks through into producing wells creating steam channels. It is believed that overall recoveries of a steam drive can be improved if the steam channeling can be controlled. This paper documents efforts under a Department of Energy cost sharing contract to reduce steam channeling in a conventional steam drive using ancillary materials. A steam foam solution and a steam foam encapsulated in a polymer gel are being introduced in four steam injection patterns in the North Kern Front Field near Bakersfield, California. The ability of the ancillary materials to improve recovery will be determined through injection profiles, chemical tracer surveys casing vent gas analysis, core and log data, and irllll oil saturation data, as well as through temperature and production data. It has been shown that in-situ steam foams can be used to alter the steam injection profiles to prevent excessive steam channeling. The results of early production data have indicated that as much as 125 B/D of incremental oil is being produced by the four chemical treated patterns. © Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE/DOE Enhanced Oil Recovery Symposium, EOR 1981. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Chemical analysis; Cost effectiveness; Crude oil; Digital storage; Heavy oil production; Injection (oil wells); Oil field equipment; Oil fields; Oil well logging; Petroleum reservoir engineering; Petroleum reservoirs; Recovery; Steam; Thermal logging; Chemical tracers; Department of Energy; Gravity segregation; Heavy oil reservoirs; Injection profile; Recovery techniques; Steam channelings; Steam injection profiles; Enhanced recovery

Title: The underground natural gas storage in the FR Germany as a result of the increasing energy demand
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Kavernen Bau- und Betriebs- Gmbh, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lindemann, N.W.B., Kavernen Bau- und Betriebs- Gmbh, Germany; Carlson, U., Kavernen Bau- und Betriebs- Gmbh, Germany
Abstract: Over the past 12 years the natural gas consumption of the Federal Republic of Germany increased from 8 × 109 m3 to 60 × 109 m3. To date approx. 70 % of this quantity is imported. Imports, however, require more or less constant delivery rates. For the compensation of fluctuations in seasonal demand adequate storage capacities must be provided. Underground storages have been constructed since about 1950 but their capacities are still far behind the rapidly increasing demand. The distribution of existing storages and those under construction are described, considering the trend of natural gas consumption during the recent past as well as the energy economical prognosis at about 9 × 109 m3 and the necessity for future construction of new storages shown. © Copyright 1981, Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME.
Index Keywords: Natural gas; Natural gas wells; Energy demands; Federal Republic of Germany; Natural gas consumption; Seasonal demands; Storage capacity; Underground natural gas storages; Underground storage; Underground gas storage

Title: International conference on seasonal thermal-energy storage and compressed air energy storage.
Abstract: Thirty-five papers were presented at the meeting. A separate abstract was prepared for each of 31 papers. Four papers were previously processed for the Energy Data Base. (A)

Title: Wind energy on the family farm. Final technical report.
Authors with affiliations: Rosental, J.S.
Abstract: This project sets out to provide a demonstration of wind energy, irrigation and refrigeration on a family farm. Various inefficiencies have contributed to lower electricity output, as has a lower than expected wind speed. Delays, inflation, unexpected events and other factors have contributed to substantially higher costs for all phases of the project. The irrigation system has mostly worked well, while the ice pond showed theoretical success. Certain innovative and practical solutions were achieved, including modifications and repaires to the generator, underground freeze proof well houses and water storage. (A)
Index Keywords: power; Wind

Title: Compressed air energy storage preliminary design and site development program in an aquifer. Final report, site selection study, part 2.
Authors with affiliations: Walke, W.C.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Hansen J.E., Packard J.E., Doyle W.T.
Title: Mariculture of red seaweeds.
Authors with affiliations: Hansen, J.E.; Packard, J.E.; Doyle, W.T.
Abstract: The history of red seaweed used as a food in Asia, Polynesia, Europe and North America is traced. The seaweed's nutrient value and use as animal fodder, as 'nutrient scrubbers' to clean contaminated water, and as biomass for energy is documented. Attempts to manipulate seaweed habitat using artificial substrates, live storage and vegetative propagation are described. -from US Govt Reports Announcements, 18, 1982

Title: Survey of thermal storage systems relevant to solar air heating - an annotated bibliography.
Authors with affiliations: Burns, A.P.
Abstract: This annotated bibliography contains abstracts of papers on solar air systems in which storage is used, sensible heat storage, latent heat storage, chemical storage, and review papers of solar energy storage for air space heating. (T.R.A.)

Title: Survey of thermal storage systems relevant to solar air heating - a review.
Authors with affiliations: Burns, A.P.
Abstract: This review covers the topics of thermal energy storage relevant to solar air space heating. These are sensible heat storage in rock beds, latent heat storage (mainly salt hydrates and paraffin waxes) and chemical energy storage (e.g. silica gel/water, sulphuric acid/water). The appendices gives detailed descriptions of the technical and economic aspects of the topics and comparisons are made wherever possible. The background to solar air heating is contained in the introduction, followed by a section which summarises and correlates the detail of the appendices. Based on the work reviewed, conclusions are drawn and areas with the greatest potential idenitifed for investigation. (A)

Authors: Reilly R.W., Brown D.R., Huber H.D.
Title: Cost of heat from a seasonal source.
Authors with affiliations: Reilly, R.W.; Brown, D.R.; Huber, H.D.
Abstract: Results are reported of an investigation to estimate the cost of aquifer thermal energy storage from a seasonal heat source. The cost of supplying energy (hot water) from an ATES system is estimated. Three types of loads are investigated: point demands, residential developments, and a multidistrict city. Several technical and economic factors are found to control the economic performance of an ATES system. Costs are found to be prohibitive for systems of small size, long transmission distances, and employing expensive purchased thermal energy. ATES is found to be cost-competitive with oil- fired and electric hot water delivery systems under a broad range of potential situations.-from STAR, 21(8), 1983
Index Keywords: aquifer; cost; thermal energy storage

Title: Economic summary of non-woody agricultural biomass.
Abstract: The resource base is discussed in terms of production, usability, environmental effects and the costs of using non-woody biomass. The agricultural biomass harvesting, transportation systems, and the storage of non-woody agricultural biomass are discussed. The utilization of non-woody agricultural biomass and the demands that may be met with this product as a heat energy source are described. Also discussed is equipment availability for non-woody agricultural biomass combustion uses. -from STAR, 20(16), 1982

Title: Preliminary assessment of promising nonaquifer STES.
Authors with affiliations: Blahnik, D.E.
Abstract: A preliminary evaluation of promising Seasonal Thermal Energy Storage (STES) concepts is underway at the Pacific Northwest Laboratory (PNL). The Thermal Energy Storage (TES) concepts being evaluated include pond, lake cavern, tank, earth, rock, and ice storage. All these concepts appear to be technically feasible and have potential to become economically feasible for particular markets and sites. Additional research and development for each concept is needed to establish design criteria, reduce costs, and eliminate uncertainties that stand in the way of implementation. Probably the most important development need is for reliable, low cost insulation and lining methods.

Title: Potential energy and capacity gains from flood control storage reallocation at existing US hydropower reservoirs.
Authors with affiliations: Eichert, B.S.; Bonner, V.R.
Abstract: This paper describes the procedures and results of an investigation to evaluate potential increases in nationwide hydropower production that could be achieved by reallocation of flood control storage at existing hydropower reservoirs. -from US Govt Reports Announcements, 10, 1082

Title: Coal and the environment.
Abstract: Produced by the Commission on Energy and the Environment, contains the following chapters: the coal industry: decline and renaissance; prospects for coal; framework of environmental control; deep mining; subsidence; spoil: dereliction and pit closures; opencast mining; coal markets; transport, handling and storage; conversion to substitute fuels; combustion technology; combustion residues; sources, quantities, control and effects; environmental effects of burning coal in urban areas; and the planning process reconciling the interests.-from CEGB Digest

Title: Papers presented at the International Conference on Energy Storage held at Brighton, U.K. on April 29 to May 1, 1981. Volume 2.
Abstract: Contains remainder of papers presented at the conference with information on workshop sessions. Relevant individual papers are abstracted elsewhere.

Title: Transient thermal analysis of phase change thermal energy storage systems with internal longitudinal fins of different geometries.
Authors with affiliations: Yimer, B.
Abstract: An analytical model was developed to evaluate the effects of internal longitudinal fins of different fin cross section on the rate of solidification/melting in an energy storage system that uses phase change material. The model was developed to determine the temperature distribution, solid/liquid interface location, and rate of solidification/melting of phase change material contained in a cylindrical annulus. Numerical results using the model were obtained for systems both with and without internal fins. The results show that addition of internal fins improve the rate of solidification. (A)
Index Keywords: augmentation; heat exchanger; Heat transfer

Title: The thermal behaviour of oscillating squeeze films.
Authors with affiliations: Tichy, J.; Smith, R.N.
Abstract: An analytical solution to the energy equation is provided for oscillating squeeze film flow, such as that which occurs in squeeze film damper bearings. Assumptions are: (a) the usual lubrication conditions for two-dimensional flow, (b) small oscillations, and (c) constant viscosity. Specific conditions are established for the last assumption, which may be in force for stably operated squeeze film bearings. Relatively simple expressions are presented for the thermal performance variables (temperature field, average temperature, Nusselt number) for a variety of cases. The results are interesting from a heat transfer point of view in that the proper energy balance consists of dissipation, conduction, and storage terms, rather than convection terms as is usual in lubrication studies. Thus inferences drawn from other thermal analyses may be in error. Both average cross-film temperature rise and heat transfer are seen to increase from zero Peclet number and asymptotically approach constant values. Due to the negligible convection conditions, the conventional definitions of bulk temperature, Nusselt number and Peclet number are not appropriate. As a result of the thermal storage effect, interesting temporal phase-shift and temperature swing effects are exhibited. (A)
Index Keywords: hydrodynamic lubrication

Title: Wind power. 1979 October, 1981 (citations from the NTIS Data Base).
Abstract: Restricted to research funded the the US Government, citations cover the use of wind power for generating electricity, comparative analyses of wind power, energy storage and wind turbine design and performance. Contains 317 citations, 182 of which are new to the previous edition.

Authors: O'Callaghan P.W., Smith I.E., Probert S.D., Bell M.A.
Title: Thermal energy storage systems (Part 1).
Source title: (Commission of the European Communities, Energy Series; EUR 7266)
Authors with affiliations: O'Callaghan, P.W.; Smith, I.E.; Probert, S.D.; Bell, M.A.
Abstract: Research into the viability of using saturated solutions of inorganic salts for thermal energy storage has shown that energy densities of between 2 and 4 times that of thermal storage in water are attainable over the temperature interval 30o to 70oC. The operation of a viable storage device using saturated solutions depends primarily on the ability to remove heat from the hot solution without its supercooling and without fouling the heat exchanger. Two types of heat exchanger were demonstrated which fulfilled these requirements: 1) used a fluidized bed of coarse particles; 2) was continuously mechanically cleaned. A small sized (46 l) thermal store was constructed and tested. Its measured thermal discharge performance showed a high degree of stratification and good agreement with predictions from a simple mathematical model. Its design appears to offer considerable scope for improvement and development in terms of thermal performance, reliability. and comparatively low cost. -Authors

Title: Regional analysis of potential energy production from agricultural wastes: a technical and economic study.
Source title: (Commission of the European Communities, Energy Series; EUR 7537)
Authors with affiliations: Have, H.
Abstract: The possibilities for utilization of agricultural wastes for energy production are analysed in two Danish counties, Ringkoebing and Vestsjaelland, with differnt agricultural production patterns. Quantitative analysis shows that the major waste products, surplus straw, waste wood and animal waste, with present techniques can meet about 28% of the demand for heat energy (mostly space heating) in both counties. The potential coverage from straw, wood and animal waste is bout 3, 3 and 22% in Ringkoebing and 18, 2 and 8% in Vestsjaelland. A technical analysis indicates that direct combustion is the most favorable conversion method for straw and wood while biological conversion at present is best suited for animal waste. An economic analysis based on costs of collection, storage, transport and conversion was made. Apart from being economically attractive in many cases waste utilization for energy production also has positive effects on foreign balance of payments, employment and supply safety. It has additional advantages. -from Author
Index Keywords: biological conversion; biomass; Denmark; Ringkoebing; Vestsjaelland

Authors: Bach W., Pankrath J., Schneider S.H.
Title: Food-climate interactions. Proceedings of an international workshop, Berlin (West), December 1980.
Source title: Food-climate interactions. Proceedings of an international workshop, Berlin (West), December 1980.
Affiliations: Center for Applied Climatology and Environmental Studies, Uniersity of Munster, Munster, Germany., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bach, W., Center for Applied Climatology and Environmental Studies, Uniersity of Munster, Munster, Germany., Germany; Pankrath, J., Center for Applied Climatology and Environmental Studies, Uniersity of Munster, Munster, Germany., Germany; Schneider, S.H., Center for Applied Climatology and Environmental Studies, Uniersity of Munster, Munster, Germany., Germany
Abstract: Forms the third part of a 'trilogy' together with: Man's Impact on climate (1979), and Interactions of energy and climate (1980), which present the proceedings of conferences carried out within the framework of a project: 'Impacts of Air Pollution on Climate', sponsored by the Federal German Republic's Federal Environment Agency, Umweltbundesamt. Deals with 'vital' climate/society relationship issues, in particular the implications for international food production of climatic change/variation. Papers are grouped in two sections: 1) deals with climate as a hazard to food production systems; 2) considers climate as a resource. Innovative policies concerning food production, storage, and distribution, and agricultural finance and insurance are presented. -C.J.Barrow
Index Keywords: agricultural finance; climate; insurance; society

Authors: Fox R.L., Donaldson A.B., Mulac A.J.
Title: Development of technology for downhole steam production
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE/DOE Enhanced Oil Recovery Symposium, EOR 1981
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fox, R.L., Sandia National Laboratories, United States; Donaldson, A.B., Sandia National Laboratories, United States; Mulac, A.J., Sandia National Laboratories, United States
Abstract: Two concepts for downhole production of steam for drive operations have been selected for comparative development. The two designs differ in method of transferring heat from hot combustion gases to produce steam. A low pressure combustion design transfers energy to water through a heat exchanger thus enabling the combustion process to be conducted at a pressure less than the injection pressure; a high pressure combustion design mixes the combustion gases directly with water, resulting in the injection of steam and combustion gases into the reservoir. The comparative development program has included analysis of energy efficiency, computational examination of recovery, core recovery experiments, and field evaluation. Field tests have been conducted under low reservoir injection pressure (2.76 MPa). The tests were carried out in a 260 m (800 ft) deep reservoir utilizing a 2.5 acre five spot pattern. Data collected from injection and production wells included fluid flow rates, fluid compositions, and energy content. The reservoir conditions were monitored by a combination of global flow measurements and simultaneous core flow tests. Test resufts have demonstrated that the recovery with the high pressure combustion design is equivalent to the low pressure design at low reservoir pressure. The injection of combustion gases with steam have reduced the quantity of air contaminents released to the atmosphere. © Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE/DOE Enhanced Oil Recovery Symposium, EOR 1981. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Computational efficiency; Digital storage; Energy efficiency; Flow of fluids; Oil fields; Petroleum reservoir evaluation; Recovery; Steam; Combustion pro-cess; Development programs; Fluid composition; High-pressure combustion; Injection pressures; Production wells; Reservoir conditions; Reservoir pressures; Enhanced recovery

Title: Submission to the Commission on Energy and the Environment. Topic 2: Transport, storage and handling of coal and ash.
Abstract: This report summarises CEGB experience of, and views on, the environmental impacts arising from the transportation, storage and handling both of the coal supplied to power stations, and of the ash and dust arising from combustion. (from paper)

Title: Improved irrigation and energy efficiency in Central Nebraska, U.S.A.
Authors with affiliations: Stansbury, M.R.; Cox, R.
Abstract: The Central Nebraska Public Power and Irrigation District (CNPPID) was formed in the 1930's to provide irrigation water and power to a four-county area in central Nebraska, USA. The storage, distribution, and power facilities were fully adequate at the time they were constructed and were planned for eventual expansion to additional areas. However, changes in cropping patterns, a need to provide full irrigation service, rising ground water levels and increased operation and maintenance costs created a need to improve and modernize the irrigation facilities. In addition, significant increases in fuel costs have made several potential hydroelectric sites appear to be feasible for construction. Beginning in 1970, the District initiated an extensive program to modernize its irrigation facilities and add hydroelectric generating capacity. The paper describes the steps being taken to improve and modernize the system. (from authors abstract)

Title: Windpower: a handbook on wind energy conversion systems.
Authors with affiliations: Hunt, V.D.
Abstract: The major topics covered by this handbook are; wind characteristics; fundamental operation of wind energy conversion systems (WECS); system design characteristics; towers; electric power; conversion and storage systems; wind energy conversion systems applications; the Federal Wind Energy Program; commercialisation; environmental, institutional and legal barriers; international development; and the future of wind power.

Authors: Sexon B., Slack G., Musgrove P., Lipman N., Dunn P.
Title: Aspects of a wind energy conversion system.
Issue: (ed.), Oxford, U.K. Pergamon Press Ltd., 1981, Topic D, Paper D4, p.153-158. (ISBN 0-08-027290-8)
Authors with affiliations: Sexon, B.; Slack, G.; Musgrove, P.; Lipman, N.; Dunn, P.
Abstract: Describes a particular system of wind turbine which is backed up by a short term battery storage facility and a diesel generator. The batteries store any excess energy from the turbine, delivering it to the load if the turbine is unable to produce sufficient power at any instant. The diesel generator ensures the continuation of supply during any lengthy period of calm which may occur. (from authors abstract)

Title: The role of joint thermal/pumped-storage/hydro-energy centres in river-basin planning.
Issue: (Athens, Greece: Nov. 5-9, 1979), Oxford, U.K., Pergamon Press, 1981, p.125-147. (ISBN 0-08-025702-X
Authors with affiliations: Calvert, J.D.
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to present details regarding present and proposed use of pumped-storage hydro developments as a joint multi-purpose facility for hydroelectric and thermal plant power. This combined concept is presently employed at two energy complexes in the United States of America and is an important new tool in river-basin planning for water and energy resources. (from paper)
Index Keywords: Water resources

Title: Participation of pumped-storage hydroelectric stations in the utilization of solar energy by means of solar cells, etc., within an integrated power generation system.
Issue: (Athens, Greece: Nov.5-9, 1979), Oxford, U.K., Pergamon Press, 1981, p.467-476. (ISBN 0-08-025702-X)
Authors with affiliations: Syntzanakis, G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Hydroelectricity Prospects in the New Energy Situation, Proceedings of a Symposium of the Committee on Electric Power of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, held in Athens, Greece on November 5-9, 1979.
Abstract: The volume is divided into five sections, each of which covers a theme discussed during the Symposium, and contains a theme report and a number of national reports. The sections are: Trends in hydroelectric schemes and related problems with reference to the economic criteria applied; Hydroelectric schemes in the context of multi-purpose development plans and their varied impact on the environment; Technological trends in the design and construction of hydroelectric schemes; Operation of hydroelectric schemes as an integral part of transmission and supply systems; Economic evaluation of conventional and pumped storage single-purpose or multi-purpose hydroelectric schemes and related financial questions. Relevant individual papers are abstracted elsewhere.

Title: Load management and thermal energy storage: information covering data from 1978-1980 ( bibliography).
Source title: Vance Bibliographies, Public Administration Series, Bibliography
Authors with affiliations: Weaver, R.
Abstract: About 150 references compiled to present the electric energy end-use community with information on thermal energy storage. - from Author

Title: Design study of a regenerative hydrostatic split power transmission for a city bus.
Authors with affiliations: Bowns; Vaughan, N.D.D.E.
Abstract: This paper discusss factors affecting the design and operation of a hydrostatic split power transmission for a city bus drive using an hydraulic accumulator for energy storage. The salient features of the accumulator selection are detailed for use in a mobile regenerative application. The incorporation of the accumulator into the transmission and the basic operation are also discussed. Alternatives for operating this transmission during braking were examined by digital computer simulation to assess the braking capability and the energy recovery potential. The acceleration ability using accumulator stored energy was similarly examined and has shown performance levels comparable with cnventional buses. Some recommendations are made for a suitable bus regenerative system. (from authors' abstract)

Title: The Volvo city bus. Hydrostatic transmission
Authors with affiliations: Evans, P.A.; Karlsson, A.
Abstract: A flywheel energy storage system coupled to a flexible and efficient hydrostatic transmission, the Volvo city bus offers improved fuel efficiency and reduced noise and exhaust pollution. (A)

Title: Hydrostatic drives and their control for energy saving.
Authors with affiliations: Wusthof, P.
Abstract: Hydrostatic drives offer a good potential for energy saving. Energy saving can be acheived by a hydrostatic drive with primary control including automotive control of the complete drive. This system is mostly applied to service vehicles. More effective energy saving can be achieved by hydrostatic drives with secondary control and energy storage. A system for a city srvice bus is illustrated containing hydrostatic-mechanical transmission and high and low pressure accumulators. (A)

Title: Electric power generation via tides and waves. January, 1970 - June, 1981. (Citations from the engineering index data base).
Abstract: The use of tidal and wave energy for the generation of electric power is covered. The engineering and economic aspects are emphasized, and theoretical analysis of the power potential of selected sites around the world are presented. The combination of tidal power and pumped storage is also featured. (Contains 164 citations fully indexed and includes a title list.)

Title: Thermal energy storage and regeneration.
Authors with affiliations: Schmidt, F.W.; Willmott, A.J.
Abstract: Contents: thermal energy storage, single-blow operating mode: infinite fluid heat capacity and simplified models, single-blow operating mode: finite conductivity model, basic concepts in counterflow regenerators, prediction of transient response of heat storage units with timewise variations in inlet fluid temperature and mass flow rate finite conductivity models of counterflow regenerators, nonlinear models of counterflow regenerators, improved computational methodology for regenerators, parallel-flow regenerators, transient performance of counterflow regenerators, heat storage exchangers, packed beds, design optimization, and heat transfer and pressure drop correlations.

Title: World energy directory.
Authors with affiliations: Bauly, J.A.; Bauly, C.B.
Abstract: This directory has been compiled from a worldwide survey of energy projects, and includes all research and development project where 'energy' is the main theme, as well as those which aim to make significant advanced in technological practice or scientific knowledge. Product development is included if the product introduces novel features that have resulted from a significant research and development programme. The following areas are included: the harnessing of renewable resources, such as wave, geothermal, wind, tidal and solar energy; energy storage; energy handling machinery and plant such as heat pumps, engines, and boilers. The finding, extraction and mining of fuels are not included .

Title: Ocean wave energy conversion.
Authors with affiliations: McCormick, M.E.
Abstract: Describes the nine or so basic wave energy conversion techniques which include; heaving and pitching bodies, cavity resonators, pressure devices, surge-wave energy converters, particle motion converters, Salter's nodding duck , Cockerell's raft , Russel's rectifier and wave focussing techniques. Contains an extensive bibliography. (114 refs)
Index Keywords: anchoring; Energy storage; Mooring; patents; wave modification

Title: The Strangford Lough tidal energy product.
Issue: (Cambridge, U.K.: Sep. 23-25, 1981), Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper K2, p.315-326.
Authors with affiliations: Cochrane, S.R.; Wilson, E.M.
Abstract: This paper describes a new appraisal of Strangford Lough as a source of tidal energy. Storage and tidal data have been used in the computation of the annual energy which would be obtained from a barrage located in Strangford Narrows. Suitable turbo-generators have been selected and optimal speeds, rated head, installed capacity and submergence requirements determined. Annual energy outputs for various combinations of turbines and refilling sluices have been calculated and the upper limits of development established. Several possible barrage sites have been considered and a final preferred site has been selected at Kilclief Point near the outlet of Strangford Narrows to the Irish Sea. Barrage construction has been considered in sufficient detail to determine the likely forms of construction for the Power Station, the sluiceways, and the embankment sections. The use of the barrage as a road link is discussed, as is the effect of such a barrage on flood control, land drainage and sewage disposal. The major environmental issues are outlined and problem areas requiring further investigation and research are identified. The principal conclusion of the study is that despite the rather small tidal range at Strangford, the combination of very large storage with short barrage length make future tidal energy costs attractive when compared with predicted oil-based electricity prices. (from authors abstract)

Title: Hydrodynamic machinery.
Authors with affiliations: Wislicenus, G.F.
Abstract: The author presents some historical aspects in the development of hydrodynamics machinery and a few problems in this field with are of current interest in association with low head hydraulic turbines and pump-turbines for hydraulic energy storage. (C.W.)

Title: SPEICHERUNG UND MOBILISIERUNG VON KOHLENHYDRATEN UND LIPIDEN IN DER BLATTWESPE GILPINIA HERCYNIAE
Affiliations: Institut Für Forstzoologie, Universität Göttingen, Büsgenweg 3, Göttingen, 3400, Germany
Authors with affiliations: SCHOPF, R., Institut Für Forstzoologie, Universität Göttingen, Büsgenweg 3, Göttingen, 3400, Germany
Abstract: Von Larven (drei Populationen, L3, L4‐, L4, L5‐ und alte L5‐ Larven), adulten Weibchen vor (Iv) und nach (***irt) Eiablage, Kokons (K) und Exucien (E) wurden die Konzentrationen von löslichen Kohlenhydraten. Alanin, Prolin, Glykogen und Lipiden sowie die Frisch‐ und Trockengewichte bestimmt. Aus den Ergebnissen werden ***Ruckschlusse auf den Energiestoffwechsel der Entwicklungsstadien Embryo, Larve und Imago gezogen. Für die sorgfältige Mitarbeit danke ich Frl. G. Hühne, Frl. C. Mignat und Frau T. Görsdorf. Der Deutschen Forschungsgemeinschaft sei für die finanzielle Unterstützung gedankt. STORAGE AND MOBILIZATION OF CARBOHYDRATES AND LIPIDS IN THE SAWFLY GILPINIA HERCYNIAE The concentrations of soluble carbohydrates (Fig. 2), alanine and proline (Fig. 3), glycogen and lipids (Fig. 4) and the weights (Fig, 1, Tab, I) of larvae (three populations, L3, L4‐, L4, L5‐ and old L5‐instar larvae), adult females before (Iv) and after (In) oviposition, cocoons (K) and exuviae (E) (Tab II) were determined. Embryonic, larval and adult stages of development have characteristic types of energy metabolism. The lipid catabolism of the embryonic stage is substituted during larval development by anabolic pathways based on resorbed sugars absorbed from spruce needles. During the first larval stages these soluble carbohydrates are directed to a glycogen pool in relatively large amounts. This pool is only slightly enlarged whereas lipids are synthesized in relatively large amounts between the 14th and 28th day after oviposition. Metamorphosis is correlated with a decrease of glycogen. Lipids are used as an energy source by imagines and in eggs. “Energy” is distributed in the body by movement of trehalose in the larval stage and by a proline‐alanine‐shuttle in the adult stage. 1981 The Netherlands Entomological Society

Title: Status Report of Radioactive Waste Management in Canada and Information about Current Researches at Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories
Source title: Nippon Genshiryoku Gakkaishi/Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Central Res. Inst. of Elec. Power Ind., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mahara, Y., Central Res. Inst. of Elec. Power Ind., Japan
Abstract: In this article, three topics of the radioactive waste management in Canada are reported; i.e. (1) the general philosophy and criteria on managements, and the operating disposal methods in situ, (2) the program of storage and disposal for a spent fuel as a high level radioactive waste, (3) studies on a underground migration of radionuclides at Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories (CRNL). The Canadian program to control the spent fuel is consisted of an interium storage(for a short-term less than 100 yr) in an aboveground facility and an ultimate storage (or disposal) in an underground one, excavated into a hard rock (e.g. Pluton), in a precambrian shield at the depth of more than 500 m. Both type of storage are planning to store the spent fuel without reprocessing. A brief information about the field studies, conducted for past 35 yr at CRNL, is mentioned here. Especially, the radionuclides migration is associated with a high liquid waste which was directly injected into ground in 1954 and 1955. © 1981, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Canada; CRNL; interium storage; Pluton; precambrian shield; radioactive waste disposal; radioactive waste management; spent fuels; ultimate storage; underground migration

Title: Surface characteristics of ecosystems
Abstract: The reception of incoming energy fluxes, their transformations, and the mix of outgoing fluxes all depend on physical characteristics of the ecosystem, which couple the ecosystem with its environments of sun, air, and substrate. The ecosystem (which might be a forest glade, a cornfield, or a wood lot) is above the size scale of a leaf, an insect, an animal, and a human being as a locus of energy transactions. Horizontal uniformity is the principal criterion. Areal extent influences development of the unique atmospheric boundary layer of an ecosystem, hence its coupling with the atmosphere. Size tends to be small in urban landscapes and larger in areas of mechanized flatland agriculture. As size increases, the interaction with neighboring ecosystems diminishes. Land form, especially in dissected topography, affects the income of radiant energy and the power of the atmosphere to ventilate an ecosystem, illustrated in the contrasts of temperature in concave and convex topography. It also affects the substrate. The soil of an ecosystem provides essential storage space for energy, water, and other substances. As this storage is alternately drawn down and replenished, it evens out the responses of the ecosystem to fluctuations in radiation and other inputs. The sun, a major but variable source of energy for all ecosystems, is the only source for the energy-conversion process of photosynthesis, which yields the highest-grade output that ecosystems produce; it also provides lower-grade (longer in wavelength) energy that is important in other aspects of ecosystem energy budgets. © 1981 Academic Press Inc.

Title: Substrate energy storage in aquatic ecosystems and its place in their energy budgets
Abstract: This chapter discusses energy relations in ecosystems that possess a large internal capacity to store heat. Aquatic ecosystems characteristically are deep, and this implies a storage capacity that is large even if stratification develops. Whether its components are emergent plants, submerged macrophytes, or algae and other microphytes, the large depth of a supporting fluid distinguishes aquatic from terrestrial ecosystems. The fluidity of water, its low viscosity, and large specific heat make it an ideal heat carrier, and turbulence in a water body efficiently diffuses sensible heat, especially in the upper photosynthesizing zone. Aquatic ecosystems extract sensible heat from the atmosphere more easily than terrestrial ones because their daytime surface temperature is generally lower than that of the air in summer and almost always so in spring. Aquatic ecosystems also extract vapor from moist air. The chapter discusses the variations in the energy budget that includes the diurnal energy cycle; irregular variations; the annual energy cycle; changes from year to year; and spatial contrasts. © 1981, Academic Press Inc.

Title: Substrate heat flux in terrestrial ecosystems
Abstract: This chapter discusses the substrate heat flux in terrestrial ecosystems. The subterranean part of a terrestrial ecosystem has a substantial capacity to take in, store, and pay out heat, which buffers the fluctuations in ecosystem temperature that result from fluctuations in absorbed radiant energy. The substrate flows of heat determine the warming and cooling of ecosystem soil and its overall temperature, which affects water uptake, decomposition of carbon compounds, fixing of atmospheric nitrogen and other vital processes. Ecosystem soil forms a closed system, and in analysis heat flux data are combined with thermal capacity. The thermal capacity of a substrate is one factor governing how much heat can be removed from the surface and is the product of specific heat per kilogram of the material and its density. Substrate heat fluxes are large in desert ecosystems because much of the heat-storing soil body lies exposed to incoming radiation and so becomes the active surface. Storage of sensible heat in the soil does not occur in one continuous 6-month wave, but rather is the accumulation of hundreds of daytime intakes and nocturnal withdrawals of heat. Substrate storage of heat is a clear expression of seasonality, which is a large-scale variable in the energy climate of a region. © 1981, Academic Press Inc.

Authors: Wong J.M., Flanagan R.C., Munro M.B.
Title: Hoop-wound fibre composite flywheel design by parameter sensitivity
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wong, J.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Canada; Flanagan, R.C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Canada; Munro, M.B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Canada
Abstract: The sensitivity and behavior of both the radial and tangential stress patterns as well as component radial growth compatibility in hoop-wound fibre composite rotors were analyzed. Both physical and material properties, representative of the glass, graphite and Kevlar fibre families were explored. For single rings, the dominant parameters were found to be the thickness ratio, physical interfacial pressures and the material modulus ratio [formula omitted]. In an actual rotor design, specific swept volume and specific energy storage should be maximized using practical manufacture techniques and available fibre materials. Several rotor designs are explored including: multimaterial - multiring and single material multiring with low modulus interfacial wraps; single material and mutimaterial ring-on-ring with manufacture controlled interfacial pressure; and multimaterial bi-annular ring-on-ring with dynamic interfacial loading through material selection. All designs can satisfy the radial/tangential stress patterns and the radial growth compatibility requirements. However, from a manufacture and material availability point of view, the multimaterial ring-on-ring designs using both manufacture and material property dynamic loading interfacial pressure control was judged promising. With proper manufacture/design they could meet the stress pattern and radial compatibility requirements as well as provide the high specific parameters desired. © 1981, Elsevier Scientific Publishing Company

Title: Broad-scale transformations of fossil energy
Abstract: This chapter discusses the broad-scale transformations of fossil energy. Fossil energy in the management of extensively exploited ecosystems includes wilderness and wildlands; rangeland; and forest. Ecosystems that receive outside material inputs that contain fossil energy are receiving an energy subsidy. The chapter describes the fossil-energy conversions in farm operations. Land preparation and management is back-breaking work, and new machines are introduced; each one represented an input to the farm of urban labor and industrial energy that increasingly came from coal. These machines are horse-drawn for several decades, and the inputs of fossil energy to agriculture consisted largely of that incorporated in the steel used. The economic and energetic integration of maize, oats, and alfalfa ecosystems into an operating farm system is made possible by physical integration of material flows. Green chop is carried from the alfalfa field to the cow barn for daily consumption; harvested hay and corn are collected at the farmstead and after processing (grain drying, silage shredding) are put into storage in corn cribs, silos, and hay barns. © 1981, Academic Press Inc.

Authors: Osumi Y., Suzuki H., Kato A., Oguro K., Nakane M.
Title: Effect of Metal-Substitution on Hydrogen Storage Properties for Mischmetal-Nickel Alloys
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Midorigaoka, Ikeda-shi 563, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Osumi, Y., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Midorigaoka, Ikeda-shi 563, Japan; Suzuki, H., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Midorigaoka, Ikeda-shi 563, Japan; Kato, A., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Midorigaoka, Ikeda-shi 563, Japan; Oguro, K., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Midorigaoka, Ikeda-shi 563, Japan; Nakane, M., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Midorigaoka, Ikeda-shi 563, Japan
Abstract: A study was made on the characteristics of the hydrogen absorption and desorption of Mm^-A2Ni3 and MmNi5_6B8 of which Mm or Ni in MmNi5 were partially substituted by the metals (A and B). The dissociation pressure of Mm3-mA1Ni3 (A : Al, B, Cu, Mn and Si) hydrides was higher than that of MmNi5 hydride, whereas the dissociation pressure of Mm∗ N′h-yBy (B : Al, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, Mn, Si, Ti, V and Zn) hydrides depended on the content of the metals, which substituted partially for nickel, and log P decreased in proportion to y. The dissociation pressure of MmKu-vBy hydrides decreased in the following order : Mn>Al> Cr>Si>Fe>Co>Cu. A linear correlation was found between log P and the cell volume of the alloy for the MmNi5_yBr The trend of lower pressures along with the Mn and Al contents were in agreement with the cell volume correlation observed in other AB5 compounds. MmNi4.5B0.5 (B : Al, Cr, Mn and Si) and MmNi2i5Co2i5 could easily be activated and react fairly readily with hydrogen to form the hydrides MmNi4.5Al0.51I4.9, MmNi2,5Co2.5H5.2, Mm∗ Ni4.5Cr0.5H6.3, MmNi4.5Mn0.5H6.6 and MmNi4.5Si0.5H3.8 (hydrogen contents: 1.2, 1.2, 1.4, 1.5 and 0.9wt%, respectively) under a hydrogen pressure of 60atm at room temperature. The enthalpy changes in hydride formation determined from the dissociation isotherms for MmNi4.5Al0.5-H, MmNi2.5Co2.5-H, MmNi4.5Cr0.5-H and MmNi4.5Mn0.5-H systems were -5.5, —8.4, —6.1 and —4.2 kcal/mol H2, respectively. These values were smaller than or nearly the same as those of LaNi5 and MmNi5. The dissociation pressures were 2. 5, 2. 0, 4. 8 and 2. Oatm at 20°C, respectively. The apparent activation energy of hydrogen desorption for these alloys were smaller than those of LaNi5 and MmNi5. For MmNi4.5Al0>5, MmNi2.5» Co2.5, MmNi4.5Cr0.5 and MmNi4.5Mn0.5 the hydrogen absorption-desorption cycles were repeated 500 times but no variation in the hydrogen absorption-desorption capacity was observed. The cyclic studies with MmNi4.5Mn0.5 showed that the spalling occurred more rapidly than with MmNi2#5Co2.5 and MmNi4.5Cr0.5. © 1981, The Chemical Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Title: Performance and Evaluation of a Greenhouse Solar Collection with Underground Heat Storage System. 1. A Steady State Analysis by Means of One Dimensional Models
Affiliations: College of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Yayoi 1-1-1, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takakura, T., College of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Yayoi 1-1-1, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113, Japan; Yamakawa, K., College of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Yayoi 1-1-1, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113, Japan
Abstract: A simple steady-state and one-dimensional model has been developed in order to analyse the performance of a greenhouse solar collection with underground heat storage system which is being predominantly adopted in Japanese protected cultivation. The objective of this system is to store solar heat during the daytime by circulating the warm greenhouse air through the pipes buried in the greenhouse soil, and to gain heat from the soil through the pipes during the nighttime. However, the problem is that the frequent attack of energy crisis on Japanese protected cultivation has forced the farmers to adopt this system without any quantitative analysis. Of course, some experimental results are available but theoretical analysis has not been conducted as far as the authors know. The purpose of the present study is, therefore, to check the performance of the system as well as to evaluate the parameters involved in the system. The effectiveness of the temperature increase in the greenhouse is found to be evaluated by the ratio of the overall heat transfer coefficient around pipes times the total pipe surface area plus the overall heat transfer coefficient through the greenhouse soil surface times the greenhouse floor surface area to the overall heat transfer coefficient at the greenhouse cover times the greenhouse surface area (see Fig. 3). It is also apparent from this ratio that the heat release from the greenhouse soil surface is rather significant in this system and in general it would be 20—30% of the heat gain through the buried pipes. The effect of the material difference of the pipes has been examined and it is concluded that the effect on the greenhouse air temperature is within 0.2°C among PVC, polyethylene and steel (Table 3). From the evaluation of the pipe dimensions, it is concluded that the difference of thickness is not significant and the optimum diameter is 11cm as far as the greenhouse air temperature is concerned (Table 4). In order to select an adequate fan for the system, the friction loss due to the plenum duct made of concrete can not be neglected. It is found that the adoption of smooth ducts could reduce the friction loss of this part significantly and the consumption of electricity, consequently the greenhouse air temperature is increased (Fig. 4). The same tendency is clear in the case of two way air flow direction system against one way (Fig. 5). © 1981, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Nakagawa H., Takahashi Y., Fujimoto Y., Maeda S., Sugimoto I.
Title: The Properties of Water of Crystallization of Sodium Prasterone Sulfate

Abstract: The properties of water of crystallization of sodium prasterone sulfate (DHA·SO3Na·2H2O) were investigated by thermometric measurements. The anhydrous form (DHA·SO3Na) was very hygroscopic, and easily transformed to the dihydrate. The dihydrate was in a stable phase under ordinary storage conditions. If the released water molecules were not effectively exhausted in the dehydration process, a liquefaction phenomenon due to the interaction between water molecules and DHA·SO3Na was observed. The activation energy (ΔE) of the dehydration reaction from the dihydrate to the anhydrous form was determined by an isothermal method and a non-isothermal method (Ozawa method) under a constant water vapor pressure, [formula omitted] mmHg. ΔE obtained by the isothermal method was 31.5 kcal/mol and ΔE obtained by the Ozawa method was 31.3 kcal/mol. © 1981, The Pharmaceutical Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: activation energy; anhydrous form; dehydration; dihydrate; hydration; sodium prasterone sulfate; water of crystallization

Authors: Baum J.D., Daniel B.R., Zinn B.T.
Title: Determination of solid propellant admittances by the impedance tube method
Affiliations: Georgia Institute of Technology, School of Aerospace Engineering, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baum, J.D., Georgia Institute of Technology, School of Aerospace Engineering, Atlanta, GA, United States; Daniel, B.R., Georgia Institute of Technology, School of Aerospace Engineering, Atlanta, GA, United States; Zinn, B.T., Georgia Institute of Technology, School of Aerospace Engineering, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: The adaptation of the impedance tube technique for the measurement of solid propellant admittances and response functions is described. These quantities are needed for combustion stability analysis of solid rocket motors. The experimental set up consists of a tube with a disk of solid propellant sample placed at one end and a combination of an exhaust valve and an acoustic driver placed at the other end. Performing a test consists of turning on the acoustic driver to excite a standing wave of a predetermined frequency in the tube, ignition, and burnout of the solid propellant sample. During a test, acoustic pressure data is measured by fifteen pressure transducers distributed along a distance that includes, at least, two standing wave pressure minima. The data are transferred via a fast analog-to-digital converter to a minicomputer system for immediate storage and later analysis. The measured acoustic pressure amplitude and phase data are input into a newly developed data reduction procedure that is based upon the solution of the impedance tube wave equations, for the determination of the admittance and response function of the tested solid propellant sample and the acoustic energy losses in the gas phase. The paper presents results obtained in a series of tests conducted with an A-14 propellant. The paper demonstrates the capability of the developed experimental technique to determine simultaneously the acoustic characteristics of the flow inside the impedance tube and the admittance of the burning solid propellant for the duration of the experiment. © 1981 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.

Authors: Ballantyne A., Woodroffe J.A., Cronburg T.L., Rudder R.R., Bina M.J.
Title: Modeling of the interaction of 10.6 pm laser radiation with reinforced plastics
Affiliations: Avco-Everett Research Laboratory, Inc, Everett, MA, United States; Air Force Weapons Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, Sunnyvale, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ballantyne, A., Avco-Everett Research Laboratory, Inc, Everett, MA, United States; Woodroffe, J.A., Avco-Everett Research Laboratory, Inc, Everett, MA, United States; Cronburg, T.L., Avco-Everett Research Laboratory, Inc, Everett, MA, United States; Rudder, R.R., Air Force Weapons Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Bina, M.J., Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, Sunnyvale, CA, United States
Abstract: The objective of this work was to develop a phenomenological model of pulsed CO2 laser interaction with reinforced composite materials. Experimental observation has shown that the multilayer composite material delaminates under pulsed CO2 laser irradiation. This is a consequence of the energy storage mechanism arising out of a finite absorption depth to the laser radiation. A heat transfer model was developed to describe the observed delamination behavior of the composite materials. Good agreement was obtained between the model predictions ami experimental data. The model has been used to extrapolate to high average power irradiation. © 1981 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.

Title: Adaptive Strategies at the Ecosystem Level: Examples from Two Benthic Marine Systems
Affiliations: Institute of Zoology, University of Vienna., Währingerstraße 17/VI, Vienna, A-1090, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Ott, J.A., Institute of Zoology, University of Vienna., Währingerstraße 17/VI, Vienna, A-1090, Austria
Abstract: Abstract. Adaptive strategies on the ecosystem level are demonstrated using the properties of systems (community biomass, trophic level energy transfer). Development of stabilizing storages versus rapid turnover and energy transfer through the grazing food chain versus detritus food chain are shown to be adaptive processes leading towards an optimal performance of the system. A model of incorporation and processing of information in ecosystems is proposed which contains the essential features of evolution. The persistence of “interspecific altruism” is discussed. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: adaptive strategies; aquatic macrophytes; Benthic communities; community biomass; detritus food chain; evolution; grazing food chain; grazing rates

Authors: Tatake V.G., Desai T.S., Govindjee, Sane P.V.
Title: ENERGY STORAGE STATES OF PHOTOSYNTHETIC MEMBRANES: ACTIVATION ENERGIES AND LIFETIMES OF ELECTRONS IN THE TRAP STATES BY THERMOLUMINESCENCE METHOD

Abstract: Abstract Several methods discussed by R. Chen (1969) were used for the calculation of the activation energies (E), frequency factors (s) and mean lifetimes of electrons in trap states at glow peak temperatures (Tm) and at room temperature (Tr) from thermoluminescence glow peaks in spinach chloroplasts and Euglena cells. Results are presented for E calculated independently, i.e. without any assumptions regarding the frequency factors which were determined subsequently using the activation energy values thus calculated. The most reliable values for E, s, r(Tm) and (Tr) for the well‐resolved glow peaks Z(118 K), I(236 K), II(261 K), III(283 K), IV(298 K) and V(321 K) are as follows: The present comprehensive study has been compared with the earlier ones and the significance of the observed high frequency factors is discussed. It is concluded that only peaks I and II, related to photosystem II, follow the Randall–Wilkins (RW) theory, whereas peaks IV and V, related to photosystem I, do not. Authors: Poulos A.T., Hammond G.S., Burton M.E.
Title: PHOTO‐INDUCED ELECTRON TRANSFER FROM TRANSITION METAL CATIONS TO EXCITED STATES OF THE 10‐METHYLACRIDINIUM ION
Affiliations: Division of Natural Sciences of the University of California, Santa Cruz, California, United States; Olson Laboratories of Rutgers University, Newark, New Jersey, 07102, United States

Abstract: Abstract— Photo‐induced electron transfer from cuprous ion to electronically excited 10‐methyiacridinium tetrafluoroborate in acetonitrile‐water solutions is described. The final photoproducts are Cu2+ (aq) and 10,10′‐dimethyl‐9,9′‐biacridane. The proposed mechanism, based on microsecond flash excitation and fluorimetry experiments, is one‐electron transfer from Cu+ to the 10‐methylacridinium ion triplet state (and possibly the singlet state), followed by dimerization of the neutral acridinyl radical. Because the high energy photoproducts revert slowly to reactants, the system may have potential for storage and controlled recovery of light energy. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: MECHANISM OF THE PHOTOSENSITIZED REDOX REACTIONS OF ACRIDINE ORANGE IN AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS‐A SYSTEM OF INTEREST IN THE PHOTOCHEMICAL STORAGE OF SOLAR ENERGY
Affiliations: Photochemistry Unit, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Ontario, London, N6A 5B7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Chan, M.S., Photochemistry Unit, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Ontario, London, N6A 5B7, Canada; Bolton, J.R., Photochemistry Unit, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Ontario, London, N6A 5B7, Canada
Abstract: ‐We have carried out a very detailed study, using fluorescence and optical flash photolysis techniques, of the photoreduction of methyl viologen (MV2+) by the electron donor ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) in aqueous solution sensitized by the dye acridine orange (AOH+). A complete mechanism has been proposed which accounts for virtually all of the known observations on this reaction. This reaction is novel in that both the triplet and the singlet state of AOH+ appear to be active photochemically. We have shown that mechanisms previously proposed for this reaction are probably incorrect due to an artifact. At pH 7 the fluorescence quantum yield φs of AOH+ is 0.26 ± 0.02 and the fluorescence lifetime is 1.8 ± 0.2 ns. φs is pH dependent and reaches a maximum of 0.56 at pH 4. The fluorescence of AOH+ is quenched by MV2+ at concentrations above 1 mM and the quenching obeys Stern‐Volmer kinetics with a quenching rate constant of (1.0 ± 0.1) × 1010M−1 s−1. The quenching of the AOH+ excited singlet state by MV2+ almost certainly returns the AOH+ to its ground state with no photochemistry occurring. EDTA also quenches the fluorescence of AOH· with Stern‐Volmer kinetics but with a smaller rate constant (6.4 ± 0.5) × 108M−1s−1 at pH 7. In this case the quenching is reactive resulting in the formation of semireduced AOH. In the presence of MV2+, flash irradiation of AOH+ does result in the reversible formation of the semireduced MV† which absorbs at 603 nm. We attribute this to a photochemical reaction of the triplet state of AOH+ with MV2+. The initial quantum yield for formation of MV† (φMV:)0 was found to be constant at 0.10 ± 0.05 for [MV2+] from 5 × 10−5 to 1.0 × 10−3 with [AOH+] = 8 × 10−6M. Previous workers had found that (φMV:)0 appears to decrease with decreasing [AOH+]; however, on careful investigation, we found this was most probably due to quenching of the triplet state of AOH+ by trace amounts of oxygen. When EDTA is added to a mixture of AOH + and MV2+ at pH 7, the photochemical formation of MV† becomes irreversible as the [EDTA] is increased. The quantum yield for the irreversible formation of MV† exceeds 0.10 becoming as large as 0.16 for [EDTA] = 0.014M. This fact requires that an alternative photochemical process must be operative and we present evidence that this is a reaction of EDTA with the excited singlet state of AOH+ to produce the semi‐reduced AOH‐ which then reacts with MV2+ to produce MV†. The full kinetic scheme was tested by computer simulation and found to be totally consistent. This also enabled the processing of a full set of rate constants. When colloidal PtO2 was added to the optimal mixture [EDTA] = 3.4 × 10−2M; [MV2+] = 5 × 10−4M; [AOH+] = 4 × 10−5M; pH6 H2 gas was produced at a rate of 0.2μmol H2h−1. Thus, acridine orange should serve as an effective sensitizer in reactions designed to use solar energy to photolyze water. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Abstract: Bipedal hopping of kangaroo rats has been studied by making force plate records and X‐ray cinematograph films simultaneously. Calculations using the data so obtained, and anatomical data, show that energy saving by elastic storage is much less important than in kangaroos. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. Authors: MOLEERATANOND W., ASHBY B.H., KRAMER A., BERRY B.W., LEE W.
Title: Effect of a Di‐Thermal Storage Regime on Quality and Nutritional Changes and Energy Consumption of Frozen Boxed Beef
Affiliations: TRRF Lab., Univ. of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, 20742, United States; USDA's Transportation and Meat Science Research Laboratories, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States
Authors with affiliations: MOLEERATANOND, W., TRRF Lab., Univ. of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, 20742, United States, USDA's Transportation and Meat Science Research Laboratories, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States; ASHBY, B.H., TRRF Lab., Univ. of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, 20742, United States, USDA's Transportation and Meat Science Research Laboratories, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States; KRAMER, A., TRRF Lab., Univ. of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, 20742, United States, USDA's Transportation and Meat Science Research Laboratories, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States; BERRY, B.W., TRRF Lab., Univ. of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, 20742, United States, USDA's Transportation and Meat Science Research Laboratories, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States; LEE, W., TRRF Lab., Univ. of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, 20742, United States, USDA's Transportation and Meat Science Research Laboratories, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States
Abstract: Seven types of beef products were commercially packaged, frozen, and stored at top corner pallet positions in three rooms for a year. The storage temperatures were: (1) ‐23°C, constant; (2) ‐23°C and ‐21°C; (3) ‐21°C and ‐18°C. Compared to the ‐23°C, constant room (as reference), a net energy saving of 6 and 14% was obtained for the two di‐thermal storage rooms by maintaining the temperatures at the lower levels for one 12‐hr period followed by the higher levels for another 12‐hr period. The weight loss for most products was negligible, except for bulk‐packed hamburger patties which lost over 1%. The results on sensory, nutritional, and other quality attributes of frozen boxed beef products showed no serious quality damage from both constant and di‐thermal storage after 1 yr, except for MPB and beef patties whose practical shelf life was limited to 6 months. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: ŠOlmajer T., Kocjan D., Hadži D.

Abstract: Interactions of catecholamines with acidic sites in the biophase are likely to be involved in the control of the receptors activity as well as in storage and transport mechanisms. In view of the importance of the phenomena a model study of ethanolamine–phosphate complexes was made. The electrostatic interaction energy surface was calculated in the charge density multipole expansion approximation with terms up to quadrupole. The consecutive minimal energy conformation shows the importance for the interaction with the biophase of the catechol ring steric and electronic relation to the side chain. Authors: Nitta M., Tsuge T., Hiki Y., Kato R.
Title: Process and Accelerated Aging Test of Gang Bonding for Gold-Plated Tab Outer Leads
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Division, Nippon Electric Co., Ltd., 1-10, Nissin-cho, Fuchu-City, Tokyo, 183, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nitta, M., Computer Engineering Division, Nippon Electric Co., Ltd., 1-10, Nissin-cho, Fuchu-City, Tokyo, 183, Japan; Tsuge, T., Computer Engineering Division, Nippon Electric Co., Ltd., 1-10, Nissin-cho, Fuchu-City, Tokyo, 183, Japan; Hiki, Y., Computer Engineering Division, Nippon Electric Co., Ltd., 1-10, Nissin-cho, Fuchu-City, Tokyo, 183, Japan; Kato, R., Computer Engineering Division, Nippon Electric Co., Ltd., 1-10, Nissin-cho, Fuchu-City, Tokyo, 183, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the evaluation results of thermocompression GANG Bonding of gold-plated TAB outer leads to three kinds of metallized ceramic substrates. Gold-Selective Plating (GSP) substrates for multi-chip package, Thick Film (TF) substrates for multi-chip package and Single Chip Packages (SCP) which have a trimetal combination of refractory metal (tungsten), Nickel and Gold. The bonding parameters such as the bonding tool (thermode) temperature, pressure, bonding time and preheat temperature were examined on each substrate to get optimum values. As the result, a relation between pull strength and the lead deformation shows that the TAB leads should be bonded with 15-65 percent deformation, the recommended parameters are; the tool temperature of 380-430°C, the bonding pressure ranging from 35 to 45 kg/mm2, with the preheat temperature of 150°C and the bonding time from 1.0 to 2.5 seconds. The evaluation of initial bondability shows that TAB GANG Bonding has the capability of excellent bonding strength; above 120 grams with standard deviation of less than 20 grams, and the necessity of OLB pads flatness; less than ±12 /xm for one ounce copper lead. The normal storage of the substrate and the lead does not affect the bondability. And the results of accelerated aging test of 125°C, 150°C and 175°C for more than 8,000 hours show that a lifetime of greater than 70 years at 65 °C operating temperature is predicted. The effective activation energy for the pull strength degradation is 0.86-1.05 eV. This is in reasonable agreement with predictions for interdiffusion of Cu-Au. And no significant degradation of the electric resistance was observed on the GSP samples. The feasibility and the high reliability of the GANG Bonding for gold-plated TAB outer leads were confirmed. © 1981, Gordon and Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Bonding; TAPE AUTOMATED BONDING; Integrated circuit testing

Title: The design and commissioning of large particle accelerators
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, E.J.N., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: This paper is concerned with the synchrotrons and storage rings which accelerate protons and electrons for high energy physics, First we trace the development of these machines from early cyclotrons, pausing to describe the main principles of their operation as they emerge, After briefly introducing the reader to the present generation of synchrotrons, we explain in more detail how such large machines are designed, drawing together a consistent whole from a diversity of technical components, We make no attempt to describe the construction phase but move to the running in where component systems must be made to work together and design principles are put to the test. © 1981 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Compressed-Air Storage Caverns At Huntorf
Source title: Subsurface Space: Environmental Protection Low Cost Storage Energy Savings

Abstract: The 290-MW Huntorf peak shave power plant of NWK is the first installation in the world where energy is stored in off-peak periods by means of compressed air in two 150 000 m3 salt caverns at pressures up to 75 bar. Construction was begun in 1975, normal operation commenced at the beginning of 1979. In the meantime there are extensive logs regarding thermodynamics, rock mechanics and salt content of the air available. At normal operation the maximum temperature difference in the cavern is only 16 K, and there was no evidence of large scale collapses or convergence. The salt content of the cavern air is less than 1 ppm. © 1981 Pergamon Press Ltd Published by Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Compressed-air storage; salinity; salt cavern; solution mining; stability; thermodynamic behavior

Abstract: The paper describes the possibilities and consequences of district heating in densely populated urban areas. Special attention is paid to the applications utilizing subsurface space for production, storage and transmission of heat. The theme is enlightened by certain typical realised projects and case studies of potential ones. Comparisons between ground level and subsurface alternatives are performed concerning their technical, economic and environmental effects. © 1981 Pergamon Press Ltd Published by Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.

Title: Energy Storage in Aquifers: A Survey of Recent Theoretical Studies

Abstract: The disparity between energy production and demand has led to increased research into the use of aquifers for the long-term, large-scale storage of thermal energy. Currently, there are several field experiments and feasibility studies under way in which the technical, economic, and environmental aspects of aquifer storage are being researched. The present paper surveys the recent theoretical efforts in aquifer storage research and the impact their results may have on these field projects. Major work is highlighted according to three categories: (1) semianalytic studies, (2) numerical modeling studies, and (3) site-specific studies. © 1981 Pergamon Press Ltd Published by Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.

Abstract: Compressed air energy storage in salt caverns induces low-frequency cyclic loading effects in rock salt.
