Abstract: We report the results of a study of the mechanism of inclusive dimuon production from the reaction p+p+-+X at the CERN intersecting storage rings. The present experiment was done at the center-of-mass energies s=62 and 44 GeV and in the dimuon pair invariant-mass region m=3-25 GeV. The dependence on the Feynman variable x has been measured. The average transverse momentum is found to increase with s and with mass and reaches pT 1.9 GeV, compatible with predictions from quantum-chromodynamic gluon processes. © 1981 The American Physical Society.

Title: Dynamics of solar cosmic ray events: Processes at large heliocentric distances (≫1 AU)
Affiliations: University of Maryland, Department of Physics and Astronomy, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hamilton, D.C., University of Maryland, Department of Physics and Astronomy, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: Observations of solar cosmic ray events far from the sun (≫1 AU) became possible after the launch of Pioneer 10 in 1972. Four spacecraft have now travelled beyond the orbit of Jupiter - Pioneer 10/11 and Voyager 1/2 - and are producing a growing body of distant observations of solar cosmic ray events. Initial studies using Pioneer 10/11 data out to ∼6 AU interpreted flare particle observations in terms of a diffusion model, including the effects of convection and adiabatic energy loss. This model enjoyed general success in explaining the time-intensity profiles in cases where the spacecraft connection longitude at the sun did not change significantly with time. The results implied that the radial diffusion coefficient (Kr) increased slowly with distance over that radial range. More recent results at larger distances imply that Kr may begin to decrease beyond ∼5 AU. It is not yet clear whether the standard diffusion model will be adequate to explain solar events well beyond 5 AU. The fact that large events at very large distances can last up to two solar rotations implies that solar wind stream structure will also play a role in the event dynamics. In general, however, observations at large distances offer perhaps the best hope of separating interplanetary propagation effects from coronal storage and propagation effects which frequently dominate observed event profiles at 1 AU. © 1981.

Title: The mercury-ammonia system at high mercury densities
Affiliations: Avco Everett Research Laboratory, Inc., Everett, MA 02149, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mandl, A., Avco Everett Research Laboratory, Inc., Everett, MA 02149, United States; Hyman, H.A., Avco Everett Research Laboratory, Inc., Everett, MA 02149, United States
Abstract: The properties of optically excited Hg/NH3 and Hg/ND3 mixtures have been studied as a function of mercury pressure in the range 1-40 Torr. At low mercury pressures ≲1 Torr, the well-known UV emission band due to HgNH3* is dominant; this regime has been investigated extensively over the past ten years. However, at higher pressures the UV band disappears and is replaced by a strong green emission band, centered near 500 nm. From a detailed study of the spectral and temporal characteristics of the green band, it is concluded that it arises from the formation of the Hg 2NH3* (or Hg2ND3*) excited molecular complex. The lifetime of this exciplex has been measured and is found to be 3.8 μsec (±25%). Because of interest in the system as a potential energy storage laser medium, optical transmission measurements have been carried out at selected wavelengths. Net absorption has been observed across the green band at high mercury density, as well as in the UV band in the low density regime. © 1981 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Higgs-boson production at large transverse momenta in electron-positron storage rings
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique Corpusculaire, Collège de France, Paris, France; Laboratoire de Physique Théorique des Particules, Université de Picardie, Amiens, France; Central University of Venezuela, Caracas, Venezuela; Theoretical Physics Dept., University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Arteaga-Romero, N., Laboratoire de Physique Corpusculaire, Collège de France, Paris, France, Laboratoire de Physique Théorique des Particules, Université de Picardie, Amiens, France, Central University of Venezuela, Caracas, Venezuela; Nicolaidis, A., Laboratoire de Physique Corpusculaire, Collège de France, Paris, France, Theoretical Physics Dept., University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: We estimate Higgs-boson production at large transverse momenta in electron-positron storage rings via bremsstrahlung off a heavy fermion. Defining by RH2(RH1) the ratio of the cross section for Higgs-boson production with pT2 GeV in two-photon collisions (e+e- annihilation) to the inclusive production cross section of a single muon via one photon, we find that RH2 rises with energy, while RH1 is relatively constant. At present energies (30 GeV beam energy) RH2 is smaller than RH1 but at LEP energies (70 GeV beam energy) both have similar magnitudes (10-5). © 1981 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Hanna D., DiBitonto D., Eickmeyer J., Kernan A., O'Connor J., VanDalen G., Wojslaw R., Böhm A., Giboni K.L., Barone M., Ceradini F., Muller F., Naroska B., Nussbaum M., Rubbia C., Irion J., Navach F., Schinzel D., Seebrunner H., Staude A., Tirler R., Voss R., Block M., Campanini R.
Title: Study of diquark fragmentation at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States; University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States; III. Physikalisches Institut der Technischen Hochschule, D-5100 Aachen, Germany; CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany; Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60201, United States; Bell Labs., Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Hughes Aircraft Co., Los Angeles, CA 90009, United States; Università degli Studi di Roma, I-00185 Roma, Italy; Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg 52, Germany; University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221, United States; Università degli Studi di Bari, I-70126 Bari, Italy; Università degli Studi di Bologna, I-40126 Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Hanna, D., Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States, CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; DiBitonto, D., Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States, CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Eickmeyer, J., University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States, Bell Labs., Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Kernan, A., University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States; O'Connor, J., University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States; VanDalen, G., University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States; Wojslaw, R., University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States, Hughes Aircraft Co., Los Angeles, CA 90009, United States; Böhm, A., III. Physikalisches Institut der Technischen Hochschule, D-5100 Aachen, Germany; Giboni, K.L., III. Physikalisches Institut der Technischen Hochschule, D-5100 Aachen, Germany; Barone, M., CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Ceradini, F., CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland, Università degli Studi di Roma, I-00185 Roma, Italy; Muller, F., CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Naroska, B., CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg 52, Germany; Nussbaum, M., CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221, United States; Rubbia, C., Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States, CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Irion, J., Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany; Navach, F., Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany, Università degli Studi di Bari, I-70126 Bari, Italy; Schinzel, D., CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland, Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany; Seebrunner, H., Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany; Staude, A., Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany; Tirler, R., Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany; Voss, R., Sektion Physik, Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany; Block, M., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60201, United States; Campanini, R., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60201, United States, Università degli Studi di Bologna, I-40126 Bologna, Italy
Abstract: Forward particle production in pp interactions triggered by a 30° pion of momentum exceeding 5 GeV/c has been studied at c.m. energy of 63 GeV. Quantum-chromodynamic model calculations show that in a majority of such interactions the incident proton loses a valence quark. Results indicate that hadronization of diquarks is primarily a recombination process leading to the formation of a high-x baryon. © 1981 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Van Bavel C.H.M., Damagnez J., Sadler E.J.
Title: The fluid-roof solar greenhouse: energy budget analysis by simulation
Affiliations: Department of Soil and Crop Sciences, Texas Agricultural Experiment Station, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Station de Bioclimatologie, Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique, Montfavet, 84140, France
Authors with affiliations: Van Bavel, C.H.M., Department of Soil and Crop Sciences, Texas Agricultural Experiment Station, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Damagnez, J., Station de Bioclimatologie, Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique, Montfavet, 84140, France; Sadler, E.J., Department of Soil and Crop Sciences, Texas Agricultural Experiment Station, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a simulation model of the energy flow and of the corresponding temperatures and humidities in a glasshouse and in a fluid-roof solar greenhouse, compared under several representative daily weather patterns. The model includes an account of soil heat storage and of the action of a simplified crop canopy in regard to radiation absorption, heat dissipation, transpiration and stomatal movement. The fluid-roof greenhouse concept embodies a selectively absorbing aqueous solution that slowly flows through a transparent, hollow roof to a storage tank and back. It has been suggested that such a device could be used to store unneeded day-time solar energy for later use, thus reducing day-time heating of plants and external energy needs for both night-time heating and day-time ventilation of the greenhouse space. Our calculations show this to be true for both winter and summer in South-Central Texas and in South-East France, near the Mediterranean. Reductions in heating requirements of 20-40% and virtual elimination of the need for forced ventilation are predicted. The theoretical calculations justify additional engineering and horticultural research to exploit the fluid-roof solar greenhouse concept in a practical way. © 1981.

Title: Design of a photovoltaic electric power system for an indian village
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, West Bengal 741235, India
Authors with affiliations: Saha, H., Department of Physics, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, West Bengal 741235, India
Abstract: Photovoltaic generation and electrochemical storage of electrical power offer an attractive possibility for the electrification of a village that is normally considered "uneconomic" for electrification by the conventional REP. The modular nature of both solar cells and storage batteries make it possible to use either a centralised or a decentralised system within a village. A critical analysis of the electrical energy requirements of the village including its domestic, agricultural, community and street lighting needs and its technoeconomic aspects is therefore to be made for the most cost effective and maximum beneficial choice between (a) the centralised village energy centre or (b) highly decentralised roof top units within the village. A methodology is first developed in this paper to investigate this problem on the basis of balance of systems (BOS) cost per peak watt and is then applied to a typical village in West Bengal, India. The analysis indicates that the centralised village energy centre approach is about five times more cost-effective than the roof top approach under the assumed conditions. © 1981.

Authors: Calvin M., Willner I., Laane C., Otvos J.W.
Title: Photosensitized electron transfer reactions in organized interfacial systems
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Calvin, M., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Willner, I., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Laane, C., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Otvos, J.W., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: The separation of photoproducts formed in photosensitized electron transfer reactions is essential for efficient energy conversion and storage. The organization of the components involved in the photoinduced process in interfacial systems leads to efficient compartmentalization of the products. Several interfacial systems, e.g. lipid bilayer membranes (vesicles), water-in-oil microemulsions and a solid SiO2 colloidal interface, were designed to accomplish this goal. An electron transfer across a lipid bilayer membrane leading to the separation of the photoproducts at opposite sides of the membrane is facilitated by establishing a transmembrane potential and organizing the cotransport of cations with specific carriers. Colloidal SiO2 particles provide a charged interface that interacts with charged photoproducts. By designing a system that results in oppositely charged photoproducts, a retardation of recombination by the charged interface can be produced. The photosensitized reduction of a neutral acceptor by positively charged sensitizers is described. The reactions are substantially enhanced in the SiO2 colloid compared with in the homogeneous phase. The effect of the SiO2 interface is attributed to a high surface potential that results in the separation of the intermediate photoproducts. The quantum yields of the photosensitized reactions are correlated with the interfacial surface potential and the electrical effects of other charged interfaces such as micelles are compared with those of SiO2. The possible utilization of the energy stored in the stabilized photoproducts in further chemical reactions is discussed. Special attention is given to the photodecomposition of water. © 1981.

Title: Molten nitrate salt technology development.
Source title: IN: PREPRINTS OF CORROSION/81, (TORONTO, CANADA: APR. 6-10, 1981)
Volume: 2 , Houston, U.S.A., Nat. Assoc. Corros. Engrs., 1981, Paper No.148
Authors with affiliations: Carling, R.W.
Abstract: This paper presents an overview of the experimental programmes underway in support of the Thermal Energy Storage Thermal Applications (TESSTA) programme. The experimental programmes are concentrating on molten nitrate salts which have been proposed as heat transfer and energy storage medium. The salt composition of greatest interest is drawsalt, nominally a 50-50 molar mixture of NaNOSUP3 with a melting point of 220SUPC. Several technical uncertainties have been identified that must be resolved before nitrate based solar plants can be commercialised. Research programmes at Sandia National Laboratories, universities, and industrial suppliers have been implemented to resolve these technical uncertainties. The experimental programmes involve corrosion, decomposition, physical properties, and environmental cracking. (from paper)
Index Keywords: experimental programs; Thermophysical properties

Title: Hydrogen as an activating fuel for a tidal power plant.
Source title: IN: HYDROGEN ENERGY PROGRESS PROC. 3RD WORLD HYDROGEN; ENERGY CONF., (TOKYO, JAPAN: JUN.23-26, 1980), T.N. VEZIROGLU; K. FUEK
Authors with affiliations: Gorlov, A.M.
Abstract: The energy of the tide is converted into the energy of compressed air by means of specialized chambers which are put on the ocean bed. Ocean water from the dammed region passes through the chamber where it works as a natural piston compressing air in the upper part of the closure. For the peak periods the compressed air can be heated by combustion of the hydrogen, and expanded through high-speed gas turbine generators. For the off-peak periods, non-heated compressed air is used for the production of the hydrogen fuel. One of the main advantages of the method is the elimination of the expense of the storage and transportation of the hydrogen.

Title: Hydrostatics with the brakes off. Hydrostatic drives
Authors with affiliations: Kerr, J.
Abstract: Hydrostatic drives have narrow speed/torque bands and their application to normal road vehicles is limited. Experiments by London Transport with a hydrostatic transmission in a double-decker bus were disappointing - fuel costs quadrupled. Work by Br. Rail on a hydrostatic transmission for a railbus have shown efficiencies comparable with electric and mechanical transmissions. Volvo Flygmotor in Sweden have developed a hydrostatic transmission which is coupled to a flywheel energy storage system. (R.B.)

Title: Stepless automatic controlling of thermal stratifications in a hot water storage tank.
Source title: IN: PAPERS PRESENTED AT THE INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR.29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 2 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper N2
Authors with affiliations: Patil, M.D.; Sauer, E.
Abstract: This paper introduces a new type of thermal energy storage tank, with the help of which a better utilization of solar energy for space heating and hot water preparation should be achieved. The special feature of this storage tank lies in the controllable moving pipes which can reach to any desired thermal layer during the charging and discharging. With the help of temperature feelers and step motors one can reach any desired thermal layer in a hot water storage tank. The first temperature measurement with the help of 270 thermocouples arranged in this storage tank for the three dimensional temperature distribution has confirmed that even during the charging and discharging there exists a clear stable separation of hot water layers from those of cold water. Further experiments in connection with simulation for different kinds of heat sources and heat sinks should show which advantages can be achieved with this type of storage tank over the conventional one, in which the charging and discharging always take place either at the bottom or at the top. (A)

Title: Physical and energy aspects of underground hydrogen storage.
Source title: IN: HYDROGEN ENERGY PROGRESS, PROC. 3RD WORLD HYDROGEN ENERGY CONF., (TOKYO, JAPAN: JUN. 23-26, 1980), N. VEZIROGLU; K. FUEKI
Authors with affiliations: Carden, P.O.; Paterson, L.
Abstract: This paper discusses the mechanisms for loss of gas associated with storing hydrogen in underground aquifer reservoirs. It is shown that the predominant loss mechanisms involve the solution and diffusion of gas in ground water. The physical extent and rate of these mechanisms are analysed. Energy losses associated with pumping hydrogen into and out of storage are also investigated. It is concluded that losses from all sources, when expressed as a fraction of the energy capacity of the reservoir, will average only a few per cent per storage cycle: approximately 1% for diurnal reservoirs and 5% for seasonal reservoirs.
Index Keywords: flow; porous media

Title: Chemical Heat Pump cycles for energy storage and conversion.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper C2
Authors with affiliations: McBride, J.R.
Abstract: Chemical Heat Pump (CHP) cycles offer considerable potential for the storage and conversion of energy, particularly heat at low to medium temperatures. As such they achieve high efficiencies both in the storage of heat and in the conversion between different temperature levels. In addition, high thermal storage densities can be obtained. These attributes may be particularly important for the recovery, storage and conversion of industrial waste heat streams at temperatures varying from 50 to 500SUPC. This paper describes the principles of Chemical Heat Pump cycles for energy storage and conversion in the context of thermochemical cycles in general, and outlines some of the practical limitations. The efficiencies of heat storage cycles are discussed. Mass and heat transfer problems are detailed with particular reference to forced convection systems. (A)

Title: Blood flow and high-energy phosphates in microregions of left ventricular subendocardium
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Heart and Circulatory Physiology
Affiliations: Dept. Physiol. Biophys., Coll. Med. Dent. New Jersey, Rutgers Med. Sch., Piscataway, N.J. 08854, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kleinert, H.D., Dept. Physiol. Biophys., Coll. Med. Dent. New Jersey, Rutgers Med. Sch., Piscataway, N.J. 08854, United States; Weiss, H.R., Dept. Physiol. Biophys., Coll. Med. Dent. New Jersey, Rutgers Med. Sch., Piscataway, N.J. 08854, United States
Abstract: Blood flow and high-energy phosphate (HEP) content were determined simultaneously in multiple microregions of left ventricular subendocardium in 29 normal anesthetized open-chest rabbits by use of a new micromethod to determine whether a direct linear relationship existed between these parameters. Tissue samples weighed 1-2 mg. ATP and creatine phosphate (CP) content were quantitated in quick-frozen hearts by fluorometry at sites where tissue perfusion was measured by H2 clearance by use of bare-tipped platinum electrodes. A series of validation studies were conducted to ensure that 1) no significant damage to the tissue surrounding the electrode occurred during the period of experimentation and 2) no significant loss of biochemical constituents had occurred due to labile processes during freezing or storage of the tissue. Blood flow, ATP, and CP values averaged 79.1 ± 24.1 (SD) ml/min-1/100 g-1, 4.9 ± 1.3 μmol/g tissue, and 8.0 ± 3.0 μmol/g tissue, respectively, and are similar to those reported in studies using larger tissue samples. Correlation between the heterogeneous distribution of tissue perfusion and HEP revealed no direct linear relationship between these parameters in the normal unstressed rabbit subendocardium.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; creatine phosphate; adenosine triphosphate; creatine phosphate; diagnostic agent; hydrogen; animal experiment; cytology; fluorometry; heart; heart left ventricle; heart muscle blood flow; peripheral vascular system; subendocardium; animal; article; coronary artery blood flow; endocardium; freezing; heart ventricle; male; metabolism; rabbit; Adenosine Triphosphate; Animal; Coronary Circulation; Endocardium; Freezing; Heart Ventricle; Hydrogen; Male; Phosphocreatine; Rabbits; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Authors: Bernas A., Grand D., Hautecloque S., Chambaudet A.
Title: Ionization potentials of polyacene molecules in micellar systems or in liquid homogeneous solutions
Affiliations: ERA 718, Université Paris-Sud, Bât. 350, 91405 Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Bernas, A., ERA 718, Université Paris-Sud, Bât. 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Grand, D., ERA 718, Université Paris-Sud, Bât. 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Hautecloque, S., ERA 718, Université Paris-Sud, Bât. 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Chambaudet, A., ERA 718, Université Paris-Sud, Bât. 350, 91405 Orsay, France
Abstract: It has been emphasized previously that photoionizable hydrophobic solutes confined in anionic aqueous micelles constitute promising systems for photosensitized water splitting and solar energy conversion and storage. In the present study, the one-photon ionization of perylene (Pe) and tetracene (Tet) in anionic lauryl sulfate (NaLS) or neutral Triton X 100 (TX 100) micelles has been compared with the photoionization process in homogeneous solutions (tetramethylsilane (Me4Si) or methanol). The photoionization yield as a function of the exciting photon frequency has been measured by photocurrent recording (in Me4Si) or by scavenging the hydrated electrons by various neutral or charged scavengers (N2O, NO3-, H+). The shape of the photoionization efficiency curves in the threshold energy region is found to differ markedly for Pe or Tet in NaLS micelles on one hand and neutral micelles or homogeneous solutions on the other. It is suggested that such a difference illustrates the reduced recombination of geminate ion pairs in the former case. The lowering of the ionization threshold energy of Pe and Tet in micelles (ΔIMi) relative to their gas-phase ionization potential amounts to 2.3-2.35 eV for both solutes. ΔIMi is interpreted in terms of the parameters which have been currently considered to govern the optical ionization of impurity molecules in condensed media. In such a framework the electric field gradient at the micelle-water interface does not seem to contribute significantly to the observed ΔIMi value. © 1981 American Chemical Society.

Title: Confinement of ions injected into a radiofrequency quadrupole ion trap: Pulsed ion beams of different energies
Source title: International Journal of Mass Spectrometry and Ion Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: O, C.-S., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Schuessler, H.A., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: The ion confinement properties of a radiofrequency (r.f.) quadrupole ion trap with phase-synchronized switching-on of the driving r.f. field are evaluated for ion pulses injected from an external source. Singly charged ions of mass 100 u are considered. Calculations are performed for well-collimated pulsed ion beams, with a finite circular cross-section 1 mm in diameter, injected into an r.f. quadrupole trap with characteristic dimension ro = 5.4 mm. Ion injections along the gap and through an aperture in one of the electrodes, including. typical off-axial- and off-equatorial-plane incidence directions, are considered. The ion confinement property of the r.f. quadrupole trap for externally injected ions is energy-dependent. The optimum time delays before turning on the quadrupole field have different values for injected ions of different energies. For an injected ion beans with a large energy-spread the overall ion-trapping efficiency therefore cannot reach unity. The phase-dependence of the overall ion-trapping efficiency is shown for an ion beam of uniform energy distribution over the range 0-20 eV. By suitably choosing the experimental conditions, energy-selective storage of the injected ions should be possible. © 1981.

Title: Confinement of ions injected into a radiofrequency quadrupole ion trap: Energy-selective storage of pulse injected ions
Source title: International Journal of Mass Spectrometry and Ion Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: O, C.-S., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Schuessler, H.A., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: Energy-selective storage of a pulsed ion beam injected into a radiofrequency (r.f.) quadrupole ion trap of characteristic dimension ro = 0.54 cm is numerically evaluated. The calculation is performed for a well-collimated pulsed beam of singly charged ions of mass 100 u, injected along the gap between the electrodes or through an aperture at the mid-point of the ring electrode or at the apex of one of the endcap electrodes. Since the ion confinement property of the r.f. quadrupole trap for externally injected ions is energy dependent, phase-synchronized switching-on of the driving r.f. field can be employed to trap only a narrow energy portion of the ion beam, which is incident with a large spread. It is shown that the magnitude and the width of the accepted ion energy can be selected and that energy-selective storage of ions can be achieved in two different ways. The first way is to choose suitable trap operation parameters to achieve a very narrow time delay interval for ion confinement at theion energy of interest. The second way is to allow a field-free drift distance before ion injection and to take advantage of the energy spread of the ion packed. In both ways an energy window of less than 1 eV at an ion energy of 10 eV cam be obtained. When the ion trap is operated at the mass-selective tip of the stable region instead of at the center, an even higher energy-selectivity is possible. However, this goes at the expense of a lower ion confinement efficiency. © 1981.

Authors: Glade M.J., Krook L., Schryver H.F., Hintz H.F.
Title: Growth inhibition induced by chronic dexamethasone treatment of foals
Affiliations: Department of Animal Science, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Glade, M.J., Department of Animal Science, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, United States; Krook, L., Department of Animal Science, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, United States; Schryver, H.F., Department of Animal Science, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, United States; Hintz, H.F., Department of Animal Science, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, United States
Abstract: Pony and horse foals were given daily intramuscular injections of dexamethasone, beginning at 6 months of age. Ponies were injected with 0 or 0.5 mg/100 kg bodyweight for 3, 8, or 11 months, or with 5.0 mg/100 kg for 11 months. Horses were treated with 0 or 5.0 mg/100 kg for 20 weeks. Rates of gain were inhibited (P< .01 ) in both ponies and horses after 8 weeks of treatment with either dose. Weight loss occurred in ponies after 40 weeks of treatment and in horse foals after 16 weeks, although feed intakes and dietary energy and nitrogen digestibilities were not effected by treatment (P>. 10). Urinary nitrogen loss increased within 3 months (P <.01), allowing little increase in total body protein during the period of normally rapid growth. Samples of left femur growth cartilage taken from ponies killed after 3 and 8 months were analyzed. Deoxyribonucleic acid content (ug/ mg dry cartilage) was doubled by treatment (P <.01), lactate dehydrogenase activities per cell and hexosamine and hexuronic acid contents were decreased 80–90% (P <.01), and hydroxyproline content decreased about 50% (P<.01), compared to tissues from untreated ponies. Growth inhibition appeared to result from the production of abnormal growth cartilage, deficient in collagen and glycosaminoglycans. A metabolic shift from energy production to intra-chondrocyte energy storage, as reflected by decreased lactate dehydrogenase activities, appeared responsible for the decreased production of cartilage components. © 1981, William E. Jones, DVM. All rights reserved.

Title: Basic theory of the isochronous storage ring laser
Affiliations: High Energy Physics Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deacon, D.A.G., High Energy Physics Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: The use of an isochronous storage ring as the electron source for a higher power, high efficiency free electron laser is proposed. Electrons can be trapped in the optical potential wells in such a system, where they couple energy directly from the radio frequency accelerating cavity into the optical frequency laser beam with negligible losses. The conditions for the existence of such traps are derived, as well as the dependence of their size and shape on the laser parameters and the deviations from isochronism in the arc of the storage ring. The results of a numerical stimulation extend the analytic results to the general case of large phase advance. The optimization of the laser parameters is discussed with the aid of a numerical example of the performance assuming a design which can be realized in practice. © 1981.

Authors: Kaetsu I., Kumakura M., Fujimura T., Yoshii F., Kojima T., Tamada M.
Title: Utilization of radiation technique on the saccharification and fermentation of biomass
Affiliations: Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Watanuki-machi, Takasaki, Gunma, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kaetsu, I., Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Watanuki-machi, Takasaki, Gunma, Japan; Kumakura, M., Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Watanuki-machi, Takasaki, Gunma, Japan; Fujimura, T., Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Watanuki-machi, Takasaki, Gunma, Japan; Yoshii, F., Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Watanuki-machi, Takasaki, Gunma, Japan; Kojima, T., Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Watanuki-machi, Takasaki, Gunma, Japan; Tamada, M., Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment, Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Watanuki-machi, Takasaki, Gunma, Japan
Abstract: The application of irradiation technique to the process of saccharification and subsequent fermentation of cellulosic wastes such as chaff and rice straw to obtain ethanol, was investigated. It was found that when waste raw materials were irradiated by {A figure is presented}-ray or electron beam, they became accessible to the subsequent enzymatic saccharification reaction. Irradiation of 107-108 Rad was enough for this effect. Some kind of additives reduced necessary dosage for this pretreatment. Cellulase, Trichoderma reesei which produce cellulase, and yeast were immobilized as biocatalysts for biomass conversion by radiation-induced polymerization of glass-forming monomer at low temperature. The immobilized cellulase showed almost same activity of glucose production as the native cellulase. Continuous saccharification reaction was carried out by using the immobilized cellulase. The immobilized Trichoderma reesei and the immobilized yeast showed almost same activity as the intact biocatalysts. It was concluded that the continuous saccharification and subsequent fermentation could be carried out effectively by using the immobilized biocatalysts. Spinach chloroplasts were immobilized by the same method as the first step for the conversion of water into hydrogen gas using solar energy. The immobilized chloroplasts kept the O2 evolution activity in storage more than 30 days at 4°C. Thermostatility of chloroplasts was also improved greatly by the immobilization. © 1981.

Title: Interface in composite materials
Affiliations: Centre de Recherches sur la Physico-Chimie des Surfaces Solides, C.N.R.S., 24, avenue du Président Kennedy, 68200 MULHOUSE, France
Authors with affiliations: Jean-Baptiste, D., Centre de Recherches sur la Physico-Chimie des Surfaces Solides, C.N.R.S., 24, avenue du Président Kennedy, 68200 MULHOUSE, France
Abstract: It is generally accepted that the mechanical properties of composite materials are largely dependent on the interactions at the matrix/filler interface. To cite an exemple, recent work on a model bitumen-silica composite has given insight into the role played by the interface. In this case, the respective influences of interfacial area and degree of matrix/filler interaction on the storage modulus of the composite have been quantitatively established. Although many factors intervene, clearly the strength of the interface must depend to a large extent on both the number and the nature of the bonds between the two phases. In cases in which only physical bonds (e.g. Van der Waals) are formed, the interfacial strength may be predicted from the surface characteristics of the two solids in contact. A study of such a system, aluminium/elastomer, has shown the significant contribution of the free surface energies of the two components to mechanical resistance, locus of failure and environment effects. In many real composite materials, interfacial bonds of a chemical nature must be taken into account. The influence of these chemical bonds will be examined by considering results obtained from polymer/polymer and polymer/glass interfaces. Despite the general applicability of the conclusions of these interfacial studies, it mustnevertheless not be forgotten that, in certain cases, the properties of the interphase in the proximity of the interface, are of fundamental importance. It is for this reason that it is of the utmost importance to define tests which enable the direct measurement of the stress-transfer capacity of both interfaces and interphases in composite materials. © 1981, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.

Title: Short-term regulation of food intake by the brown honeyeater, Lichmera indistincta
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -- Part A: Physiology
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Bentley, WA 6102, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Collins, B., Department of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Bentley, WA 6102, Australia; Cary, G., Department of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Bentley, WA 6102, Australia
Abstract: 1. 1. Regardless of nectar concentration, there are strong positive correlations between the durations of feeding bouts by Lichmera indistincta and subsequent inter-bout intervals, and energy intake during feeding bouts and energy expenditure during subsequent inter-bout intervals. 2. 2. Energy utilization by L. indistincta conforms to an accumulation-depletion model, with a portion of the energy acquired during each feeding bout contributing to the gradual diurnal storage of energy that is subsequently used for maintenance during non-foraging periods. 3. 3. L. indistincta compensates for a decrease in nectar concentration by increasing the frequency of feeding bouts and decreasing the duration of inter-bout intervals. 4. 4. Changes in the duration of inter-bout intervals caused by alterations to the calorific value of nectar drunk can be explained in terms of the rate at which the stomach empties. © 1981.

Title: Engineering design of a 6000m3/day seawater hybrid RO-ED helio-desalting plant
Affiliations: Science Applications, Inc. -, Ames, IA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Husseiny, A.A., Science Applications, Inc. -, Ames, IA, United States; Hamester, H.L., Science Applications, Inc. -, Ames, IA, United States
Abstract: Employment of solar energy as a power source for desalination processes has been thought of as an evaluation of the solar stills which have been in operation for a long period of time. With the recent efforts to commercialize active collectors of solar radiation, interest in developing solar-powered desalting systems has been revived. Among the new viable concepts is the design of a Hybrid RO-ED commercial plant to desalt sea water. The design is based on the development of a stand-alone system that provides 6,000 m3/day at a minimum cost of product which can eventually compete with cost of water from conventional desalting plants. A detailed design description, design parameters and cost estimates are provided in this paper. The plant is based on the combined use of reverse osmosis and electrodialysis in a flexible multi-staged hybrid technique. AC power is to be generated for the reverse osmosis first stage using a solar thermal power system based on line focusing thermal collectors and ranking cycle power conversion. DC power for the electrodialysis second stage will be produced directly from a solar photovoltaic field. Although both the ED and RO desalting concepts are individually inherently more adaptable to solar energy than vapor phase processed because of their energy efficiency, there is considerable merit in the hybrid concept as applied in this design over the choice of either concept for the total desalting process. First, the RO first stage and ED second stage can be completely decoupled in their operation. This provides for a significant operating flexibility since with power supplied by a flat plate photovoltaic array, the ED system can be run under conditions of diffuse insolation which would render the thermal concentrating collectors very ineffective. Each stage in conjunction its power source can be optimized with respect to its own operating day. In addition, because the output rate of the ED system can be adjusted to respond to varying available power levels, the ED system can be run at partial output at portions of the day when solar thermal power is unavailable with no loss in process efficiency. A total reverse osmosis system offers no such operating flexibility requiring either larger arrays or large amounts of storage to be available for converting an irregular daily insolation energy pulse to a square wave power output. Second, the interface between the RO and ED is adjustable providing a range of first stage product salinities and blending ratios of RO product and pretreated feedwater. This allows an optimum system which minimizes product cost by minimizing RO size and ED energy use, thus minimizing overall thermal and photovoltaic array requirements. Unlike the RO system, which suffers severe membrane degradation at high temperatures, the ED membranes are tolerant to feedwater temperatures as high as 160°F. The energy usage of the ED process decreases with increasing feed stream temperature. The second stage feedwater can be used for condenser cooling providing the synergistic effect of reducing parasitic pumping and the ED power requirement. Finally, the ED and RO systems are of rugged design with few moving parts other than pumps. This feature provides maximum reliability in often hostile operating environments, minimizing maintenance requirements over vapor phase systems. The plant is sized to operate 2A hours per day with minimum battery storage to reduce the cost. The selected system has several innovative features, although it is designed using off-the-shelf components and equipments. Variation in the salinity of the sea waters could be handled by controlling the blending ratio of the feed to the ED. Such control is much simpler than recycling or change in pressure. The function of the ED stack as an active part of the PV-DC electrical circuit would be to provide a constant overall rate of production independent of the hourly variation in insolation. Also, the ED can be designed to save power demand from the PV system by heating the feed and by changing the load. Recirculation of the product in the ED system to assist the RO system in case of emergencies is also possible. Furthermore, the use of ORC allows the use of low temperature thermal system. © 1981.

Authors: Gruber R., Troyon F., Rousset S., Kerner W., Bernard L.C.
Title: Transformation of ERATO into a δW code
Affiliations: Centre de Recherches en Physique des Plasmas, Association Euratom - Confédération Suisse, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, CH-1007 Lausanne, Switzerland; Max-Planck Institut für Plasmaphysik, Association Euratom-IPP, D-8046 Garching bei München, Germany; General Atomic Company, San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gruber, R., Centre de Recherches en Physique des Plasmas, Association Euratom - Confédération Suisse, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, CH-1007 Lausanne, Switzerland; Troyon, F., Centre de Recherches en Physique des Plasmas, Association Euratom - Confédération Suisse, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, CH-1007 Lausanne, Switzerland; Rousset, S., Centre de Recherches en Physique des Plasmas, Association Euratom - Confédération Suisse, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, CH-1007 Lausanne, Switzerland; Kerner, W., Max-Planck Institut für Plasmaphysik, Association Euratom-IPP, D-8046 Garching bei München, Germany; Bernard, L.C., General Atomic Company, San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: The spectral code ERATO has been transformed into a stability code based on the energy principle δW. It only gives the stability index, i.e. the "yes or no" answer to the stability of an axisymmetric toroidal plasma equilibrium. Compared to the full ERATO code, the computing time is reduced by a factor of 4. Storage requirements and input/output operations reduced by a factor of 5. © 1981.

Title: A survey of commercial meat block freezing in the United Kingdom and Fire
Affiliations: Agricultural Research Council, Meat Research Institute, Langford, Bristol, BS18 7DY, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Creed, P.G., Agricultural Research Council, Meat Research Institute, Langford, Bristol, BS18 7DY, United Kingdom; James, S.J., Agricultural Research Council, Meat Research Institute, Langford, Bristol, BS18 7DY, United Kingdom
Abstract: The results of a survey of meat block freezing in the UK and Eire have been compared with experimental and calculated data. This comparison showed that only 58% of the throughput is being frozen within ±20% of the actual time required. There was little standardization of block size, type of wrapping and carton, freezing and storage conditions. The weight of the majority of blocks was between 25 and 30 kg and 80% of the meat was frozen in cartons between 14.6 and 15.9 cm thick. The survey concludes that refrigeration and meat companies must aim for more realistic freezing times and conditions in order to avoid either incomplete freezing or wasting energy by freezing for longer than necessary. © 1981.

Title: Light sources and recording methods
Authors with affiliations: Hugenschmidt, M.; Vollrath, K.
Abstract: High speed photographic recording is one of the most important techniques for the study of transient phenomena in the field of technical engineering and scientific research. The development of light sources adapted to the special uses focuses on spectral distribution, luminous flux, and pulse duration. The part of the spectrum between about 200 and 300 nm, and the far infrared up to several hundred microns, which is used for photographic recording, occupies only a small portion of the whole electromagnetic spectrum. Light efficiencies of flash tubes can be increased by choosing gases of high atomic mass and total efficiencies, as defined by the ratio of light energy integrated over all wavelengths to electrical energy of the storage capacitor, of about 40% and more have been achieved. The optical properties are determined by temperatures and densities in the channel during the discharge. It is found that the time dependence of emission can be measured by multipliers, fast cameras, and spectrometer. © 1981, Academic Press, Inc.

Title: Beam modelling techniques for computerized therapy planning
Affiliations: Dept. Med. Phys., West. Gen. Hosp., Edinburgh EH 4 2XU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Redpath, A.T., Dept. Med. Phys., West. Gen. Hosp., Edinburgh EH 4 2XU, United Kingdom; Wright, D.H., Dept. Med. Phys., West. Gen. Hosp., Edinburgh EH 4 2XU, United Kingdom
Abstract: In radiotherapy planning beam modelling is considered to be the means of representing the necessary information for the calculation of depth dose data. The merits of mass storage, mathematical approximation and the separate calculation of the individual primary and scatter dose components is reviewed. With regard to the speed and accuracy of the depth dose calculation the conclusion is reached that the linear interpolation of data from a data base is the most satisfactory representation. It is also proposed that the data base itself could be sufficiently accurately generated from a limited amount of measured data using an algorithm based on the calculation of the separate primary and scatter dose components.
Index Keywords: computer; computer analysis; methodology; radiation beam; radiotherapy; theoretical study; therapy; human; megavoltage radiotherapy; neoplasm; patient care; radiation dose; review; Computers; Human; Neoplasms; Patient Care Planning; Radiotherapy Dosage; Radiotherapy, High-Energy

Title: Binding kinetics and physical properties of androgen receptor in androgen-dependent shionogi mammary carcinoma 115
Affiliations: Department of Pharmacology, Kawasaki Medical School, Kurashiki, Okayama 701-01, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nohno, T., Department of Pharmacology, Kawasaki Medical School, Kurashiki, Okayama 701-01, Japan
Abstract: The characteristics of the androgen receptor in the cytoplasmic fraction of Shionogi carcinoma 115 were studied in vitro by means of charcoal adsorption assay, sucrose density gradient centrifugation, and polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The equilibrium dissociation constant for [3H]dihydrotestosterone (Kd=(2-5)×10-11 M) was estimated from independently determined rates of association and dissociation, and was lower by one order of magnitude than the value obtained by saturation analysis (Kd=(2-8)×10-10 M). Evaluation of the effect of temperature on receptor binding of androgen allowed the estimation of several thermodynamic parameters, including activation energies of association (4 kcal/mol) and dissociation (14 kcal/mol), the apparent free energy (-13 kcal/mol), enthalpy (-9 kcal/mol), and entropy (+14 cal/mol per K). The receptor was greatly stabilized when bound with androgen. The results indicate how the lability of the unbound receptor and slow rate of dihydrotestosterone-receptor interaction can influence the estimation of dissociation constants by usual saturation analysis. The sedimentation coefficient of androgen receptor in freshly prepared cytosol was 6S, and became 7S after storage for 2 months at -80°C. The 7S conversion of the receptor was reversed by treatment with heparin. In all cases, a single 7S peak was obtained in the presence of 0.5 M KCI. On electrophoresis in heparin-containing polyacrylamide gel, protein-bound radioactive androgen migrated as a single peak (Rf=0.5 in 5% gel). Differences in reported values for the sedimentation coefficient of androgen receptor in cytosol of Shionogi carcinoma 115 appear to be derived largely from aggregation of the receptor protein during the assay procedure. © 1981, by the Japanese Biochemical Society.
Index Keywords: androgen receptor; androstanolone; binding affinity; breast; breast carcinoma; in vitro study; Animal; Binding Sites; Centrifugation; Cytosol; Electrophoresis, Polyacrylamide Gel; Female; Kinetics; Mammary Neoplasms, Experimental; Mice; Receptors, Androgen; Receptors, Steroid; Stanolone; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Temperature; Thermodynamics

Authors: Horne F.W., Anderton R.L., Grant F.A.
Title: Water reuse: Projecting markets and costs
Affiliations: Orange and Los Angeles Counties Water Reuse Study, Los Angeles, CA 90054, United States
Authors with affiliations: Horne, F.W., Orange and Los Angeles Counties Water Reuse Study, Los Angeles, CA 90054, United States; Anderton, R.L., Orange and Los Angeles Counties Water Reuse Study, Los Angeles, CA 90054, United States; Grant, F.A., Orange and Los Angeles Counties Water Reuse Study, Los Angeles, CA 90054, United States
Abstract: The water reuse market survey for the 5180-km2 study area yielded more than 1100 prospective customers who met quantity-of-use and type-of-use screening criteria. The identified new applications totaled 950 000 m3/d (280 000 acre-ft/year), in addition to the 200 000 m3/d (60 000 acre-ft/year) now in operation. The total market was visualized in order of development as existing A-level projects (200 000 m3/d); B-level greenbelt and lower-order industrial projects (374 000 m3/d); C-level industrial and power-plant cooling projects (200 000 m3/d); and D-level groundwater recharge projects (372 000 m3/d). The short-term to mid-term B and C-level projects varied in cost between 16c/m3 and 73c/m3 ($200-$900 per acre-ft) delivered, depending on pump requirements and the degree of user scattering. According to California Department of Health Services' project criteria, the standard treatment process for B-level projects is activated sludge secondary treatment, followed by dual media filtration and chlorination to ensure a virologically safe effluent. C users will require lime softening prior to filtration in order to provide adequate cycles of concentration in cooling towers. Much of the variation in delivery system cost among projects was attributable to differences in pumping energy and degree of user clustering. Generalized curves for estimating delivery system capital and O&M costs for pipelines, pump stations, storage reservoirs, user hookup, and replumbing were displayed as a function of total dynamic pumping head and degree of user clustering. (Costs for advanced treatment may be added separately on the basis of judgment). Despite the wide variation in cost from project to project, the percentage contribution of individual components to delivery system capital cost was fairly stable, with pipelines typically accounting for 70-75%; pump stations, 10-15%; storage, 5-10%; and onsite replumbing and user connections, 5-10%.
Index Keywords: cost; economic aspect; prevention; therapy; waste water recycling

Title: Phosphoryl Group Transfer by a Fraction of the Soluble Proteins of Catecholamine Storage Vesicles
Affiliations: Max‐Planck‐Institut für medizinische Forschung, Abteilung Physiologie Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Taugner, G., Max‐Planck‐Institut für medizinische Forschung, Abteilung Physiologie Heidelberg, Germany; Wunderlich, I., Max‐Planck‐Institut für medizinische Forschung, Abteilung Physiologie Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: Abstract: The terminal phosphate group of ATP was transferred to ADP by an enzyme present in the soluble core proteins of adrenal medulla catecholamine storage vesicles. It was purified 10–30‐fold by DEAE Sephadex chromatography (Fraction I). The enzyme required divalent metal ions for activation; Mn2+ was almost as effective as Mg2+, but Ca2+ was only a weak activator. Activation by Mg2+ took place over a very narrow concentration range (0.5–3 mm). The specificity of the enzyme activity to nucleoside triphosphates was broad, to the nucleoside diphosphates narrow, favouring adenosine diphosphate. In dependence on the pH the activity increased from pH 4 to pH 7 and remained constantly high between pH 7 and 9. The Arrhenius plot was linear between 5 and 70°C, with an activation energy of 11.1 kcal/mol. The phosphoryl group transfer reaction depended on the function of thiol groups; p‐hydroxymercuribenzoate inhibited 50% of the enzyme activity; dithioerythritol reactivated it completely. Gel electrophoresis revealed that in Fraction I, a protein of molecular weight about 45,000, was enriched compared with the total soluble proteins. The enzyme‐enriched Fraction I differed significantly in its relative amino acid composition from that of the total soluble proteins; in general, the acidic amino acids were reduced and the more basic acids enhanced. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Chromogranines; Divalent cation requirement; Nucleotide metabolism; Phosphoryl group transfer; Thiol group involvement
Index Keywords: adenosine diphosphate; adenosine triphosphate; calcium; magnesium; manganese; adrenal medulla; animal experiment; autonomic nervous system; catecholamine granule; cattle; endocrine system; Adenosine Diphosphate; Adenosine Triphosphate; Adenylate Kinase; Adrenal Medulla; Amino Acids; Animal; Calcium; Cattle; Dithiothreitol; Ethylmaleimide; Hydroxymercuribenzoates; Lysosomes; Magnesium; Manganese; Substrate Specificity

Authors: Frasca P., Harper R., Katz J.L.
Title: Strain and frequency dependence of shear storage modulus for human single osteons and cortical bone microsamples-Size and hydration effects
Affiliations: Orthopaedic Research Lab, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia, PA 19107, United States; Laboratory for Crystallographic Biophysics, Department of Physics, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY 12181, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frasca, P., Orthopaedic Research Lab, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia, PA 19107, United States; Harper, R., Laboratory for Crystallographic Biophysics, Department of Physics, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY 12181, United States; Katz, J.L., Laboratory for Crystallographic Biophysics, Department of Physics, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY 12181, United States
Abstract: Using a specially designed and laboratory built microtorsional device, the shear storage modulus of single osteons and microsamples containing up to a dozen osteons was investigated for both strain and frequency dependence. The data indicate that an increase in number of osteons in the microsample reduces the storage modulus, and results in smaller strains at which deviation from linearity and plasticity effects are first noticed. Size effects were also noticed, which suggest that an increase in number of osteons, increases the effectiveness of water (hydration of dry samples) in reducing the storage modulus and in increasing the internal energy loss in the sample. Some of the effects were noticed to approach saturation in samples with more than a half dozen osteons, while others appeared to persist (at least up to a dozen osteons). Also noticed, were reductions in shear storage modulus of 10-35% over an approximate frequency reduction of 103-1 Hz for microsamples containing one or more osteons. © 1981.

Authors: Yoshino H., Kobayashi M., Samejima M.
Title: Polymorphic Transition Rate of Semisynthetic Fatty Suppository Bases
Affiliations: Products Formulation Research Laboratory, Tanabe Seiyaku Co., Ltd., 16-89, Kashima 3-chome, Yodogawa-ku, Osaka, 532, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshino, H., Products Formulation Research Laboratory, Tanabe Seiyaku Co., Ltd., 16-89, Kashima 3-chome, Yodogawa-ku, Osaka, 532, Japan; Kobayashi, M., Products Formulation Research Laboratory, Tanabe Seiyaku Co., Ltd., 16-89, Kashima 3-chome, Yodogawa-ku, Osaka, 532, Japan; Samejima, M., Products Formulation Research Laboratory, Tanabe Seiyaku Co., Ltd., 16-89, Kashima 3-chome, Yodogawa-ku, Osaka, 532, Japan
Abstract: The degree of polymorphic transition of semisynthetic fatty suppository bases was estimated by means of X-ray diffraction measurements. IR values, defined as the relative intensities of two characteristic diffraction peaks of unstable A-form and stable B-form were useful for this purpose. Storage experiments using Witepsol H-15 suppositories containing 1% Brilliant Blue were performed. During storage, the changes of melting point, softening time and drug release rate were measured and compared with IR. Each of these properties showed a correlation with IR value irrespective of storage temperature or period. With lapse of time, the IR values commonly fell to a minimum in the earlier period, subsequently increased to a maximum and then remained constant. This change depended markedly on the storage temperature, so we attempted to predict the IR change using two rate parameters. One was the half-transition time t1/2 and the other was the shift factor AT calculated by the reduced variable method. On plotting these rate parameters against 1/T, good linear relations were obtained, and the activation energies were 98 kcal and 108 kcal for t1/2 and AT respectively. Using these values, prediction of the physical stability of the suppository seems to be possible. It was also shown that this IR method is applicable to other commercial fatty vehicles. © 1981, The Pharmaceutical Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Somlyo A.V., Gonzalez-Serratos H., Shuman H., McClellan G.
Title: Calcium release and ionic changes in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of tetanized muscle: An electron-probe study
Affiliations: Pennsylvania Muscle Inst., Univ. Pennsylvania Sch. Med., Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Somlyo, A.V., Pennsylvania Muscle Inst., Univ. Pennsylvania Sch. Med., Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States; Gonzalez-Serratos, H., Pennsylvania Muscle Inst., Univ. Pennsylvania Sch. Med., Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States; Shuman, H., Pennsylvania Muscle Inst., Univ. Pennsylvania Sch. Med., Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States; McClellan, G.
Abstract: Approximately 60-70% of the total fiber calcium was localized in the terminal cisternae (TC) in resting frog muscle as determined by electron-probe analysis of ultrathin cryosections. During a 1.2 s tetanus, 59% (69 mmol/kg dry TC) of the calcium content of the TC was released, enough to raise total cytoplasmic calcium concentration by ~1 mM. This is equivalent to the concentration of binding sites on the calcium-binding proteins (troponin and parvalbumin) in frog muscle. Calcium release was associated with a significant uptake of magnesium and potassium into the TC, but the amount of calcium released exceeded the total measured cation accumulation by 62 mEq/kg dry weight. It is suggested that most of the charge deficit is apparent, and charge compensation is achieved by movement of protons into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) and/or by the movement of organic co- or counterions not measured by energy dispersive electron-probe analysis. There was no significant change in the sodium or chlorine content of the TC during tetanus. The unchanged distribution of a permeant anion, chloride, argues against the existence of a large and sustained transSR potential during tetanus, if the chloride permeability of the in situ SR is as high as suggested by measurements on fractionated SR. The calcium content of the longitudinal SR (LSR) during tetanus did not show the LSR to be a major site of calcium storage and delayed return to the TC. The potassium concentration in the LSR was not significantly different from the adjacent cytoplasmic concentration. Analysis of small areas of 1-band and large areas, including several sarcomeres, suggested that chloride is anisotropically distributed, with some of it probably bound to myosin. In contrast, the distribution of potassium in the fiber cytoplasm followed the water distribution. The mitochondrial concentration of calcium was low and did not change significantly during a tetanus. The TC of both tetanized and resting freeze-substituted muscles contained electron-lucent circular areas. The appearance of the TC showed no evidence of major volume changes during tetanus, in agreement with the estimates of unchanged (~72%) water content of the TC obtained with electron-probe analysis.
Index Keywords: calcium; animal experiment; electron microscopy; muscle; muscle spasm; sarcoplasmic reticulum; Animalia; Anura

Title: Formation of bone electrets and their charge decay characteristics
Affiliations: School of Environmental Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, 110067, India
Authors with affiliations: Andrabi, W.H., School of Environmental Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, 110067, India; Behari, J., School of Environmental Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, 110067, India
Abstract: Thermo electret, electro electret and magneto electret phenomena have been examined for bone, collagen and apatite. It is found that they acquired a saturation charge of about 10-6C/cm2-10-8C/cm2 when subjected to moderate temperature, electric and high magnetic field treatments. A significant fraction of charge developed is found to be retained in these materials for a period of several months. A possible explanation for the mechanism at work is suggested. A relationship between energy storage and development of bone is perceived. © 1981.

Title: Calorimetric study of the endogenous metabolism of yeast
Source title: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology
Affiliations: The Institute of Applied Microbiology, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nunomura, K., The Institute of Applied Microbiology, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113, Japan; Fujita, T., The Institute of Applied Microbiology, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113, Japan
Abstract: A considerable amount of heat was produced when a suspension of yeast was added to a suspending medium in the absence of an exogenous energy source. The amount of heat produced was proportional to the cell concentration and accompanied by oxygen consumption, suggesting that the exothermic reaction may be due to the endogenous metabolism of cells. The patterns of heat production varied with the physiological state of cells, which were influenced by several factors including culture conditions, methods of storage, starvation, temperature and the suspending medium used for calorimetric measurements. © 1981, Applied Microbiology, Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Research Foundation. All rights reserved.

Title: Design and operation experience with solar powered multistage desalination plants
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Lausanne Scientific advisor to Atlantis Energy Ltd., P.O.Box, 3000 Bern 6, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Kriesi, R., Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Lausanne Scientific advisor to Atlantis Energy Ltd., P.O.Box, 3000 Bern 6, Switzerland
Abstract: Desalination is a favourable application for solar energy and has a good potential for economic viability, since water demand is a consequence of abundant solar irradiation (no long term storage needed) and only low temperatures are necessary for the required thermal energy (simplicity of solar collector system). An R + D partnership for the development and implementation of solar desalination technology has been set up between the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (fundamental development and laboratory testing), Atlantis Energy Ltd. (hardware design, construction and delivery) and the Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research (field testing). A 3-phase-program is under way: 1. Phase 1 (completed): Initial construction of a conventional MSF plant, laboratory and field tests. Design criteria for solar equipment resulted such as capability of operation under heavily fluctuating energy input conditions, minimisation of mechanical energy consumption, simplicity of equipment, etc. 2. Phase 2 (completed): Design of a new "real solar" MSF-unit, meeting the above requirements, laboratory testing, field testing in Kuwait. 3. Phase 3 (under way): Upscaling of the pilot plant to commercial sizes of 100 to 1000 m3/day, optimization of the process, realisation of a demonstration plant, coupled to a salt solar pond, specially developed for this purpose. It can be concluded, that solar desalination has been demonstrated to be a reliable method of obtaining drinking water when using a specially developed salt solar pond system as heat source, water at lower prices is obtained compared with that from an oil-fired evaporator. © 1981.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Kuwait; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SALT POND COLLECTORS; SOLAR DESALINATION PLANTS; DESALINATION

Title: Test results from a solar boiler for saline water distillation
Affiliations: University of California, Sea Water Conversion Laboratory, Richmond, CA 94804, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jundi, Z.M., University of California, Sea Water Conversion Laboratory, Richmond, CA 94804, United States; Tleimat, B.W., University of California, Sea Water Conversion Laboratory, Richmond, CA 94804, United States
Abstract: In this paper the performance of a low temperature, 50-70 C, solar boiler is presented. The boiler consisted of a double-glazed flat-plate solar collector, a flash chamber, a water cooled surface condenser, a circulating pump, and a temperature-controlled preheater to simulate constant temperature thermal storage. Data were obtained on this boiler from October 1980 to May 1981. During this period, the instantaneous total incident solar radiation at noon, as measured by a pyranometer in the plane of the collector ranged from 0.7 to 1.0 kWm-2 and the diurnal total incident solar radiation ranged from 13 to 29 MJ m-2day-1. At these conditions the instantaneous efficiency of the collector ranged from 30 to 55 percent while the diurnal efficiency ranged from 20 to 44 percent. The results show that the performance of the solar collector was the dominant factor in determining the performance of this boiler. They also show that low temperature steam, 50 to 70 C, from such boilers can be produced to drive multieffect distillation systems using high performance evaporators for desalting saline water. © 1981.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR BOILERS; DESALINATION

Title: Modeling soil-water-plant atmosphere systems of deserts.
Affiliations: Dept Agronomy & Soils, Washington State Univ, Pullman, Washington 99164, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Campbell, G.S., Dept Agronomy & Soils, Washington State Univ, Pullman, Washington 99164, USA.; Harris, G.A., Dept Agronomy & Soils, Washington State Univ, Pullman, Washington 99164, USA.
Abstract: The collection of equations that describes all fluxes and storages of energy and mass within the desert system can be regarded as a model of the soil-plant-atmosphere system of the desert. The primary source of energy is solar radiation. For the annual cycle, the absorbed solar radiation is dissipated mainly by convection and net long-wave radiation. This is also the case for the instantaneous energy budget of dry soil, except that a significant quantity of heat goes to storage in the soil during the day. When the soil surface is wet, the incoming energy is dissipated primarily by evaporation, but the amount of time that surfaces are wet is not large in the desert.-from Authors

Title: Metabolic responses of striped bass (Morone saxatilis) to temperature acclimation. I. Alterations in carbon sources for hepatic energy metabolism
Affiliations: Migratory Fish Research Institute and Department of Zoology, University of Maine at Orono, Orono, Maine, 04469, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stone, B.B., Migratory Fish Research Institute and Department of Zoology, University of Maine at Orono, Orono, Maine, 04469, United States; Sidell, B.D., Migratory Fish Research Institute and Department of Zoology, University of Maine at Orono, Orono, Maine, 04469, United States
Abstract: The relative contribution of carbohydrate and lipid to energy metabolism in liver tissue of temperature‐acclimated striped bass was examined in vitro. Respirometry experiments were conducted to assess the role of various endogenous foodstuffs in providing reduced two‐carbon fragments for aerobic metabolism. Liver composition was measured as a reflection of foodstuff flux and storage. Catabolism of 14C‐labeled substrates to 14CO2 was monitored to estimate the tissue capacity for utilization of various classes of compounds. When measured at the temperature of acclimation, oxygen uptake (V̇O2 by liver slices shows near perfect compensation between 15 and 25° C, whereas a 2.75‐fold increase is found between 5 and 15°C. Respiratory quotients (R.Q.) near unity are found at 5° C and decrease to 0.85 and 0.82 at 15 and 25° C, respectively. Inhibition of V̇O2 by iodoacetic acid, a glycolytic inhibitor, is near 60% at 5° C and decreases to 30–40% at 15 and 25° C. Evolution of 14CO2 from 14C‐labeled glucoses and palmitate confirms a conservation of liver tissue capacity for carbohydrate utilization between acclimation temperatures of 5 and 15° C, and an increasing capacity for utilization of fatty acids as temperature increases. Ratios of 14CO2 from 14C‐6‐and 14C‐1‐labeled glucoses indicate a relative increase in the participation of the pentose shunt in carbohydrate metabolism with cold acclimation. The results are consistent with an increasing reliance on carbohydrates for energy metabolism in the cold, whereas lipid substrates are utilized more at warm temperatures. These changes may be adaptive in partitioning energy reserves for seasonal activities of migration and reproduction. Copyright © 1981 Wiley‐Liss, Inc., A Wiley Company
