Title: Lib(ch3)4 -Dioxolane Electrolyte in Rechargeable Li/Tis2 Cells
Affiliations: Exxon. Research and Engineering Company, Corporate Research Laboratories, Linden, New Jersey 07036, Guyana
Authors with affiliations: Klemann, L.P., Exxon. Research and Engineering Company, Corporate Research Laboratories, Linden, New Jersey 07036, Guyana; Newman, G.H., Exxon. Research and Engineering Company, Corporate Research Laboratories, Linden, New Jersey 07036, Guyana
Abstract: LiB(CH3)4 is an example of a large class of boron complex anion salts which are very soluble and highly conductive in dioxolane. Solutions of LiB(CH3)4 have been investigated as electrolytes in Li-TiS2 cells. At room temperature such cells have been operated as rechargeable energy storage devices which are capable of continuous discharge (5 mA/cm2) and charge (1.25 mA/cm2) cycling. While solutions of LiB(CH3)4-dioxolane appear stable over long periods, contact with TiS2 results in anion oxidation with concomitant formation of LixTiS2 (x < 1). The oxidation products are gases whose apparent rate of generation is proportional to the concentrations of solute and TiS2. The product distribution depends on whether LiB(CH3)4-dioxolane solution contacts TiS2 alone, or in a Li-TiS2 cell. The electrolyte-cathode reaction is thought to involve transient methyl radicals which are formed during a concerted process involving anion oxidation and TiS2 lithiation. © 1981, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: anion; battery; discharge; organic; oxidation
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ELECTROLYTES

Title: Effects of stratification on the performance of solar air heating systems
Affiliations: Utah State University, Logan, UT 84322, United States
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, W.F., Utah State University, Logan, UT 84322, United States
Abstract: A theoretical model is presented which predicts the effects of stratification in the rock bed storage unit of a solar air heating system. The results are presented in terms of a stratification coefficient which is defined to be the ratio of the actual useful energy gain to the energy gain that would be achieved if the rock bed were maintained at a uniform temperature. This stratification coefficient is shown to be a system constant which depends on only three dimensionless system parameters. © 1981.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR AIR HEATING SYSTEMS; THERMAL STRATIFICATION; THERMAL VARIABLES MEASUREMENT

Title: Fault Contribution of Chlor-Alkali Cell Line
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corporation Electronics Components Divisions, Westinghouse Circle, Horseheads, NY 14845, United States; Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Box 4250 10510 Harwin Dr, Houston, TX 77001, United States

Abstract: Electrolytic cells, such as used in the chlor-alkali industry, have a potential of storing large amounts of electrical energy. The means of storage is discussed and the effect of a fault discharge is approached by mathematical model. Several means of dealing with this hazard are presented. Copyright © 1981 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTROLYTIC CELLS

Title: Loss of 111Indium as indicator of platelet injury
Affiliations: Dept.Med. St Louis Univ. Sch. Med., St Louis. Mo.63104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Joist, J.H., Dept.Med. St Louis Univ. Sch. Med., St Louis. Mo.63104, United States; Baker, R.K., Dept.Med. St Louis Univ. Sch. Med., St Louis. Mo.63104, United States
Abstract: We previously demonstrated that platelets can be labeled with 111Inoxine with high labeling efficiency and that 111In is not liberated from labeled platelets during the platelet release reaction or prolonged in vitro storage. In view of these findings, we examined the potential usefulness of loss of 111In from labeled platelets as an indicator of platelet damage by compairing the loss of 111In with that of 51Cr and LDH (in some experiments also with platelet factor 3 availability) under different conditions of platelet injury. When washed human platelets labeled with either 51Cr-chromate or 111In-oxine were exposed to increasing concentrations of detergents (Triton X-100, lysolecithin), threshold, rate, and extent of loss of 111In, 51Cr and, LDH were similar. In contrast, when labeled platelets were depleted of metabolic energy by incubation in glucose-free Tyrode albumin solution or glucose-depleted plasma in the presence of antimycin A and 2-deoxy-D-glucose, loss of 51Cr (and PF3a) occurred earlier and progressed at a faster rate than that of 111In or LDH. Similar results were obtained when platelets were exposed to increasing concentrations of PI(A1) antibody, causing complement-mediated immune injury. The findings indicate that with certain agents that cause rapid platelet disruption (lysis), different platelet constituents are lost at similar rates. However, under conditions of more subtle or slowly progressive platelet injury, small molecules such as adenine nucleotides (51Cr) may escape earlier and at faster rates than larger molecules such as LDH or 111In-binding platelet protein. Thus, neither 111In loss nor LDH loss appear to be suitable indicators for sublytic or prelytic platelet injury.

Title: the absorption process for heating, cooling and energy storage—an historical survey

Authors with affiliations: Bjurström, H., Department of Physical Chemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, S-100 44, Sweden; Raldow, W., Department of Physical Chemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, S-100 44, Sweden
Abstract: The principle of the absorption process is described and its versatility demonstrated. A wide range of applications, from household refrigerators to topping processes in power plants, are surveyed in an historical perspective. the production of mechanical energy and open systems are also included. Modern developments are reviewed, special attention being given to the aspets of thermal energy storage. Copyright © 1981 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Title: A combined wind and hydro power system
Affiliations: Roskilde University Center Roskilde, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Sørensen, B., Roskilde University Center Roskilde, Denmark
Abstract: A high degree of coverage of electricity demand by wind energy conversion is possible only with access to energy storage. For regions with both hydro and wind resources, the hydro power system and the wind power system may complement each other and alleviate the need for any other energy storage. Scandinavia is such a region, and this article uses a simulation model to assess the conditions under which all the electricity needs of Norway and Denmark could be satisfied by a combination of the existing Norwegian hydro power system with a hypothetical all wind-based Danish power system. © 1981.
Index Keywords: Denmark; electricity generation; Norway; COGENERATION PLANTS; ELECTRIC GENERATORS - Hydroelectric; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Norway; MODELS - Simulators; WIND POWER - Denmark; ENERGY POLICY

Authors: Braun J.E., Klein S.A., Mitchell J.W.
Title: Seasonal storage of energy in solar heating
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, W1, Madison, 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Braun, J.E., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, W1, Madison, 53706, United States; Klein, S.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, W1, Madison, 53706, United States; Mitchell, J.W., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, W1, Madison, 53706, United States
Abstract: This paper focuses on several aspects of seasonal storage for space heating using water as the storage medium. The interrelationships between collector area, storage volume, and system performance are investigated using the transient simulation program TRNSYS. The situations for which seasonal storage is most promising are presented. Particular emphasis is placed upon design of seasonal storage systems. A design method is presented which is applicable for storage capacities ranging from a few days to seasonal storage. This design method, coupled with cost information, should be useful in assessing the economic viability of seasonal storage systems. Also investigated are the importance of the load heat exchanger size, tank insulation, collector slope, and year-to-year weather variations in system design. © 1981.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; HEATING

Authors: Siegel M.D., Klein S.A., Beckman W.A.
Title: A simplified method for estimating the monthly-average performance of photovoltaic systems
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siegel, M.D., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Klein, S.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Beckman, W.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A method is presented for estimating the monthly-average conventional energy displaced by photovoltaic systems. Monthly-average array efficiency is estimated in terms of array parameters and monthly-average meteorological data. Monthly-average excess capacity is estimated for systems having a constant load during daylight hours. If the system does not have battery storage, excess capacity must be dissipated or fed back to the utility. With battery storage, a portion of the excess capacity can be stored for later use. A method is presented for estimating the monthly-average system performance for a constant 24 hr-per-day load with a battery of specified capacity. © 1981.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS - Arrays; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: A design procedure for wind powered heating systems
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Manwell, J.F., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States; McGowan, J.G., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a generalized design procedure for the month-by-month prediction of performance of wind powered residential heating systems. In its initial form, the technique is restricted to the simulation of residential heating systems using conventional horizontal axis wind turbines that dissipate their output into water based thermal storage systems (via electrical resistance heaters or fluid dissipation devices). The procedure using a graphical formulation (Wf-chart) is designed to give the monthly heating energy fraction supplied by a wind heating system with a minimum of site, wind turbine, and system input parameters. Such information is useful for simple performance studies or as input for economic assesment of wind heating systems. In addition example results of the calculational procedure for a typical wind heating system are presented. © 1981.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; WIND POWER; WIND POWERED HEATING SYSTEMS; WIND TURBINES; HEATING

Title: Geometrical effects on oxide scale integrity
Affiliations: Materials Division, Central Electricity Research Laboratories, Leatherhead, Surrey England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Manning, M.I., Materials Division, Central Electricity Research Laboratories, Leatherhead, Surrey England, United Kingdom
Abstract: The strains developed during oxidation on curved surfaces depend on the rate at which the bulk of the already formed scale is being displaced from an arbitrary reference point well within the metal substrate. A scale displacement vector is defined in terms of certain variables of scale formation and the strains arising can then be related to scale growth. Strain energy storage within the scale can be calculated for various oxidation kinetics and allowance made for stress relaxation due to oxide creep. Integrity limits for oxide scales growing on curved surfaces are then defined in terms of a critical strain energy criterion for oxide scale failure. The anodizing of aluminium and the growth of oxide scales on iron are considered as examples. It is also shown that the scale displacement vector as defined in this paper may have wider significance in areas where mechanical factors influence oxidation and where oxidation processes exert mechanical effects on their surroundings. © 1981.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS - Anodic Oxidation; IRON AND ALLOYS - Oxidation; OXIDE SCALE; METALS AND ALLOYS

Authors: Bénard C., Gobin D., Gutierrez M.
Title: Experimental results of a latent-heat solar-roof, used for breeding chickens
Affiliations: Laboratoire des Signaux et Systèmes, C.N.R.S./E.S.E., Plateau du Moulon, 91190-Gif-sur-Yvette, France; GR 14 (C.N.R.S.) Ecole Centrale, 92290 Chatenay-Malabry, France; Hualalache, Talavera, Provincia de Andahuaylas, Peru, Peru
Authors with affiliations: Bénard, C., Laboratoire des Signaux et Systèmes, C.N.R.S./E.S.E., Plateau du Moulon, 91190-Gif-sur-Yvette, France; Gobin, D., GR 14 (C.N.R.S.) Ecole Centrale, 92290 Chatenay-Malabry, France; Gutierrez, M., Hualalache, Talavera, Provincia de Andahuaylas, Peru, Peru
Abstract: The experimental results presented here have been obtained on a solar chicken brooder built in the Peruvian mountains (altitude {reversed tilde equals}3000m, latitude {reversed tilde equals}13°S). This installation is made of adobe and part of its roof is a solar collection-storage system consisting of two tanks of paraffin-wax located below glass panes. We study the short-range and long-range fluctuations of the variables characterizing the behaviour of the system and its fitness to its purpose: breeding young chickens that must be kept in a given range of temperature, with the air regularly renewed. © 1981.
Index Keywords: FARM BUILDINGS - Space Heating; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ROOFS; SOLAR ENERGY; HEATING

Title: Salt hydrates as absorbents in heat pump cycles
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stanish, M.A., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States; Perlmutter, D.D., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States
Abstract: A thermodynamic analysis has shown that inorganic salt hydrates are attractive candidates for absorbents in heat pump cycles. Their computed performance efficiencies compare favorably to those of previously proposed solid and liquid absorbents, under conditions typical of domestic, solar-powered, intermittent operation. It was found that hydrate cooling cycles, with coefficients-of-performance in the range of 0.6-0.7, can significantly outperform all others considered. In space heating applications, solid-absorbent cycles were far superior to a typical liquid-absorbent cycle in both overall efficiency and per cent of thermal energy input stored. Predicted hydrate coefficients-of-performance were in the range 1.4-1.6 with 75-85 per cent effective storage. © 1981.
Index Keywords: HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY; THERMODYNAMICS - Mathematical Models; HEATING

Title: Integrated performance of liquid-based solar heating systems
Affiliations: Utah State University, Logan, UT 84322, United States
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, W.F., Utah State University, Logan, UT 84322, United States
Abstract: A closed form model for the integrated performance of liquid-based solar heating systems is presented. The model is general enough to be used for most liquid-based systems. It can be used for systems with either flat plate or concentrating collectors and the load is not restricted to space heating applications. Three new system parameter are introduced by this model. These are the system heat storage factor, the solar distribution factor and the load distribution factor. These three factors respectively account for the reduction in system performancev which results from finite storage, non-uniform solar flux and non-uniform load. These factors are discussed in detail and closed form mathematical expressions, from which numerical values can be calculated, as persented. © 1981.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HEATING

Authors: Oke T.R., Kalanda B.D., Steyn D.G.
Title: Parameterization of heat storage in urban areas
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Oke, T.R., Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada; Kalanda, B.D., Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada; Steyn, D.G., Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
Abstract: A simple parameterization of hourly urban heat storage is developed. It relies on: established linear relationships between net radiation and heat storage in materials commonly encountered in urban areas; and a weighting of these equations according to the areal fraction of greenspace and built land-uses. Heat storage estimates are found to be in agreement with data available for suburban energy balances. Some of the limitations of the approach are reviewed. © 1981.
Index Keywords: theoretical study; thermal pollution; urban area

Title: Construction and startup performance of the miamisburg salt-gradient solar pond
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Monsanto Research Corp., Mound Facility, Miamisburg, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wittenberg, L.J., Monsanto Research Corp., Mound Facility, Miamisburg, OH, United States; Harris, M.J., Monsanto Research Corp., Mound Facility, Miamisburg, OH, United States
Abstract: The largest salt-gradient solar pond in the U. S. occupies an area of 2020 m2 and was installed for only $35/m2. The pond has a storage layer of 1.6 m consisting of 18 percentsodium chloride, a l-m gradient zone and a 0.4-m top convective zone. After 1.5 yr of operation, the storage temperature reached a maximum of 64°C in July and a minimumof 28°C in February. During July-September 1979, 143.5 GJ (136 million Btu) of heat was utilized. Under steady-state conditions, the pond is conservatively predicted to deliver over 1015 GJ/yr (962 million Btu) of heat to be used principally for heating an outdoor swimming pool in the summer and an adjacent recreation building from October to December each year.Based upon a 15- yr depreciation of the installation costs, the cost ofthis heat, $8.95/GJ ($9.45 /million Btu) is already belowthe cost of heating with fuel oil. Maintenance of water clarity, corrosion of metallic components, and the assurance of the containment of thepond water have been the principal operational concerns and will require further study. © 1981 by ASME.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; WATER RESOURCES

Title: The development and application of aquifer storage in China.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper P2
Authors with affiliations: Yan, Q.S.
Abstract: In order to solve the problem of the annual lowering of water table and land subsidence caused by excess extracting of aquifer water in Shanghai -- the biggest industrial city in China, we started to recharge water into aquifers through driven well since 1958 and obtain certain success. In the meantime we got some experiences in aquifer energy storage. Based on this experience Shanghai started to use aquifer storage of natural cooled water in winter for summer air conditioning in large scale since 1965 . Right now there are about ten cities using this method mostly for air conditioning in textile industry. This paper give a general description of aquifer energy storage in China, and the experience we have in selection of hydrogeological data, injection methods, clogging prevention and storage effectiveness. (A)

Authors: Chan H.C., Cheng K.B., Cheng A.C.C.
Title: A novel method of gas storage under the sea.
Source title: IN: HYDROGEN ENERGY PROGRESS, PROC. 3RD WORLD HYDROGEN ENERGY CONF., (TOKYO, JAPAN: JUN. 23-26, 1980), N. VEZIROGLU; K. FUEKI
Authors with affiliations: Chan, H.C.; Cheng, K.B.; Cheng, A.C.C.
Abstract: The surplus electricity of nuclear power stations during off-peak periods can be used to produce HSUP2 by eletrolysis. It is proposed that the large amount of HSUP2 produced can be stored in flexible containers under the sea. The advantages are two-fold: (i) being able to utilize the water pressure to counter balance the gas pressure, and (ii) being able to resist the pressure difference efficiently by membrane stresses only. Structural analysis shows that the stresses induced can be accommodated by inexpensive polymeric materials such as fibre reinforced butyl rubber. Problems of sea current, anchorage and construction of such a container are discussed.
Index Keywords: energy storage; offshore structures; submarine

Title: Advanced batteries for energy storage.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper L2
Authors with affiliations: Jensen, J.; Tofield, B.C.
Abstract: Rechargeable electric batteries offer considerable promise in energy storage systems, in particular for direct load levelling within the electrical utility network, for indirect load levelling and fuel substitution using electric vehicles, and for storage of renewable energy inputs, particularly solar energy. A review of these applications is given with emphasis on applications in Europe of electric vehicles and solar energy storage. Battery performance specifications are discussed and compared with current engineering developments. New data on battery storage in combination with photovoltaic and wind energy systems in Northern Europe are given. Finally, current materials developments which offer improved battery performance are reviewed. Particular reference is made to the work of an Anglo-Danish programme partially funded by CEC as part of the Indirect Action on Energy Conservation where future battery use in Europe has been assessed and development work on materials for advanced batteries in several cooperating laboratories has been coordinated in a joint programme.

Title: Performance study of air-heated packed-bed solar-energy collectors
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology, India
Authors with affiliations: Mishra, C.B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology, India; Sharma, S.P., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology, India
Abstract: A performance study of three packed-bed solar collectors for air-heating is presented. Iron chips, aluminium chips, and pebbles have been used as packing materials. It is observed that the performance of plane collectors improves appreciably by packing with blackened metallic materials. Moreover, the packed-bed collector also works nicely as a thermal storage system. Iron-chips packed-bed collectors show the best performance. © 1981.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS - Energy Storage; GRANULAR MATERIALS - Energy Storage; HEATING - Hot Air Systems; IRON AND ALLOYS - Energy Storage; SAND AND GRAVEL - Energy Storage; METAL CHIPS; PEBBLES; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Challis, H.
Abstract: A report on the conference on energy storage held in Brighton, U.K. from 29 April-1 May, 1981 is presented.

Title: Retrievable drilling facility of marginal oilfields.
Abstract: Three major energy related companies have formed Sea Plex Corporation of Tulsa to provide the offshore industry with retrievable, bottom supported facilities for drilling, production and storage specially designed to exploit marginal fields.

Title: Solar energy storage in forced stratification tanks.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper N3
Authors with affiliations: Jesch, I.F.; Greeves, T.M.
Abstract: A solar energy storage system has three main components: collector, heat exchanger and storage tank. Each component has its own operating characteristic and efficiency, but when they are series connected they have mutual effects on each other. The size and distribution of tanks will influence the heat exchanger which in turn will determine the limits for the collector operation. The secondary circuit of the indirect system transfers energy from the heat exchanger to the storage tanks which are distributed in size and in temperature. This has the effect of a forced stratification which increases the system's capability of collecting and storing solar energy. Four different storage tank arrangements are examined all arrangements having the same overall capacity. Four different weather patterns are used and several different control strategies. The total collector area is 60 mSUB2 and the total storage capacity is 9mSUB3 solar heated storage plus a 1 1/2 mSUB3 final tank with auxillary heating in an installation which is used for validating the proposition of this paper: forced stratification improves the performance of the solar energy storage. (A)

Title: PCM bulk storage.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper H3
Authors with affiliations: MacCracken, C.D.
Abstract: On-site filling, high performance efficiency, low thermal losses, small size, and overall reliability have established the phase change material (PCM) bulk storage concept with internal plastic tube heat exchanger as a serious contender in the field of themal energy storge. (A)

Title: Thermal storage system using metal hydrides.
Source title: IN: HYDROGEN ENERGY PROGRESS PROC. 3RD WORLD HYDROGEN ENERGY CONF., (TOKYO, JAPAN: JUN.23-26, 1980), T.N. VEZIROGLU; K. FUEKI
Authors with affiliations: Sakai, T.; Honda, N.
Abstract: With an acceleration of the development of thermal energy storage (TES) systems, an advanced TES technology is required. In this paper, the chemical thermal energy storage (CTES) method whch has a potential for long-term storage is described. In the study, the experimental CTES system was constructed by using metal hydrides which were known as CTES materials and were comparatively superior in CTES performances. The experimental CTES performances for both individual metal hydrides and the system were obtained; energy balance of the system was estimated and possibility of th CTES system using metal hydrides was discussed.

Title: Sea thermal power.
Source title: IN: ENERGY - PRESENT AND FUTURE OPTIONS
Volume: 1 , D. Merrick; R. Marshall (eds.), Chichester, U.K., John Wiley & Sons, 1981, Chapter 2
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, J.H.; Mayer, D.E.
Abstract: Sea thermal power (STP) denotes the use of the tropical sea as a natural collection and storage system for solar energy. Three systems using different cycles for harnessing the thermal gradient are described, the closed (Rankine) cycle, the open cycle and the foam mist cycle. None of these techniques has been incorporated into systems larger than model scale, but a number of full scale design studies have been completed. (from paper)
Index Keywords: Ocean thermal energy conversion

Authors: Saugy B., Hadorn J.C., Bloch G.
Title: Large-scale underground heat storage.
Source title: IN: NEW ENERGY CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGIES & THEIR COMMERCIALIZATION, PROC. INT. CONF., (BERLIN, FED. REP. GERMANY: APR. 6-10,
Volume: 1 , Berlin, Fed. Rep. Germany, Springer Verlag, 1981, Session G, p.748-755. (ISBN 3-540-11124-7)
Authors with affiliations: Saugy, B.; Hadorn, J.C.; Bloch, G.
Abstract: Selection and exploration of a test site for heat storage in an aquifer is described and technico-economic aspects of such storage are analyzed. A future pilot project is reported. (N.G.G.)
Index Keywords: Energy storage; feasibility study

Title: Project Icebox - an annual energy storage system.
Authors with affiliations: Klassen, J.
Abstract: Annual storage of energy is becoming a valuable building energy conservation procedure. Within cold climate areas, and abetted by the escalating energy costs, the practice could be revived if labor costs could be reduced. Project Icebox is an attempt to do so by creating the ice naturally near the load, within the insulated icehouse, and by transferring the cooling capacity via chilled water to the warm weather load. (A)

Title: Thermal exchange to earth with concentric well pipes.
Source title: TRANS. AM. SOC. AGRIC. ENGRS. (GEN. EDN.)
Authors with affiliations: Oliver, J.; Braud, H.
Abstract: An analysis of steady state heat transfer to earth with concentric well pipes was made. Equations for fluid temperature distribution in the pipes are given. The effects of inner pipe insulation, well depth and pipe, fluid, and earth thermal properties are related to heat transfer capacity with dimensionless parameters. A design graph for heat flow rate is given. Alternative well design configurations are compared on cost-effective basis to demonstrate the use of the well design graph. (A)
Index Keywords: Earth; energy; heat exchanger; Storage

Title: Hydroelectric power station.
Authors with affiliations: Petlach, A.
Abstract: Describes the new hydroelectric power station built in the Ore Mountains which has a total capacity of 1050 MW. It works on the system of water being pumped into storage reservoirs situated at great heights to form a ready reserve of energy. That energy, converted by water turbines into electric power, covers the shortages in the power system at times of peak demand or during failures of the system. Details of construction, capacity and operation are given.

Title: Convective and conductive heat transfer in hot-water storage tanks.
Source title: IN: NEW ENERGY CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGIES & THEIR COMMERCIALIZATION, PROC. INT. CONF., (BERLIN, FED. REP. GERMANY: APR. 6-10,
Volume: 1 , Berlin, Fed. Rep. Germany, Springer-Verlage, 1981, Session G, p.715-725. (ISBN 3-540-11124-7)
Authors with affiliations: Straub, J.; Staudt, A.
Abstract: The economic efficiency of hot water storage depends on the amount of available energy for heating. The thermodynamic behaviour is discussed and a calculation for the temperature profile in the tank is given taking into account the external heat losses and the internal heat exchange by conduction and convection. Because of so many parameters like volume, geometry, insulation, temperatures, storage cycle, etc. no analytical solution can be expected. The differential equation system must be solved numerically for each set of boundary conditions. (from authors' abstract)
Index Keywords: power stations; Solar collectors

Title: Experimental experience with the ASHRAE/NB5 procedures for testing a phase change thermal storage device.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper H1
Authors with affiliations: Marshall, R.
Abstract: The application of the ASHRAE 94-77 Standard and it counterpart NBSIR 74-634 is considered in conjunction with testing for thermal performance of a paraffin based phase change storage unit. The results of these tests lead to meaningless values because they imply more energy can be stored or extracted than is theoretically possible. It is the purpose of this study therefore to review the standard procedures in light of the results to indicate where the deficiencies arise.

Title: Thermal energy storage in industry and power stations.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper G1
Authors with affiliations: Goldstern, W.
Abstract: balancing fluctuations, recovering waste heat and adjusting heat and power requirements in combined plants. Accumulators have moved into the high pressure range, a new type of pressure vessel may provide a basis for the size required in power stations. (A) Since the fuel crisis, thermal storage has received greatly increased attention, especially in connection with unconventional methods and new source of energy, such as solar energy. The two main systems are described and compared. Typical installations in industrial works are shown, as used for eliminating shortage of steam,

Title: Wave device could rival pumped storage.
Abstract: The use of gyroscopes inside the nodding duck wave energy device could now make it more efficient than conventional pumped storage stations for return times of about 40 mins.

Title: Storage of solar energy.
Source title: ASSET. Abstracts of selected solar energy technology
Authors with affiliations: Kakac, S.; Yener, Y.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Energy in a finite world- executive summary. Report by the Energy Systems Program Group of the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis. Wolf Hafele, Program Leader.
Source title: Executive Report, International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis
Authors with affiliations: McDonald, A.
Abstract: Attempts to determine how the world might successfully negotiate the transition to a sustainable global energy system. Includes an historical analysis and a long-term evaluation of future supply possibilities. A detailed analysis of the immediate future to determine trends that are already established follows. These 3 sections together suggest that adaption has already begun and is currently proceeding on a number of fronts. Concludes by making a case for hydrogen as the fuel of the future, because 1) the technology for its production is well developed 2) processes for converting nuclear or solar heat directly into hydrogen without the intermediate step of electricity production appear promising; 3) of ease of storage; 4) much existing infrastructure can be used for hydrogen; 5) it is environmentally attractive. -C.Elliott
Index Keywords: environmental impact; fuel; global energy system; hydrogen; technology

Title: Potential energy and capacity gains from flood control storage reallocation at U.S. hydropower reservoirs.
Source title: IN: WATERPOWER '81, PROC. INT. CONF. ON HYDROPOWER, (WASHINGTON, D.C.: JUN. 22-24, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., U.S. Army Corps Engrs., 1981, Session I & II
Authors with affiliations: Eichert, B.S.; Bonner, V.R.
Abstract: Procedures and results of an investigation to evaluate potential increases in nationwide hydropower production that could be achieved by reallocation of flood control storage at existing hydropower reservoirs are described. (from paper)

Title: Kinetic ring energy storage system.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper S2
Authors with affiliations: Russell, F.M.; Chew, S.H.
Abstract: There is an existing need for storing energy on a large scale in a form which can efficiently and quickly be converted to electricity. In particular, the storage system should not be critically dependent upon the geographic nature of the site nor be environmentally obtrusive. A system for storing energy in kinetic form is proposed which is based upon existing technologies. A massive ring, free to rotate about its axis of symmetry, is accelerated to high linear speeds by means of motors coupled to the ring through wheels or gears. Power is extracted by decelerating the ring using the same motors as generators. The gravitational and inertial forces of motion are transmitted to the surrounding ground by means of a distributed support system using rolling wheels on rails. (A)

Authors: Mead J.W., Mead K.E., Auerbach I., Ericksen R.H.
Title: (Accelerated ageing of nylon 6,6 and Kevlar 29 in elevated temperature, elevated humidity, smog and ozone)
Authors with affiliations: Mead, J.W.; Mead, K.E.; Auerbach, I.; Ericksen, R.H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Night storage heaters.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper G2
Authors with affiliations: Eeles, W.T.
Abstract: The development of storage heating equipment in the UK is discussed. The performance of various types of heater is described and future storage systems are considered in the light of present day requirements and possible minimum energy scenarios. (A)

Title: Wind energy in the Kingdom of Morocco - past, present and future.
Authors with affiliations: D'Aquanni, R.T.; Wung, H.T.
Abstract: Wind Energy Conversion Systems (WECS) as an available technology to supply small electric loads and to replace unreliable and expensive diesel engines for water pumping in the Kingdom of Morocco were examined. The selected systems ranged from 10 to 40 KW's in peak capacity, used both AC and DC generators, and employed battery and water storage. (A)
Index Keywords: wind power

Title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Storage held in Brighton, U.K., on April 29-May 1, 1981. Volume 1.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Model simulations of aquifer stores and their application to actual field experiments.
Source title: IN: NEW ENERGY CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGIES & THEIR COMMERCIALIZATION, PROC. INT. CONF., (BERLIN, FED. REP. GERMANY: APR. 6-10,
Volume: 1 , Berlin, Fed. Rep. Germany, Springer Verlag, 1981, Session G, p.734-741. (ISBN 3-540-11124-7)
Authors with affiliations: Tsang, C.F.
Abstract: An experiment in which hot water was stored in an aquifer for two months is described and aquifer storage where buoyant flow is and is not negligible is analyzed. (N.G.G.)
Index Keywords: Energy storage

Title: Estimation of storage costs for large hydrogen storage facilities.
Source title: IN: HYDROGEN ENERGY PROGRESS, PROC. 3RD WORLD HYDROGEN ENERGY CONF., (TOKYO, JAPAN: JUN. 23-26, 1980), N. VEZIROGLU; K. FUEKI
Authors with affiliations: Carpetis, C.
Abstract: The paper presents an economic evaluation of alternative hydrogen storage methods (pressurized gas, metal hydride or cryogenic storage) for large stationary (utility-scale) applications. The presentation of cost calculation clarifies the importance and influence of a set of relevant parameters depending on the charging-discharging schedule, the relation of the power to capacity level etc. The results presented define the useful range of application for each storage method, whereas the corresponding cost composition (power related capital costs, capacity-related capital costs, energy costs) is analysed and discussed.
Index Keywords: energy storage

Title: Transient thermal effects in an enclosed water body due to heated water discharge for heat rejection and solar energy storage
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, 110016, India; Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, 208 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, S.K., Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, 110016, India, Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, 208 016, India; Jaluria, Y., Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, 110016, India, Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, 208 016, India
Abstract: An experimental study of the transient temperature distribution in an enclosed water body due to the discharge of hot water into it is carried out. The dependence of the profiles on the inlet location and the inlet temperature and flow rate is studied in detail. A stable thermal stratification is found to arise in several cases and the study determines its growth with time and its dependence on the flow configuration. The relevance of the study to solar energy storage, as sensible heat, and to heat rejection processes is also discussed. © 1981.
Author Keywords: Convection in enclosures; Heat rejection; Mixed convection in enclosures; Solar energy storage; Thermal discharge in enclosures; Thermal stratification
Index Keywords: WATER - Thermodynamics; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Underground pumped hydro and compressed air energy storage concepts a technical and economic comparison.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper R1
Authors with affiliations: Willett, D.C.
Abstract: Either underground pumped hydro (UPH) or compressed air energy storage (CAES) concepts can meet the needs of power utilities for central energy storage over the next several decades. However, many of the characteristics of these two concepts are significantly different and will impact in different ways upon the economics and operations of power systems. A recent major study commissioned by the U.S. Department of Energy and the Electric Power Research Institute has provided the opportunity to undertake a detailed comparison of the two energy storage concepts. The paper briefly describes the study program which includes site selected and investigation, examination of alternative designs, and the selection of an optimum arrangement of both the CAES and UPH facilities. The paper goes on to compare and contrast the characteristics of the two concepts from the standpoint of site selection, capital and operating costs, construction schedules and environmental impact. (A)

Title: Thermal Storage of Solar Energy, Proc. Int. TNO-Symp., held in Amsterdam, The Netherlands on November 5-6, 1980.
Authors with affiliations: Den Ouden, C.
Abstract: Sensible heat storage, latent heat storage; long term storage; chemical storage of thermal energy.

Title: Some basic phenomena of aquifer storage and their influence on storage and systems performance.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper P1
Authors with affiliations: Reffstup, J.; Wurtz, J.
Abstract: In the present paper some of the basic physical principles governing the storage of thermal energy in aquifers are discussed. Simplified numerical models for the prediction of storage efficiencies are presented. On the basis of numerical results obtained by the use of these models, the influence on the storage efficiency of important parameters such as aquifer permeablity, aquifer height, injection rate, and storage time are discussed and illustrated graphically. Furthermore, the paper gives a simple expression to be used for a first estimate of the suitability of specific geological structures for thermal energy storage. Finally, the performance of the aquifer store as a component of the energy system is described. The discussion concentrates on the relationship between energy recovery ratios and operational modes of the district heating system. Correlations between storage efficiencies and supply/return temperatures in the distict heating systems are shown. (A)

Title: Potential for a danish power system using wind energy generators, solar cells and storage
Affiliations: Physics Laboratory III, The Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark; Laboratory of Applied Physics III, The Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Blegaa, S., Physics Laboratory III, The Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark; Christiansen, G., Laboratory of Applied Physics III, The Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Denmark; solar energy; wind energy; POWER GENERATION - SOLAR ENERGY; WIND POWER - ENERGY UTILIZATION; SOLAR CELLS; ENERGY RESOURCES - ENERGY MANAGEMENT

Title: Pumped - storage development in Brazil.
Authors with affiliations: Ciarlini, R.M.; Filho, W.J.
Abstract: Because of particularly advantageous topographical and geographical conditions in Brazil, the potential for pumped storage is not only vast, but also located in areas close to the main load centres. This article gives details of a preliminary analysis of the Brazilian power system for the future development of daily/weekly pumped-storage plants, planned to meet system peak loads, information is given from surveys carried out covering about 160 sites in the Southeast and Northeast of the country. An economic comparison of options focuses on investment, operation and maintenance, fuel, financial and pumping energy costs, showing the competitiveness of pumped-storage, conventional hydro and gas turbines. (A)

Title: Air storage gas turbine power plants a major distribution for energy storage.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper R3
Authors with affiliations: Lehmann, J.
Abstract: This paper gives an overview about air storage gas turbine power plants. After describing briefly the operation experience with the world's first plant in Huntorf an outlook is given for future development. Main projects in different countries are mentioned. The development of advanced systems up to integrated use of PFBC boiler systems is explained. (A)

Title: Low grade heat storage using sodium acetate solution.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper J2
Authors with affiliations: Bell, M.A.
Abstract: This paper presents an account of the author's experience and results during the development of a small scale thermal store using sodium acetate solution. Reasons for the choice of sodium acetate are given and the operational principles of the store are described. Three different prototype stores are considered and the operational experience with each is described. A theoretical model for the discharge performance of the third store is presented and compared with the experimental results. Problems associated with heat extraction from the store are discussed. The experimental results show that during the discharge cycle a high degree of stratification was maintained and the thermal energy storage density exceeded twice that available from water for the same temperature swing. The potential for design improvement and areas requiring further investigation are outlined. (A)

Authors: Babaz G., Cros P., Muzyka D.W., Large J.F.
Title: High temperature heat storage using fluidizable media: applications to the rational energy management on industrial sites.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper F1
Authors with affiliations: Babaz, G.; Cros, P.; Muzyka, D.W.; Large, J.F.
Abstract: This paper presents the results from a study on the integration of a high temperature heat storage system using fluidizable media into a refinery or other industrial site where heat is recovered from variable flowrate combustion gases partly to produce electricity. The system flowsheet and individual components are described with emphasis placed on heat exchangers especially the Raining Packed Bed Exchanger used for direct contact gas-solids heat transfer. Experimental results on this exchanger showing that temperature gradients of up to 700SUPC are possible with gas pressure drops of only a few centimeters of water are given. The results of the storage system design show that a large percentage of the available energy can be recovered using either a gas turbine or steam power cycle while maintaining a moderately sized overall installation. (A)

Authors: Rao A.K., Niewiarowski S., Murphy S.
Title: Acquired granular pool defect in stored platelets
Affiliations: Spec. Cent. Thrombosis Res., Temple Univ. Hlth Sci. Cent., Philadelphia, Pa. 19140, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rao, A.K., Spec. Cent. Thrombosis Res., Temple Univ. Hlth Sci. Cent., Philadelphia, Pa. 19140, United States; Niewiarowski, S., Spec. Cent. Thrombosis Res., Temple Univ. Hlth Sci. Cent., Philadelphia, Pa. 19140, United States; Murphy, S., Spec. Cent. Thrombosis Res., Temple Univ. Hlth Sci. Cent., Philadelphia, Pa. 19140, United States
Abstract: Platelets stored as concentrates (PC) for 72 hr at 22°C develop a functional defect. Alterations in adenine nucleotides of platelets have been shown to affect platelet function. Adenine nucleotide content of platelets was measured before and after storage and a decrease of 27.1 ± 1.7% (mean ± SE) in ATP and 39.1 ± 2.6% in ADP were found in 34 PC stored with final volume of 50 ml. In 11 PC with 30 mol volume, ATP and ADP decreased by 39.4 ± 3.2% and 49.4 ± 2.1%, respectively. The mean ATP to ADP ratio of stored platelets was significantly higher than of fresh platelets in both groups, suggesting a relatively greater decrease in granular than metabolic pool nucleotides. Levels of low affinity platelet factor 4 measured by radioimmunoassay in plasma increased from 0.86 ± 0.08 μg/ml in the fresh PC to 8.59 ± 0.39 μg/ml in stored PC, indicating a concomitant α-granular secretion. Labeling of metabolic pool with 14C-adenine revealed a mean decrease in the adenylate energy charge of 2.0 ± 0.4% in 12 of 16 stored PC, with a lower ATP and higher hypoxanthine labeling in stored as compared to fresh platelets. These observations suggest that stored platelets develop an acquired defect in both dense and α granules and in their ability to maintain ATP homeostasis.
Index Keywords: blood and hemopoietic system; blood storage; human cell; theoretical study; thrombocyte dysfunction

Title: Chemical heat storage and heat transformation using reversible solid-gas reactions.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper C3
Authors with affiliations: Nonnenmacher, A.; Groll, M.
Abstract: Reversible chemical reactions can be utilised for both storage of thermal energy as well as upgrading of thermal energy by the use of heat pumps and heat transformers. Suitable reactins for such processes are liquid-gas reactions ('wet' absorption processes) and solid-gas reactions ('dry' absorption processes). Among the multitude of potentially feasible solid-gas reactions the metal-hydrogen reactions form a special class with attractive characteristics. Those reactions are dealt with in greater detail. Results obtained with a heat transformer laboratory model demonstrate the potential of metal-hydrogen reactions and provide useful information concerning the further development of such systems. (A)

Title: Natural rubber protects platforms and supply ships.
Abstract: Describes the Regal 'Defender', the latest in a line of stand-off devices, all using natural rubber as an energy storage material. Specifications and capabilities are discussed along with improvements over other devices.
Index Keywords: fenders

Authors: Sexon B., Slack G., Musgrove P., Lipman N., Dunn P.
Title: Aspects of a wind energy conversion system.
Authors with affiliations: Sexon, B.; Slack, G.; Musgrove, P.; Lipman, N.; Dunn, P.
Abstract: A description of a wind energy conversion system being considered at Reading University . A wind turbine is used as its primary power source, backed up by a short term battery storage facility and a diesel generator. The system is designed for a community having a power capacity of 10kW to 50kW. (from paper)

Title: Energy storage within a two-basin tidal power scheme.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper S1
Authors with affiliations: Bickley, D.T.
Abstract: A two-basin tidal power scheme could generate energy to meet a specified day-time pattern of demand almost independently of the tide. More day-time energy is obtainable if the scheme absorbs energy at night for pumping to help restore its water level; and if it is operated to obtain the maximum possible day-time energy output within a specified demand pattern it requires approximately the same energy input at night. The scheme can therefore function as a bulk energy- transfer scheme of at least 100% efficiency, storing surplus energy at night and releasing it during the day. The peak power demand on the rest of the C.E.G.B. system would be reduced and the base load raised, so giving a double reduction in the amount of plant which has to be cycled daily. This will become increasingly valuable as the nuclear component of the C.E.G.B. system increases. This paper describes the performance of such a scheme located in the Severn Estuary and operated to meet both constant and variable day-time power demands. The day-time energy output varies relatively little with the range and time of the tide, but the night-time energy input varies more noticeably. The scheme would also generate more energy if it was not required to meet the very short-term peaks in the day- time demand. The capital cost of the scheme would probably be higher than that of inland high-head pumped storage; but it may be necessary if there are not enough suitable site available for high-head schemes. It also combines into one project the functions of generation and storage which otherwise would required development of several separate sites.

Authors: Merrick D., Giramonti A.T., Lessard R.D., Blecher W.A.
Title: Coal-fired air storage power plants for load leveling applications.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper R4
Authors with affiliations: Merrick, D.; Giramonti, A.T.; Lessard, R.D.; Blecher, W.A.
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) power plants have been extensively studied for USA and European electric utility load leveling applications, and one plant is in commercial operation. All contemplated first generation CAES power plants would consume premium petroleum fuel during the power generation mode. This paper presents highlights of a study of a coal-fired CAES system using Pressurized Fluidized Bed Combustors (PFBC). The results of the study indicate that PFBC/CAES power plants have the potential for commercial application by the early 1990's, should be economically competitive with conventional oil-fired plants, and should have good part load performance and rapid load following capability. (A)

Title: The man-made aquifer concept.
Source title: IN: NEW ENERGY CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGIES & THEIR COMMERCIALIZATION, PROC. INT. CONF., (BERLIN, FED. REP. GERMANY: APR. 6-10,
Volume: 1 , Berlin, Fed. Rep. Germany, Springer Verlag, 1981, Session G, p.756-776. (ISBN 3-540-11124-7)
Authors with affiliations: Weissenbach, B.
Abstract: The concept of a near surface aquifer heat storage unit with processed material was developed to the state of project definition of a pilot plant. Simultaneously to technical and economic investigations, problems of chemical mass transport in typical soil materials were investigated in laboratory tests. Special attention was paid to the biological behaviour of a wet gravel bed in view of the possibility of clogging by slime. Corrosion in connection with the quality of water in aquifers was considered for various materials. Several layouts of aquifer storage units were drafted and the cost calculated for different site conditions. Facilities larger than 10 000 m SUP 3 (water equivalent) turned out to be cheaper than present known storage concepts. (from author's abstract)
Index Keywords: Energy storage

Title: Aquifer thermal energy storage: experimental and theoretical investigations.
Source title: IN: NEW ENERGY CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGIES & THEIR COMMERCIALIZATION, PROC. INT. CONF., (BERLIN, FED. REP. GERMANY: APR. 6-10,
Volume: 1 , Berlin, Fed. Rep. Germany, Springer Verlag, 1981, Session G, p.742-747. (ISBN 3-540-11124-7)
Authors with affiliations: Rouve, G.; Pelka, W.
Abstract: Heat transport in flowing ground water was analyzed using a finite element technique and the results obtained are compared with those obtained from a model test. (N.G.G.)

Title: A review on the R & D on heat storage in the European Solar Energy Programme.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR.29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper A1
Authors with affiliations: Steemers, T.C.
Abstract: The impact of Solar Energy as an alternative energy source will be greatly influenced by the way we deal with its main handicap, the daily and seasonal fluctuation of the supply of solar energy to the earth's surface. Right from the start of the programme on solar energy of the Commission of the European Communities in 1976 , great emphasis has been laid upon R & D on solar heat storage. Since then, 35 research contracts in this field of heat storage have been concluded with European research institutes, industries, universities, etc. with a total cost of 7 million units of account i.e. 4.2 million pounds sterling. This paper reviews that part of the Commission's R & D programme that deals with solar heat storage. It presents the results obtained so far and describes the work in progress. (A)

Authors: White P.A., E Rohn M., Sokol D.R.
Title: FRC-80 a protective membrane for thin film anticorrosion coatings.
Authors with affiliations: White, P.A.; E Rohn, M.; Sokol, D.R.
Abstract: The transportation of energy resources, mainly oil and gas, from well heads to storage and distribution centres has intensified during recent years. Particularly in areas which had previously been considered uneconomic to work, evidence shows that improvements in the integrity of transporting pipelines are both necessary and technically desirable. Any advances in technology which could be used for the protection and preservation of pipelines, under all feasible conditions of service, would create an active interest in the pipeline production industry which is required to devise and provide transportation services throughout this century and into the next. Over the years, bituminous compounds have been used with some success to combat corrosion on pipeline exteriors. If a thicker, cheaper protective and integrated coating could be laid over the epoxy corrosion resistant film, which would give strength and protection to the epoxy coating, it would make possible a confident and wider use of such protected pipelines for heavy duties. Such a protective coating has been developed. Known as FRC-80, it is a fibre reinforced cementitious plastic. (A)

Title: The U.S. Thermal Energy Storage Program.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981
Authors with affiliations: Olszewski, M.
Abstract: Thermal energy storage can play a key role in industrial energy conservation efforts to reduce oil and gas consumption. This can be accomplished by using storage to recycle industrial reject heat, thereby reducing energy consumption, or by substituting alternate fuels for oil and gas. Thus, the three major program areas include in-plant reuse of industrial reject heat, external reuse of industrial reject heat, and the use of alternate fuels. The U.S. Industrial Thermal Energy Storage Program has demonstration and/or technology transfer project underway in each of these areas. This paper will describe these projects, the organisation of the U.S. Industrial Thermal Energy Storage Program, and indicate future program directions. (A)

Authors: Adams B., Kitching R., Barker J.A., Miles D.L.
Title: Investigation of the potential of aquifier thermal energy storage in the United Kingdom.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper P3
Authors with affiliations: Adams, B.; Kitching, R.; Barker, J.A.; Miles, D.L.
Abstract: A substantial amount of theoretical and experimental research into Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage (ATES) has been carried out in the USA, China and to a lesser extent in parts of Europe. Consideration is given to the major chemical and physical processes and parameters involved in the ATES including convection, porosity, permeability, solution-precipitation reaction, clay mineralogy and radius of influence of the anomaly. The Lower Greensand and the Permo-Triassic formations are discussed as potential aquifers for preliminary ATES investigations. It is suggested that the Lower Greensand aquifer to the Cambridge area would be more suited to a relatively small-scale experiment and Permo-Triassic Sandstone of the Midlands to investigations on a much larger scale. Is is concluded that there is currently a need for some field experimental work to assess the practical problems of the application of ATES in the United Kingdom. (A)

Authors: Wood R.J., Gladwell S.D., O'Callaghan P.W., Probert S.D.
Title: Low temperature thermal energy storage using packed beds of encapsulated phase-change materials.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper H2
Authors with affiliations: Wood, R.J.; Gladwell, S.D.; O'Callaghan, P.W.; Probert, S.D.
Abstract: In the temperature range of 30 to 100SUPC, thermal energy can be readily stored in the forms of latent and sensible heat in packed beds of encapsulated phase-change materials. The net energy density of such systems is significantly greater than for water over the same temperature swing. A summary for encapsulation processes is presented along with target cost figures. Thermal energy storage systems of this type have good heat transfer characteristics because of the large surface areas available. Self-supporting packed bed particles are favoured because of the consequent overall simplicity of the storage system design. Typical results obtained from a small-scale, experimental packed bed of 20 mm diameter, wax-filled, high density polypropylene spheres are presented. A computer model of this system is described and the performance of the characteristics for congruent and phase-change trajectory conditions are predicted. A packed-bed heat transfer correlation has been developed using a technique of least squares matching between the computed and experimentally determined, dynamic performance characteristics.

Title: New ways to save energy.
Abstract: A report from an EEC seminar held in Brussels in October 1979 , which included sessions on heatpumps; heat exchangers; heat recovery; energy storage; transport.

Title: A seismic response analysis of a cylindrical liquid storage tank including the effect of sloshing.
Authors with affiliations: Fujita, K.
Abstract: A seismic response analysis method for a cylindrical liquid storage tank subjected to a horizontal earthquake is presented in this paper. The kinetic and strain energies of an empty tank shell were estimated assuming it has an axisymmetric shell. The virtual work of liquid pressure exerting on the tank wall was also estimated analytically by assuming that the behaviour of the liquid follows the velocity potential theory which includes the effect of sloshing. As a result of numerical studies, this solution was proved to be an effective and reasonable method for the seismic response analysis of a cylindrical liquid storage tank. (from author's abstract)
Index Keywords: storage vessel; Stresses

Title: The catalytic reversible (de) hydrogeneration of cyclohexane as a means for energy storage and chemical heat pump.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper D2
Authors with affiliations: Giordano, N.; Cacciola, G.
Abstract: Catalytic reversible reactions have ben recently advocated as promising means for thermal energy storage and/or energy transfer (chemical heat pipe). In this area, the (de)hydrogenation model reaction appears outstanding for it is characterized by high degree of reversibility, high energy storage density, easy separation of product, ability to store for any desired length of time, from daily to interseasonal. A crucial point of the system is the development of suitable catalysts and reactors as well as choice of proper operative conditions.

Title: System Tepidus, high capacity thermochemical storage/heat pump.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper C1
Authors with affiliations: Bakken, K.
Abstract: In 1976 research team at the Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Sweden, started the development of a new type of thermochemical storage system. TEPIDUS AB is a development company founded to further develop and market SYSTEM TEPIDUS. The system is a dual chamber system with distillation storage. The working fluid and the absorber are HSUP2O and NaSUP2S respectively. As the thermal energy is converted into chemical energy, storing is possible for an unlimited period of time, and when needed the chemical energy is reconverted again into thermal energy.

Title: Sede boqer shallow pond project
Affiliations: Energy Conversion Unit, Institute for Desert Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kudish, A., Energy Conversion Unit, Institute for Desert Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva, Israel
Abstract: The use of shallow solar ponds (convecting solar ponds) for the conversion of solar energy into low grade thermal energy has been a subject of intensive investigation in recent years. At the Institute for Desert Research at the Sede Boqer Campus we have been testing this concept with emphasis placed upon the utilization of locally manufactured components. The daily performance of four small module shallow solar ponds has been monitored almost continuously between August 1978 and May 1979. The ponds are each 2 × 1.3 m in size. They all have the same black PVC lower film, but differ either in the type of upper transparent film, glazing material or glazing angle. The daily performance is characterized by three factors, viz. the maximum daily water temperature achieved, the total daily thermal energy collected and the daily efficiency. Monthly average performance factors for the SSP modules have been determined. Based upon the experimental data, we conclude that the SSP system is capable of supplying ~ 3 GJ/m2-yr of thermal energy under climatic conditions similar to those prevailing at Sede Boqer, i.e. semi-arid zones. The economic feasibility of such a system has been analyzed in comparison with the following alternate energy sources: oil (heavy fraction), natural gas and electricity. © 1981.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Applications; SOLAR PONDS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Feedstock hydrogen-competition for energy storage?
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON ENERGY STORAGE, (BRIGHTON, U.K.: APR. 29-MAY 1, 1981)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1981, Paper M2
Authors with affiliations: Bowles, R.; Hart, A.B.
Abstract: The UK presently uses about half a million tonnes of hydrogen per year for making fertilizer ammonia, methanol and for oil processing. The source of this hydrogen is either naptha or natural gas. Coal is a likely future source, and coal is also the likely basis for future fuels in the form of substitute natural gas and synthetic petroleum products. Economic production of these would benefit from adding elemental hydrogen. Several million tonnes of hydrogen could be usefully used per year in this way. The hydrogen could be produced electrolytically from off-peak under nuclear energy, but the question is whether this can be done at a price which is competitive with the coal-derived product. The paper discusses this. The cost and efficiency of the electrolyser and the value of the off-peak nuclear electricity are relevant factors. The alternative use of this energy is to store it by pumping water to an uphill reservoir for later on-peak generation. It is shown that hydrogen production does not compete with storage for the use of off-peak nuclear electricity until the price of coal, in real terms, doubles from the 1979 value .

Title: Solar energy alternatives ( renewable energy sources).
Source title: Liquid fuels: what can Australia do? Papers of a meeting 1980, (Australian Academy of Sciences, Canberra, Forum Report 17)
Authors with affiliations: Kirkwood, J.B.
Abstract: Describes the use of solar power for heating and cooling, and also discusses wind and water power. storage of power as hydrogen is seen as an attractive possibility. J.Clayton

Title: Latent heat storage
Affiliations: Philips GmbH Forschungslaboratorium Aachen, Weisshausstrasse, Aachen, 5100, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schröder, J., Philips GmbH Forschungslaboratorium Aachen, Weisshausstrasse, Aachen, 5100, Germany; Gawron, K., Philips GmbH Forschungslaboratorium Aachen, Weisshausstrasse, Aachen, 5100, Germany
Abstract: The investigations of materials presumably suitable as storage media for latent heat indicate that water, some salt hydrates and eutectic mixtures of water and salt hydrates possess extreme heats of fusion. Their melting points, ranging from about ‐50° to + 130°C, fit well for storing low grade heat in residential energy systems. Detailed experimental investigations on a large number of these media show, however, that only a few of them satisfy the quality requirments for practical application in storage units. Flexible flat‐plate storage containers especially developed for selected salt hydrates which expand on melting also show satisfactory performance over long periods of operation. In the case of water and selected water‐salt hydrate eutectics the volume increases on solidification, and the expansion of solid storage material, being very inhomgeneous, breaks even flexible containers after only a few storage cycles. This ruinous local expansion can be avoided, however, by adding a small amount of special, lower melting salt hydrate eutectics which homogenize the crystallization and solidification of the storage medium. Copyright © 1981 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Latent heat energy storage
Index Keywords: Energy storage.; Latent heat energy storage; SALTS - Energy Storage; WATER - Energy Storage; EUTECTICS; LATENT HEAT STORAGE; SALT HYDRATES; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Energy vs the environment
Source title: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
Affiliations: Bureau of Economics, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, DC 20580, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, T., Bureau of Economics, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, DC 20580, United States
Abstract: Optimal development programs that explicitly account for the environment impacts of extracting energy resources are analyzed. Possibilities of storing the resources above ground once it has been extracted are examined When environmental disruption results from resource extraction, as in the case of strip mining or drilling for oil, then the socially optimal rates of resource consumption and extraction depend on the type and severity of the environmental impact and on the prospects of storing the resource above ground. © 1981.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY STORAGE; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT; RESOURCE EXTRACTION; ENERGY RESOURCES; energy; environment; prevention; resource management

Title: Electric Vehicle: Energy and Environmental Aspects. [IL VEICOLO ELETTRICO: ASPETTI ENERGETICI E AMBIENTALI.]
Authors with affiliations: Nencioni, Franco
Abstract: The many road-tests carried out in Italy and abroad with the electric vehicles available today show that, within the framework of urban transport, the use of electric vehicles, at their present state of development, offers a considerable advantage as compared with petrol engines, because they can operate with an energy saving, in terms of crude oil, of about 20%. This advantage drops to 10% if consideration is taken of the energy required for making the batteries used during the lifetime of the electric vehicle. If electric road vehicles were to be widely used, based on more intensive use of thermo-electric power stations during the nighttime, this would offer the considerable advantage of doing away with the pollution of internal combustion engines in those very places where the problem of preserving the environment is most acutely felt.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILES - Electric; Energy conservation; Environmental protection; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: Phase separation, charge separation and biogenesis
Affiliations: Yale University New Haven, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morowitz, H.J., Yale University New Haven, CT, United States
Abstract: The current view of bioenergetics postulates transmembrane charge separation as a primary mechanism of energy storage and transformation. Using that bioenergetic view we examine possible methods of photon driven transduction in primordial vesicles. Two possible types of proton pumps are analyzed and a method of anaerobic photophosphorylation is discussed. Using these principles we theorize about the formation of prebiotic photochemical vesicles utilizing the same transmembrane energy conversions characteristic of contemporary cellular systems. © 1981.
Index Keywords: phosphate; anaerobic growth; article; biogenesis; chemistry; energy transfer; photosynthetic phosphorylation; potentiometry; Anaerobiosis; Biogenesis; Chemistry; Energy Transfer; Phosphates; Photophosphorylation; Potentiometry

Title: Computing indoor temperatures in hot climates
Affiliations: Building Research Establishment, Garston, Watford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Harris-Bass, J., Building Research Establishment, Garston, Watford, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; BUILDINGS

Title: General Considerations Regarding Electric Vehicle and Its Problems. [CONSIDERAZIONI GENERALI SUL VEICOLO ELETTRICO E SUI SUOI PROBLEMI.]
Authors with affiliations: Silvestri, Mario
Abstract: After a survey of the electric car development in the past, it is predicted that an energy density of 30-35 Wh/kg, with a lifetime of 300 cycles, will soon be achieved for lead-acid batteries. With such batteries, electric vehicles might give a total distance traveled of about 10,000 km, while, with tubular-plates batteries, which are at present being perfected, a total distance of 20--30,000 km is anticipated. Even with these results the electric vehicle would not surpass the vehicles powered by internal combustion engines. However, it may still be used in towns for carrying goods. With more ambitious batteries, the electric vehicle might be used for public passenger transport in towns.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILES - Electric; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Authors: Rea J.R., Kelsey G.S., Kuo H.C., Kallianidis M.
Title: Development of a solid-state secondary battery system
Affiliations: Laboratory for Physical Science, Duracell International Inc. Formerly named P.R. Mallory, Co. Inc., Nortwestern Industrial Park, Burlington, MA 01803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rea, J.R., Laboratory for Physical Science, Duracell International Inc. Formerly named P.R. Mallory, Co. Inc., Nortwestern Industrial Park, Burlington, MA 01803, United States; Kelsey, G.S., Laboratory for Physical Science, Duracell International Inc. Formerly named P.R. Mallory, Co. Inc., Nortwestern Industrial Park, Burlington, MA 01803, United States; Kuo, H.C., Laboratory for Physical Science, Duracell International Inc. Formerly named P.R. Mallory, Co. Inc., Nortwestern Industrial Park, Burlington, MA 01803, United States; Kallianidis, M., Laboratory for Physical Science, Duracell International Inc. Formerly named P.R. Mallory, Co. Inc., Nortwestern Industrial Park, Burlington, MA 01803, United States
Abstract: Solid-state batteries have features that make them attractive for mobile and stationary energy-storage applications. The use of the LiI (alumina) solid electrolyte at elevated temperatures (≥300°C) makes feasible the development of a high-rate system of this type. Small solid cells composed of a lithium-alloy negative electrode and metal-sulfide-containing positive electrodes were fabricated and galvanostatically cycled between selected cut-off voltages. A cycle life of 300 deep discharge cycles and energy efficiencies as high as 85% have been achieved. Test results also show that the solid cells are higly resistnt to such abuses as thermal cycling, short circuiting and forced discharge. Thus the solid-state lithium battery system is a promising candidate for advanced storage battery application. © 1981.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Sotomura T., Nakai M., Sekido S.
Title: Reaction mechanisms in the Li/LiI/1-n-butylpyridinium polyiodide solid electrolyte cell
Affiliations: Material Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., 1006 Kadoma, Osaka, 571, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sotomura, T., Material Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., 1006 Kadoma, Osaka, 571, Japan; Nakai, M., Material Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., 1006 Kadoma, Osaka, 571, Japan; Sekido, S., Material Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., 1006 Kadoma, Osaka, 571, Japan
Abstract: A Li/(BPIa+SiO2 gel) cell, in which BPIa represents the 1-n-butylpyridinium polyiodide charge-transfer complex, has been investigated by measuring internal cell resistances (Ri) and the self-discharge capacities (Qs) estimated from the chemical analysis of the cathode mixtures. The activation energy as determined from the temperature dependence of Ri is for ionic conduction in the solid electrolytes. It is 12 kcal/mol and maintains a nearly constant value during the storage period. However, the value is reduced to 7-8 kcal/mol after the initiation of cell discharge. The value of Qcs followed the parabolic law after the initial storage period up to ≈50 days at 20°C, i.e. Qs (mA h/cm2 of Li anode)=4.3+0.034 t 1 2 (t in hours). The above iodine losses during storage are decreased by a preliminary discharge of more than 2 mA h/cm2, immediately after constructing the cell. © 1981.
Index Keywords: ELECTROLYTIC CELLS

Title: Short-term Operation Planning in Electric Power Systems
Source title: Journal of the Operational Research Society
Affiliations: Brown Boveri and Co. Ltd, Baden, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Lajda, P., Brown Boveri and Co. Ltd, Baden, Switzerland
Abstract: A practical application of operational research methods is shown here for the short-term operation planning in an electric power system. Two interactive application programs are presented: a short-term load forecasting program and a unit commitment optimisation program.
