For the load prediction within the load forecasting program a four-component weather dependent load model is used, whereby for the weather-dependent load component an econometric model, and for the time-dependent load component a seasonal multiplicative ARIMA-model is applied. The unit commitment is optimized using dynamic programming. With this method the start-up and shut-down costs can easily be taken into consideration. Special features are necessary to allow the optimal scheduling of a large number of generators to minimize storage requirements and execution time of the program. For every cost-optimal unit commitment determined the reliability of the energy supply is then calculated. The success of the application software depends to a large extent on the man-machine interface. Special attention has to be paid to the man-machine dialogue. The dialogue has to be structured in such a way that the user has the facility to control the programs as easily as possible. All input data has to be checked and in case of a false input an error message has to be displayed and a new input requested. The data-base has to be protected against wrong actions. © 1981 Operational Research Society Ltd.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Time resolved spectroscopy using synchrotron radiation
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Rice University, Houston, Texas 77001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walters, G.K., Department of Physics, Rice University, Houston, Texas 77001, United States; Bonifield, T.D., Department of Physics, Rice University, Houston, Texas 77001, United States
Abstract: The time structure of synchrotron radiation from a single bunch of high-energy electrons circulating in a storage ring is readily exploited for studies of fast kinetic and radiative processes involving short lived electronically-excited species in bulk matter. The sample is excited repetitively by very short bursts of monochromatized synchrotron radiation once each orbital period, as the radiation pattern associated with the radially accelerating electron bunch sweeps past an entrance aperture. Time resolved measurements of the rise and fall of features in the afterglow fluorescence spectrum are analyzed to yield rates for the formation and decay of the radiating species. Copyright © 1981 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Inc.
Index Keywords: SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; SPECTROSCOPY, ULTRAVIOLET

Title: Potential nuclear safeguards applications for neutron generators
Affiliations: International Safeguards Group (Q-5), Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lindquist, L.O., International Safeguards Group (Q-5), Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico, United States
Abstract: Many nuclear safeguards inspection instruments use neutron sources to interrogate the fissile material (commonly 235U and 239Pu) to be measured. The neutron sources currently used in these instruments are isotopics such as Californium-252, Americium—Lithium etc. It is becoming increasingly more difficult to transport isotopic sources from one measurement location to another. This represents a significant problem for the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards inspectors because they must take their safeguards instruments with them to each nuclear installation to make an independent measurement. The purpose of this paper is to review the possibility of replacing isotopic neutron sources now used in IAEA safeguards instruments with electric neutron sources such as deuterium-tritium (D-T, 14-MeV neutrons) or deuterium-deuterium (D-D, 2-MeV neutrons). The potential for neutron generators to interrogate spent-light water reactor fuel assemblies in storage pools is also reviewed. Copyright © 1981 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Inc.
Index Keywords: NEUTRONS

Title: NBS-SURF II: A small, versatile synchrotron light source
Affiliations: Center for Radiation Research, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rakowsky, G., Center for Radiation Research, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation sources do not have to be large multi-megadollar installations. SURF II is based on a compact electron storage ring with a radius of only 0.84 m, an operating energy of 250 MeV, and useful light output down to 5 nm. Small beam size, high brightness and wide-angle light ports give SURF II unique capabilities. Presently five beamlines are instrumented and operational, supporting experiments in atomic and molecular physics, surface science and materials studies, as well as providing optical calibration services. Nearing completion is a large facility for calibrating optical instruments, especially those intended for space flight. The capability of determining the absolute light flux emitted by SURF II has recently been improved and is now operational. The technique employs ultra-linear silicon photodiodes to detect and count individual electrons in the stored beam. Other user conveniences include close access to the machine, flexible scheduling and close interaction with the operations staff. The machine's simplicity contributes to reliability and a high ratio of beamtime to down-time. Copyright © 1981 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Inc.
Index Keywords: LIGHT SOURCES; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Dran J.C., Langevin Y., Maurette M., Petit J.C., Vassent B.
Title: Ion implantation effects in insulators and the long-term stability of radioactive waste storage materials
Affiliations: Laboratoire René Bernas, Orsay-Campus, France
Authors with affiliations: Dran, J.C., Laboratoire René Bernas, Orsay-Campus, France; Langevin, Y., Laboratoire René Bernas, Orsay-Campus, France; Maurette, M., Laboratoire René Bernas, Orsay-Campus, France; Petit, J.C., Laboratoire René Bernas, Orsay-Campus, France; Vassent, B., Laboratoire René Bernas, Orsay-Campus, France
Abstract: Most insulator materials so far proposed for storing high-level radioactive wastes, such as glass and and the constituent minerals of ceramics are nuclear track detectors. Lead ion implantation experiments show that such materials should be transformed into "giant" nuclear tracks, when the internal fluence of heavy recoils emitted during the α-decay of actinide elements stored in them exceeds a critical value, which corresponds to an equivalent storage period of a few thousand years for the wastes expected from a pressurized water reactor. In contrast, actinide bearing minerals are much more stable against α-recoil damage. As nuclear tracks are extremely chemical reactive, α-recoil damage is expected to shorten the lifetime of storage materials such as glass and ceramics against dissolution in ground waters. Fortunately new nuclear track concepts are already yielding guidelines for predicting and improving the long-term stability of storage materials. The results of the present studies also bear on the physics of ion implantation phenomena an insulator targets exposed to high fluences of low energy ions. © 1981.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Radioactive Materials; INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Radioactive Materials; DIELECTRIC MATERIALS; Dielectric materials

Title: Trends in mass storage technology and possible impacts on high energy physics experiments
Affiliations: CERN, 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Williams, D.O., CERN, 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
Abstract: The reasons for the wide-spread use of magnetic tapes to record data from high energy physics experiments are analysed. Problems due to the sequential nature of the medium and to the large amount of human intervention required are discussed. It is suggested that a high capacity removable disk might resolve these problems. An analysis of track-to-track spacing in magnetic recording shows that multi-track tape is unlikely to be of major interest. A discussion of helical recording shows that the proposed Ampex Super High Bit Rate Recorder might allow for extremely high data rates at future general-purpose facilities. A review of optical disk recording shows that it has great potential for physics data recording. Several areas needing careful attention to product design are indicated. Holographic tape storage is briefly reviewed. © 1981.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL - Storage Devices; PHYSICS - High Energy; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Authors: Mueller J.J., Bechis D., Chang G.K., Imlay R., Potter D., Sannes F., Skubic P., Stone R.
Title: The cleo photon shower detector
Affiliations: Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Louisiana State University, Boton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mueller, J.J., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Bechis, D., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Chang, G.K., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Imlay, R., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Potter, D., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Sannes, F., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Skubic, P., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Stone, R., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Abstract: We describe an electromagnetic shower detector which measures photon energies and positions, and provides charged particle tracking over a solid angle of 50% of 4πin the CLEO magnetic detector at the Cornell Electron Storage Ring. The detector is segmented into octants, each made of interleaved layers of proportional tubes and lead. The performance of the detector in an electron test beam and in initial e+e- annihilation experiments is discussed. Copyright © 1981 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: PARTICLE DETECTORS

Authors: de Waal V.J., Van den Hamer P., Mooij J.E., Klapwijk T.M.
Title: Very low noise all-niobium DC squids
Affiliations: Laboratorium voor Technische Natuurkunde Lorentzweg 1, 2628 CJ Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: de Waal, V.J., Laboratorium voor Technische Natuurkunde Lorentzweg 1, 2628 CJ Delft, Netherlands; Van den Hamer, P., Laboratorium voor Technische Natuurkunde Lorentzweg 1, 2628 CJ Delft, Netherlands; Mooij, J.E., Laboratorium voor Technische Natuurkunde Lorentzweg 1, 2628 CJ Delft, Netherlands; Klapwijk, T.M., Laboratorium voor Technische Natuurkunde Lorentzweg 1, 2628 CJ Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: All-niobium thin film planar DC SQUIDs have been fabricated, containing submicron tunnel junctions. The fabrication method using photoresist techniques is briefly described. The I R product of the SQUIDs is 0.3 mV, the inductance 1 nH. They show no changes after repeated thermal cycling or storage over extended periods. The best intrinsic energy resolution obtained so far in a flux-locked loop configuration is -32 4. 10-32 J/Hz. The noise power is an order of magnitude higher than predicted from the simple RSJ model calculation. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: DC SQUIDS; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES

Authors: Shintomi T., Masuda M., Eyssa Y.M., Boom R.W.
Title: Construction of a model magnet for shielded pulsed energy storage
Affiliations: National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Ibaraki, Japan; University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shintomi, T., National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Ibaraki, Japan; Masuda, M., National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Ibaraki, Japan; Eyssa, Y.M., University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, United States; Boom, R.W., University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: The first model magnet system of the shielded pulsed superconductive energy storage was designed and constructed to test the shielding effect. The capacity is 200 kJ. The superconductive coil was designed as a usual dc magnet. The rated current was decided as 1,350 A not to be large heat leak through power leads. The shield coil was divided into 12 blocks which were wound in a. solenoid type. These blocks were distributed in optimum distribution not to generate magnetic field on the superconductive coil. This enables the construction of such small scaled shield coil. The system is designed to be able to generate energy of 250 kJ in the duty factor of 0.2 %. The field was measured and well agreed with the calculated one. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Title: Superconductive energy storage for diurnal use by electric utilities
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin, Madison Wisconsin 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boom, R.W., University of Wisconsin, Madison Wisconsin 53706, United States
Abstract: A summary report of a five-year study of superconductive energy storage for electric utility systems is presented. Conceptual designs over that period have all been for one layer solenoids of aluminum-NbTi composite conductors cooled to 1.8 K in superfluid helium. The solenoids are mounted underground in bedrock in one or more tunnels. The two preferred designs in 1980 are: a 15 tunnel solenoid arranged in a circular pattern and a large radius single tunnel solenoid. The electrical energy storage efficiency in all cases is 95 to 96%. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: SOLENOIDS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Applications; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Title: Magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rogers, J.D., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: Magnetic energy storage has become the foundation for near time and longer range electric utility applications and for current induction in the plasma of fusion devices. The fusion program embraces low loss superconductor strand development with integration into cables capable of carrying 50 kA in pulsed mode at high fields. This evolvement has been paralleled with pulsed energy storage coil development and testing from tens of kj at low fields to a 20 MJ prototype tokamak induction coil at 7.5 T. Energy transfer times have ranged from 0.7 ms to several seconds. Electric utility magnetic storage for prospective application is for diurnal load leveling with massive systems to store 10 GWh at 1.8 K in a dewar structure suported on bedrock underground. An immediate utility application is a 30 MJ system to be used to damp power oscillations on the Bonneville Power Administration electric transmission lines. An off-shoot of this last work is a new program for electric utility VAR control with the potential for use to suppress subsynchronous resonance. Pulsed magnetic energy storage is not a widely developed technology. Current work is done almost exclusively in Japan and the United States. This paper does not cover past work or completed studies but presents work in progress, work planned, and recently completed unusual work. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC DEVICES - Applications; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Applications; MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Isabelle – a progress report
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, H., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the ISABELLE project, which has the objective of constructing a high-energy proton colliding beam facility at Brookhaven National Laboratory. The major technical features of the intersecting storage accelerators with their projected performance are described. Application of over 1000 superconducting magnets in the two rings represents the salient characteristic of the machine. The status of the entire project, the technical progress made so far, and difficulties encountered are reviewed. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS; ISABELLE PROJECT; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Schemer R.I., Boenig H.J., Henke M., Turner R.D., Schramm R.
Title: Conductor qualification tests for the 30-MJ bonneville power administration smes coil
Affiliations: Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; National Bureau of Standards, Boulder, CO 80303, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schemer, R.I., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Boenig, H.J., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Henke, M., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Turner, R.D., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Schramm, R., National Bureau of Standards, Boulder, CO 80303, United States
Abstract: The 30-MJ energy storage coil for the Bonneville Power Administration requires a low-loss, cryostable conductor that is able to carry 4.9 kA in a field of 2.8 T and will maintain its properties over 108 partial discharge cycles. The multi-level cable which satisfies these requirements has been extensively tested at various stages in its development and in its final form. Tests have been performed to determine the effect of manufacturing options on ac losses, low temperature electrical resistivity, stability, and fatigue resistance of the insulated conductor. This paper will concentrate on the stability and fatigue tests which have not previously been reported. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Title: An evaluation of superconducting magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Arthur D. Little, Inc., Cambridge, MA 02140, United States
Authors with affiliations: Winer, B.M., Arthur D. Little, Inc., Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Nicol, J., Arthur D. Little, Inc., Cambridge, MA 02140, United States
Abstract: A Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) system will accept and regenerate ac electrical energy very efficiently. It can therefore compete economically with alternative advanced storage technologies if (1) the unit's cost and efficiency are within the presently expected ranges; and (2) the unit is sized so as to perform the same task as the alternatives and no more. Present conceptual SMES designs are unlikely to meet the electric utilities’ needs for reliability, maintainability and system protection; and the environmental impact of the magnetic field may be large. Consequently, the uncertainties associated with the costs of an acceptable SMES system are large. Their reduction should be the principal goal of future component and system research. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC DEVICES - Applications; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Applications; MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Murakami Y., Okada T., Yamamoto J., Inuishi Y., Mitsuishi A., Nishimura M.
Title: 0.5 MJ superconducting pulse magnet for energy storage
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Osaka University, 565 Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Murakami, Y., Faculty of Engineering, Osaka University, 565 Suita, Japan; Okada, T., Faculty of Engineering, Osaka University, 565 Suita, Japan; Yamamoto, J., Faculty of Engineering, Osaka University, 565 Suita, Japan; Inuishi, Y., Faculty of Engineering, Osaka University, 565 Suita, Japan; Mitsuishi, A., Faculty of Engineering, Osaka University, 565 Suita, Japan; Nishimura, M., Faculty of Engineering, Osaka University, 565 Suita, Japan
Abstract: Laboratory for Applied Superconductivity was started in FY 1980 in Osaka University. The main objectives of laboratory are to develop the basics of the technology of superconducting magnet; superconducting material, control system, and energy application of superconducting magnet such as energy storage. The system of pulsed superconducting coil is the main facility of the laboratory. The specifications of the magnet are; I.D.: 30 cm, O.D.: 49 cm, Height: 25.5 cm, Stored energy: 515 KJ, Central field: 5T, dB/dt: 5 ∼ 7 T/s. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Title: Considerations of a large force balanced magnetic energy storage system
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin Madison, Wisconsin 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eyssa, Y.M., University of Wisconsin Madison, Wisconsin 53706, United States; Boom, R.W., University of Wisconsin Madison, Wisconsin 53706, United States
Abstract: We show in this paper that any generalized toroid-dipole force balancing system will require a minimum unidirectionally stressed structure e-qual to the minimum amount required by the virial theorem. 1.2.3 The analytical proof is general and independent of configuration, current distribution, and the fraction of energy stored in the poloidal and toroidal fields. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Authors: Hoffmann E., Alcorn J., Chen W., Hsu Y.-H., Purcell J., Schermer R.
Title: Design of the bpa superconducting 30 MJ energy storage coil
Affiliations: General Atomic Company, P.O. Box 81608, San Diego, California 92138, United States; Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoffmann, E., General Atomic Company, P.O. Box 81608, San Diego, California 92138, United States; Alcorn, J., General Atomic Company, P.O. Box 81608, San Diego, California 92138, United States; Chen, W., General Atomic Company, P.O. Box 81608, San Diego, California 92138, United States; Hsu, Y.-H., General Atomic Company, P.O. Box 81608, San Diego, California 92138, United States; Purcell, J., General Atomic Company, P.O. Box 81608, San Diego, California 92138, United States; Schermer, R., General Atomic Company, P.O. Box 81608, San Diego, California 92138, United States, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, United States
Abstract: The design of a superconducting magnetic energy storage coil is presented. The purpose of this coil is to stabilize low frequency power oscillations in long high voltage ac power lines. The practical application for this specific coil will be the installation in the Pacific intertie between Washington State and Los Angeles, California. The guiding principles of the design are performance, fabrication economy and reliability. © 1981 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC COILS; SUPERCONDUCTING CABLES - Energy Storage; SUPERCONDUCTING COILS; ELECTRIC LINES

Authors: Ralston J., Van Vliet T., Lyklema J.
Title: Inference on ion binding to polyelectrolytes from emulsion rheology
Source title: Journal of Colloid And Interface Science
Affiliations: Laboratory for Physical and Colloid Chemistry, Agricultural University, De Dreijen 6, 6703 BC Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Ralston, J., Laboratory for Physical and Colloid Chemistry, Agricultural University, De Dreijen 6, 6703 BC Wageningen, Netherlands; Van Vliet, T., Laboratory for Physical and Colloid Chemistry, Agricultural University, De Dreijen 6, 6703 BC Wageningen, Netherlands; Lyklema, J., Laboratory for Physical and Colloid Chemistry, Agricultural University, De Dreijen 6, 6703 BC Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: Extending a previously developed technique, we studied the rheological properties of paraffin oil in water emulsions, stabilized by partially esterified polymethacrylic acid (PMA-pe) in the presence of NaI, CaII, CdII, MnII, CuII, and NiII. In addition, the conformational transition of PMA-pe as a function of pH in the presence of these ions was studied potentiometrically. The formation of cation bridges between PMA-pe molecules adsorbed on different particles leads to high storage moduli, which are found at low α for CdII and at intermediate a for the other divalent cations. The binding strength of the cation and the polyelectrolyte increases in the order NaI < CaII < MnII < NiII < CdII. Screening of the charges is dominated by the valence of the counterions and not significantly by their nature. The Gibbs energy of the conformational transition is insensitive to the valence and nature of the cation. © 1981.

Authors: Rillema D.P., Nagle J.K., Barringer L.F., Jr., Meyer T.J.
Title: Redox Properties of Metalloporphyrin Excited States, Lifetimes, and Related Properties of a Series of Para-Substituted Tetraphenylporphine Carbonyl Complexes of Ruthenium(II)
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society
Affiliations: Departments of Chemistry, The University of North Carolina, Charlotte, North Carolina 28223, United States; Departments of Chemistry, The University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27514, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rillema, D.P., Departments of Chemistry, The University of North Carolina, Charlotte, North Carolina 28223, United States; Nagle, J.K., Departments of Chemistry, The University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27514, United States; Barringer, L.F., Jr., Departments of Chemistry, The University of North Carolina, Charlotte, North Carolina 28223, United States; Meyer, T.J., Departments of Chemistry, The University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27514, United States
Abstract: Excited-state and redox properties of Ru(p-XTPP)(CO), X = MeO, Me, H, F, Cl, H and Br, have been defined. Emission bands were centered at 730 ± 3 nm and excited-state lifetimes were in the range of 30 ± 10µs. Two one-electron oxidations in CH2Cl2 ranged from 0.74 to 0.86 V for the first step and from 1.18 to 1.27 V for the second one. A one-electron reduction process in (CH3)2SO ranged from -1.35 to -1.24 V. Excited-state lifetimes and redox potentials exhibit a weak dependence on the Hammett function. In general, redox potentials increase as the electron-withdrawing power of the substituents increases, whereas excited-state lifetimes decrease. The first oxidation step (0.74-0.86 V) and the reduction step are, respectively, assigned to π-electron removal or acceptance by the porphyrin ring. The second oxidation is assigned to removal of an electron from the ruthenium(II) center. The excited state is shown to be the (π- π*) state of the porphyrin ring and to exhibit photoredox behavior involving both oxidative and reductive quenching. Redox product separation occurred in flash photolysis quenching experiments and back-reactions took place at near-diffusion-controlled rates. The redox potential of the Ru(TPP)(CO)+/* couple was estimated from emission and redox data to be -0.57 ± 0.03 V; it was determined from oxidative quenching studies to be -0.56 ± 0.10 V. Comparison to the excited-state properties of Ru(bpy)3 2+ is made, and the utility of porphyrin complexes as potential solar energy storage catalysts is examined. © 1981, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Method for calculating wave functions in a nonspherical potential
Affiliations: IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Janak, J.F., IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Williams, A.R., IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: A new method is described for the solution of the single-particle Schrödinger equation in which the potential is nonspherical. This method is more efficient than methods based on spherical-harmonic expansions, both in terms of computer time and storage. The method is distinguished by the use of a "ray" representation in which (a) the potential is diagonal, (b) the nondiagonal portion of the Laplacian is small, and (c) boundary conditions are easily imposed. Illustrative applications to the orbital and total energies of free atoms are described. © 1981 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Takahashi Y., Sakamoto R., Kamimoto M., Kanari K., Ozawa T.
Title: Investigation of latent heat-thermal energy storage materials. I. Thermoanalytical evaluation of modified polyethylene
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sakamoto, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kanari, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Ozawa, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: Differential scanning calorimetry is used to evaluate polyethylene for latent heat-thermal energy storage. Polyethylene is a suitable material from the points of view of latent heat, behavior of melting and crystallization, and material cost. The thermal stability is satisfactory when it is used in a closed system with heat transfer media, such as silicone oil, alkyldiphenyl, alkyldiphenylethane, Caloria HT and ethylene glycol, which shield polyethylene from air. Surface-crosslinking by ion bombardment prevents polyethylene from mutual adhesion and it retains its form after melting. Surface-crosslinked polyethylene with silicone oil or ethylene glycol is the most promising, while the heat transfer media, such as alkyldiphenyl, alkyldiphenylethane and Caloria HT, which dissolve polyethylene, decrease the melting point, but have little effect on the latent heat and sharp DSC peaks of melting and crystallization. Thus, the composite of polyethylene with these media can also be used at an adjusted and desirable operating temperature. © 1981.

Authors: Bulow F.J., Zeman M.E., Winningham J.R., Hudson W.F.
Title: Seasonal variations in RNA–DNA ratios and in indicators of feeding, reproduction, energy storage, and condition in a population of bluegill, Lepomis macrochirus Rafinesque
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, Tennessee, 38501, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bulow, F.J., Department of Biology, Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, Tennessee, 38501, United States; Zeman, M.E., Department of Biology, Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, Tennessee, 38501, United States; Winningham, J.R., Department of Biology, Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, Tennessee, 38501, United States; Hudson, W.F., Department of Biology, Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, Tennessee, 38501, United States
Abstract: Liver and epaxial muscle RNA concentrations and RNA‐DNA ratios (RNA/DNA) of bluegill Lepomis macrochirus from a central Tennessee lake were maximum in the spring, low during the summer, high again in the fall, and low during the winter. Liver‐somatic indexes and DNA concentrations indicated that liver cell volume and energy storage varied seasonally and were lowest during late spring and summer. Seasonal variations in gonosomatic indexes were typical of this species, and RNA/DNA decreased as gonads matured during the spring. RNA/DNA and energy storage in the liver decreased during the major spawning season. Seasonal variations in food consumption may have effected seasonal growth and energy storage. However, a summer depression in RNA/DNA may have been more closely associated with the effects of thermal stratification and dissolved oxygen stress. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Determination of adenine nucleotide levels and adenylate energy charge ratio in two Spartina species
Affiliations: Laboratory for Wetland Soils and Sediments, Center for Wetland Resources, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mendelssohn, I.A., Laboratory for Wetland Soils and Sediments, Center for Wetland Resources, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; McKee, K.L., Laboratory for Wetland Soils and Sediments, Center for Wetland Resources, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Abstract: A method was developed for measuring adenine nucleotide levels in vascular plant tissue and the use of the adenylate energy charge (EC) ratio as a monitor of environmental stress in coastal plant communities. This method, which utilizes bioluminescence resulting from the reaction of ATP with the luciferin-luciferase substrate-enzyme complex, was found to be sensitive, reproducible and suitable for field sampling. Extraction of the adenylates from feeeze-dried tissue in boiling 1 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid plus 5% polyvinylpolypyrrolidone solution yielded the highest ATP levels and recovery rates (98, 97 and 89% of added ATP, ADP and AMP, respectively) of the extraction solutions and extractant modifications tested. Sources of variation due to sampling, storage of tissue, extraction and analysis of the adenine nucleotides, and natural changes in the environment were examined in two ecologically important salt-marsh macrophytes, Spartina alterniflora Loisel. and Spartina patens (Aiton) Muhl. Also, the relatively greater stress associated with low-productivity inland Spartina marshes compared to high-productivity streamside sites was correctly delineated by the EC ratio methodology. © 1981.

Authors: Ouain D.E., Thurston P.A., Tubb R.S.
Title: THE STRUCTURAL AND STORAGE CARBOHYDRATES OF SACCHAROMYCES CEREVISIAE: CHANGES DURING FERMENTATION OF WORT AND A ROLE FOR GLYCOGEN CATABOLISM IN LIPID BIOSYNTHESIS
Source title: Journal of the Institute of Brewing
Affiliations: Brewing Research Foundation, Nutfield, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ouain, D.E., Brewing Research Foundation, Nutfield, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom; Thurston, P.A., Brewing Research Foundation, Nutfield, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom; Tubb, R.S., Brewing Research Foundation, Nutfield, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom
Abstract: Detailed analysis of the structural and storage carbohydrates of Saccharomyces cerevisiae (NCYC 240) during wort fermentation showed that there were no significant changes in the amounts of trehalose or alkali‐soluble glycogen. However, glucan and mannan individually increased from ca4% of the yeast dry weight at pitching to ca6% during the first 3–17 h of fermentation, butthen declined to the former level. In the first 2 h of fermentation, prior to yeast multiplication, acid‐soluble glycogen was rapidly dissimilated from ca 40% to ca 6% of the yeast dry weight. During this period of oxygen uptake, wort sugars were not removed by the yeast. Glycogen, therefore, was the sole source of metabolic energy for lipid resynthesis and hexose transport appeared to require the formation of a component membrane. During the latter phase of fermentation when the yeast was not growing but expending energy for maintenance of cellular functions, glycogen reserves were slowly depleted; after a period of prolonged anaerobic storage, the content of glycogen fell well below that which was initially present in the pitching yeast. 1981 The Institute of Brewing & Distilling
Author Keywords: glucose; glycogen; lipid; oxygen; Saccharomyces cerevisiαe; transport

Title: A cluster algorithm for the study of jets in high energy physics
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik C Particles and Fields
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dorfan, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States
Abstract: A cluster algorithm using angular correlations and leading particle effects is presented which is applicable to the study of jets produced in high energy storage ring collisions. The algorithm uses the concept of a minimal spanning tree and is computationally very efficient. Events are classified by their cluster number and the cluster number frequency distribution can be used for comparison with particle production models. Individual particles are assigned to the clusters and the vector sum of their momenta generate a cluster axis. These cluster properties permit the study of the dynamics of the jet production and fragmentation processes. The example of two and three jet production at PEP and PETRA energies is used to illustrate this technique. © 1981 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Caldwell R.A., Mizuno K., Hansen P.E., Vo L.P., Frentrup M., Ho C.D.
Title: Photochemistry of the Phenanthrene-Stilbene System. Cycloaddition and Singlet-Sensitized Isomerization
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society
Affiliations: Chemistry Program, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080, United States
Authors with affiliations: Caldwell, R.A., Chemistry Program, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080, United States; Mizuno, K., Chemistry Program, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080, United States; Hansen, P.E., Chemistry Program, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080, United States; Vo, L.P., Chemistry Program, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080, United States; Frentrup, M., Chemistry Program, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080, United States; Ho, C.D., Chemistry Program, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080, United States
Abstract: Photocycloaddition of phenanthrenes to stilbenes is a general and remarkably facile reaction. Two isomeric trans adducts often result with unsymmetrical phenanthrenes. The product with cis-stilbene and 9-cyanophenanthrene is the crowded cis, endo isomer. With 9-cyanophenanthrene and trans-stilbene, geometric isomerization occurs but only in a triplet process. With cw-stilbene, geometric isomerization results from the triplet, and both geometric and valence isomerizations can be induced by singlet 9-cyanophenanthrene. The reactivity of the stilbene isomers can be accounted for by an algorithm we have previously derived, as can the 20- to 30-fold enhancement of stilbenes over styrenes as a reactant in cycloadditions to phenanthrene. The possibility of singlet-sensitized valence isomerization as a mechanism for storage of solar energy is discussed. © 1981, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Enhanced heat conduction in phase-change thermal energy storage devices
Source title: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Henze, R.H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Humphrey, J.A.C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: Phase-change energy storage devices have an inherent disadvantage due to the insulating properties of the phase-change materials (PCM's) used. Such systems are difficult to analyze theoretically due to the nonlinearities of the moving liquid-solid interface and the presence of natural convection as shown by several recent numerical and experimental investigations. Previous work has been unsuccessful in predicting the performance of phase-change devices in the presence of fins and natural convection. This study presents a simplified numerical model based on a quasi-linear, transient, thin fin equation, which predicts the fraction of melted PCM, and the shape of the liquid-solid interface as a function of time with sufficient accuracy for engineering purposes. Experimental results are compared in dimensionless form with model predictions, and show fairly good agreement. To achieve high heat-transfer rates with a fixed amount of PCM and metal fin material, the model indicates that melting the PCM in a pure conduction mode with closely spaced thin fins is preferable to melting PCM with thicker fins spread further apart, even in the presence of natural convection. © 1981.

Authors: Willson R.C., Gulkis S., Janssen M., Hudson H.S., Chapman G.A.
Title: Observations of solar irradiance variability
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena 91103; Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences, University of California, San Diego 92093; San Fernando Observatory, California State University, Northridge 91330
Authors with affiliations: Willson, R.C., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena 91103; Gulkis, S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena 91103; Janssen, M., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena 91103; Hudson, H.S., Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences, University of California, San Diego 92093; Chapman, G.A., San Fernando Observatory, California State University, Northridge 91330
Abstract: High-precision measurements of total solar irradiance, made by the active cavity radiometer irradiance monitor on the Solar Maximum Mission satellite, show the irradiance to have been variable throughout the first 153 days of observations. The corrected data resolve orbit-to-orbit variations with uncertainties as small as 0.001 percent. Irradiance fluctuations are typical of a band-limited noise spectrum with high-frequency cutoff near 0.15 day -1; their amplitudes about the mean value of 1368.31 watts per square meter approach ±0.05 percent. Two large decreases in irradiance of up to 0.2 percent lasting about 1 week are highly correlated with the development of sunspot groups. The magnitude and time scale of the irradiance variability suggest that considerable energy storage occurs within the convection zone in solar active regions. Copyright © 1981 AAAS.

Authors: Delwiche J., Hubin-Franskin M.-J., Guyon P.-M., Nenner I.
Title: Autoionization of OCS by threshold photoelectron spectroscopy
Affiliations: LURE, Batiment 209C, Université de Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Institut de Chimie, Bâtiment B. 6, Université de Liège, Sart-Tilman par 4000 Liege I, Belgium; Laboratoire des Collisions Atomiques et Moléculaires, Université de Paris-Sud, Orsay, France; C. E. N. Saclay, Département de Physicochimie, Service de Photophysique et de Photochimie, B. P. 2, 91190 Gif-sur-Yvette, France
Abstract: Autoionization of carbonyl sulfide between 12 and 16 eV has been investigated by photoionization using the pulsed synchrotron radiation from ACO Orsay's storage ring. The threshold photoelectron spectrum and the total photoionization spectrum of carbonyl sulfide have been recorded at high resolution in the wavelength range between 112.0 and 65.0 nm (11-19 eV). Threshold energy electrons are observed in specific wavelength regions: (i) at excitation energies where the X̃, Ã, B̃, and C̃ ionic states are formed by a direct process; (ii) in the Ã state region where resonant autoionization to Ã can be understood classically within the Franck-Condon approximation; (iii) in the Ã-X̃ Franck-Condon gap between 90 and 110 nm, where resonant autoionization leads to very sharp electron energy distribution strongly peaked at zero energy. Here the mechanism must be more complex. © 1981 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Maruyama K., Terada K., Yamamoto Y.
Title: Exploitation of Solar Energy Storage Systems. Valence Isomerization between Norbornadiene and Quadricyclane Derivatives
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Maruyama, K., Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606, Japan; Terada, K., Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606, Japan; Yamamoto, Y., Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606, Japan
Abstract: Use of copper(I)-nitrogen ligand catalysts such as Ph3PCuCl-bpy (3), Ph3PCuCl-phen (4), Ph3PCuCl'phtha (5), and Ph3PCuBr.py (6) enables the photochemical isomerization of norbornadiene to quadricyclane to be performed at a longer wavelength than 350 nm, at which CuCl catalyst itself cannot induce such an isomerization. Among the norbornadiene derivatives bearing various chromophores, 3-(phenylcarbamoyl)norbornadiene-2- carboxylic acid (1f) undergoes a facile and quantitative isomerization into the corresponding quadricyclane derivative (2f) in sunlight. The back-isomerization of 2f to If proceeds quantitatively by use of catalytic amounts of Rh2(CO)4Cl2. © 1981, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Protein bodies in seeds
Affiliations: Depr of Biology, McMaster Univ, Hamilton, Ontario, L8S 4K1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Lott, J.N.A., Depr of Biology, McMaster Univ, Hamilton, Ontario, L8S 4K1, Canada
Abstract: Membrane bound protein bodies (aleurone grains) are thought to be the main subcellular location of protein and mineral storage in seeds. In addition to structurally homogeneous proteinaceous matrix, protein bodies may contain protein crystalloids, electron–dense globoid crystals, electron–transparent soft globoids, and crystals of calcium oxalate. Protein crystalloids vary in shape, size and number. For example, cotyledon mesophyll cell protein bodies in the Cucurbitaceae generally contain protein crystalloids whereas those of Compositae and Cruciferae do not. Globoid crystals, which are rich in phytin, vary greatly in size and number per protein body. Some species have numerous small globoid crystals per protein body whereas others have one or two large globoid crystals per protein body. Phosphorus and various cations (K, Mg, Ca, Fe, Ba, Mn) located in globoid crystals can be studied with an energy dispersive X–ray (EDX) analysis system mounted on a transmission electron microscope. In some cases, cations such as Ca, Mn and Fe are specifically localized in globoid crystals of certain tissues or embryo regions. Further investigations may allow elemental composition of globoid crystals to be used in studies of systematics. Biref–ringent crystals, sometimes in the form of single large crystals but frequently in the form of druses, are present in protein bodies of some species. At least some endosperm protein bodies of all Umbelliferous species examined contain druse crystals. While seed protein bodies of relatively few species have been studied with electron microscopy, there are indications that protein bodies could be a useful character for studies in plant systematics. Copyright © 1981, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Transfer and storage of vibrational energy in liquids: Liquid carbon monoxide and its solutions with argon
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chandler, D.W., Department of Chemistry, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Ewing, G.E., Department of Chemistry, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Abstract: Liquid carbon monoxide and its solutions with argon in a five order of magnitude concentration range were vibrationally excited by pumping with a blackbody source. Infrared fluorescence decay from the excited carbon monoxide was used to explore the storage and transfer of vibrational energy in this system. In the limit of the infinitely dilute solution the storage time, 18 ms, is determined by IR spontaneous emission. For concentrations in the range 0.01-1 mole % this radiation tends to be trapped by CO self-absorption and the lifetime of the vibrational excitation lengthens. We apply a simple model to interpret this lifetime behavior. Neat carbon monoxide stores vibrational energy for 1 s. Here radiation trapping is so effective that vibrational energy is lost essentially by non-radiative processes. The 1 s lifetime allows a useful limit to be placed on the vibration to translation and rotation rate of relaxation of excited CO by its neighbors. © 1981.

Title: Photosensitivity enhancement by H- and He-ion implantation in lead lanthanum zirconate titanate ceramics
Affiliations: Sandia Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Land, C.E., Sandia Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Peercy, P.S., Sandia Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Abstract: H- and He-ion implantation has been used to increase the photoferroelectric image storage sensitivity of lead lanthanum zirconium titanate ceramics by factors of ∼10 and ∼30, respectively. The increased photosensitivity can be attributed primarily to implantation-produced disorder, which increases the efficiency of carrier photoexcitation and trapping and reduces the exposure energy required to establish nonvolatile space-charge fields. Implantation-induced disorder may also contribute to a substantial increase in photoconductivity in the ion-damaged near-surface region.

Title: Mechanisms of charge separation at the photosynthetic reaction centre
Affiliations: Institute of Electrochemistry, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Organic Semi-Products and Dye Research Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Vorotyntsev, M.A., Institute of Electrochemistry, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation, Organic Semi-Products and Dye Research Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Itskovich, E.M., Institute of Electrochemistry, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation, Organic Semi-Products and Dye Research Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The light quanta absorbed with the aid of the light-collecting matrix of the pigment molecules are transferred by several special molecules forming the photoreaction centre (p.r.c.). For the effective storage of electron excitation to take place as a result of charge separation in the p.r.c. the following conditions must be fulfilled: 1) electron transfer from donor to acceptor must occur in a time less than the lifetime of the initial excited state; 2) this transfer must be sufficiently irreversible; 3) in this process the smallest possible share of the excitation energy must be lost. The simultaneous fulfilment of these conditions involves certain difficulties. The paper proposes two ways of overcoming these difficulties (the multi-stage nature of the process and participation of the conformational degrees of freedom). Their realization at different stages of the process of charge separation represents a possible mechanism of functioning of the p.r.c. © 1981.

Title: Ablative optical recording using organic dye-in-polymer films
Affiliations: Xerox Research Centre of Canada, 2480 Dunwin Drive, Mississauga, Ont. L5L 1J9, Canada; Webster Research Center, Xerox Corporation, 800 Phillips Road-114, Webster, NY, 14580, United States

Abstract: Ablative optical recording using dissolved dyes in polymer films has been investigated. Polyester yellow dissolved in poly(vinyl acetate) was used as a model to study the potential for high-sensitivity, high-density optical storage applications. With 20% dye loading, a 59-nm film was more sensitive at 457 nm than a 15-nm Te monolayer, and marks down to 0.5 μm were recorded. The signal contrast (Rf-Ri)/(Rf+Ri) was approximately 0.68 for marks ablated with high-energy laser pulses. The morphology of the marks shows a clean removal of recording material. Suitable polymeric overcoatings, used to simulate second-surface recording situations, had little effect on the results.

Title: All-Nb low-noise dc SQUID with 1-μm tunnel junctions

Abstract: Tunnel-junction dc SQUIDs are being fabricated from Nb films using electron-beam lithography to define linewidths as small as 0.5 μm. The barriers in the Nb-NbOx-Nb junctions are grown in an oxygen plasma discharge, and the Pd2Si resistive shunts are formed by annealing Pd on the Si substrates. These devices have excellent storage and recycling properties. At a measurement frequency of 40 kHz, a SQUID with an inductance of about 1 nH, a critical current of about 4 μA, and a parallel shunt resistance of about 15 Ω had an intrinsic energy resolution of 2.5×10 -32 J Hz-1 at 4.2 K and 1.1×10-32 J Hz-1 at 1.6 K, in good agreement with a model of the dc SQUID.

Title: Relationship between mucus viscoelasticity and ciliary transport in guaran gel/frog palate model system
Affiliations: Meakins Christie Laboratories, McGill University Clinic, Royal Victoria Hospital, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: King, M., Meakins Christie Laboratories, McGill University Clinic, Royal Victoria Hospital, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: Guaran gels, when placed on cilio-active but mucus-depleted frog palate, are transported by ciliary action. The relationship between the rate of ciliary transport of these gels and their viscoelastic properties was investigated. The mechanical properties were determined by the magnetic rheometer technique; this gave elasticity G′ and tan δ (ratio of energy loss to storage) at various frequencies. Transportability was determined by comparing the linear velocity of the gel with that of endogenous palatal mucus. Because of aging effects, both G′, and tan δ for a single gel change considerably over the course of several days. It was thus possible to obtain gels where tan δ at constant G′ varied by a factor of 8 and G′ at constant tan δ by more than an order of magnitude. Transport was found to decrease significantly as both G′ and tan δ increased. However, the importance of tan δ on transport was much greater; the rate of decrease of transport with increasing tan δ being approximately 4 × that with increasing G′. The findings confirm those found previously for the transport of whole canine tracheal mucus. © 1980.

Authors: Rao K.V., Radhaiah G., Raju S.V.S.
Title: Association of growth status and the prevalence of anaemia in preschool children
Affiliations: Nat. Inst. Nutrit., Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Rao, K.V., Nat. Inst. Nutrit., Hyderabad, India; Radhaiah, G., Nat. Inst. Nutrit., Hyderabad, India; Raju, S.V.S., Nat. Inst. Nutrit., Hyderabad, India
Abstract: Hemoglobin levels were determined in 1000 preschool chldren of poor socioeconomic status, whose nutritional status and anthropometric measurements were also determined. The prevalence of mild and severe forms of anaemia was assessed in children by age, sex and various forms of growth retardation and clinical nutritional status. The study revealed that the prevalence of anaemia was higher in younger age groups than the children of 3-5 yr. The prevalence of anaemia was more or less the same in male and female children. Children with poor grades of growth status assessed in terms of height, weight, arm and calf circumferences, weight/height, weight/height and muscle area were found to have higher prevalence of severe anaemia than in those with better grades of growth status. Prevalence of anaemia varied by the criteria adopted and measurements used. Severe forms of clinical PEM signs were more in anaemic children. Prevalence of severe anaemia was higher in those with chronic or current forms of undernutrition than in others. Haemoglobin levels were correlated with measurements reflective of growth status but coefficients were lower than 0.50. Association of severe forms of anaemia with poor grades of growth status might be due to general dietary inadequacy, poor utilisation of iron from food and unavailability of storage iron caused by infections or infestations. Further studies could be of interest for the elucidation of the interrelationship between these factors.

Title: Fuel utilization in marathons: Implications for performance
Abstract: The following data summarize studies of fuel metabolism as applied to the marathon. The pre-exercise muscle glycogen content determines the duration of performance. There is obligate glycogen utilization at the pace of a competitive marathon, approaching 0.5 gram per kg of muscle per km. When muscle glycogen falls below 3 to 5 grams per kg of muscle, pace must decrease, as effort is sustained by fat metabolism. The glycogen burst at the iniatiation of exercise contributes a significant portion (approximately 20 percent) of total glycogen utilization. Dietary manipulation can double muscle glycogen levels. Free fatty acids spare glycogen to that required for the obligate carbohydrate substrate as determined by the ATP to ADP ratio (pace). The rate-limiting step in FFA metabolism is mobilization from adipose tissue. Mobilization lags behind utilization only at the onset of exercise, coincident with the glycogen burst. Otherwise, FFA are available in excess of need. Raising levels of FFA at the onset of exercise can substantially spare glycogen that would otherwise be consumed in the glycogen burst and, hence, enhance performance. In practical terms, the following guidelines should be useful to marathon athletes. Optimal glycogen loading involves the three phases of depletion (exercise), a carbohydrate-poor diet followed by a carbohydrate-rich diet. Depletion exercise must use the same muscles as will be used in the race. A carbohydrate-poor diet for two days will optimize subsequent glycogen storage. A carbohydrate-rich (greater than 70 percent carbohydrate) diet should be consumed for three days before competition, with only light training, to preserve muscle glycogen stores. The runner should maximize caloric intake (as carbohydrates) for the first 10 to 24 hours of carbohydrate loading, and then eat only isocaloric, high-carbohydrate diet for the remaining 2 to 2 1/2 days before competition. This takes advantage of the high specific storage immediately after depletion, and minimizes storage in adipose tissue, with its potentially disadvantageous weight gain. Two meals per day may achieve higher glycogen levels than many small feedings. The last sugar intake should be four to six hours before competition to assure high hepatic glycogen stores while allowing insulin levels to decrease to postabsorptive levels; 100 grams of carbohydrate (two candy bars) is adequate. Caffeine (5 mg per kg of body weight; one NoDoz tablet contains 100 mg of caffeine) taken orally an hour before competition will raise FFA levels and spare glycogen that would otherwise be consumed in the glycogen burst at the beginning of the race. Although these metabolic considerations can benefit runners at any level of ability, it is important to realize that metabolic manipulations can in no way approach the beneficial effects of consistent training on performance.

Title: Anemia and menstrual blood loss
Affiliations: Alza Corp., Palo Alto, Calif. 94304, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, B.J.B., Alza Corp., Palo Alto, Calif. 94304, United States; Gibor, Y., Alza Corp., Palo Alto, Calif. 94304, United States
Abstract: Iron deficiency is highly prevalent worldwide. It occurs in progressively severe stages such as prelatent or storage iron deficiency, latent iron deficiency, and, ultimately, iron deficiency anemia. World Health Organization (WHO)-sponsored surveys have demonstrated iron deficiency in 40 to 99 per cent of pregnant women in various parts of the world and anemia in 21 to 80 per cent of pregnant women. Since iron is essential for energy metabolism, its deficiency has the potential for causing serious consequences: impaired immunity and a higher frequency of serious infectious illnesses; diminished vitality; lowered economic productivity; maternal morbidity and mortality; fetal or neonatal mortality; premature births; and iron-deficient neonates of low birth weight. Women sustain substantial iron losses throughout their reproductive years from menstruation, pregnancy, childbirth, and lactation. The most common cause of iron deficiency, however, is excessive menstrual bleeding. Factors that control menstrual blood loss (MBL) are still unclear, but genetic influences play a part, and volume of flow correlates positively with duration of menstrual periods and possibly with parity and infant birth weights. Factors having no effect include the interval between periods or the interval since the birth of the last child. Age is significant only in that flow is often lighter during menarche than at other times and heavier prior to menopause. Various explanations for the heavy bleeding of menorrhagic women include: excessive prostaglandin activity; coagulation problems; hormonal imbalance; increase in fibrinolysis, heparin-like activity, capillary fragility, or number of endometrial arterioles; and iron deficiency anemia. Some methods of contraception affect the volume of MBL. Combination oral contraceptives and progestogen intrauterine devices (IUDs) decrease MBL by 25 to 60 per cent. By contrast, excessive bleeding is a major reason for discontinuing use of nonhormonal IUDs. Among IUD users with excessive flow, the incidence of anemia is fivefold the preinsertion incidence. Lippes Loop and Dalkon Shield users rank highest and second highest, respectively, in volume of MBL and prevalence of menorrhagia (flow >80 ml), and also in incidence of decreased hemoglobin concentration and of anemia. These two IUDs raise MBL 50 to 100 per cent above preinsertion levels vs. 25 per cent for the Tatum-T intrauterine copper contraceptive (Copper-T) and Copper-7. Progestogen-containing IUDs, although associated with some intermenstrual spotting, generally diminish MBL. The Progestasert intrauterine progesterone contraceptive system (releasing 65 μg progesterone/day) (Progesterone-T) reduces mean menstrual blood loss by 40 to 50 per cent. Progesterone-releasing U-coils also decrease MBL and iron loss values. A T-device, releasing 25 μg d-norgestrel daily, lowers MBL by 40 per cent. Injection or subdermal implanting of synthetic contraceptive progestogens is associated with at least a 10 per cent discontinuation rate within a year because of menstrual disturbances: increased or prolonged bleeding, spotting, irregularities, or amenorrhea. Various oral agents are used to control excessive MBL. These include: antifibrinolytic agents such as aminocaproic acid, tranexamic acid (AMCA), and aprotinin; prostaglandin synthetase inhibitors such as mefenamic acid and flufenamic acid; hormones that inhibit ovulation; low molecular weight polypeptides; and danazol. Particular systemic side effects accompany each, as well as a cost that may be prohibitive. Surgical procedures can also decrease MBL. Uterine curettage reduces blood loss, but only temporarily. When milder procedures fail, hysterectomy is an option. When dietary Vitamin A is deficient, its administration reduces menorrhagia. Iron supplementation is useful for offsetting iron deficiency in vulnerable groups and for treating severe cases requiring rapid correction. Iron fortification programs may be more effective for chronic iron deficiency in large proportions of a population; the iron-enriched food must be readily available and acceptable, inexpensive, absorbable, and not subject to altered stability. We conclude that iron deficiency anemia in women is a serious problem that is frequently ignored. It is prevalent even in the most developed countries, often being associated with MBL. Treatment and prevention have included use of a variety of agents (given locally or systemically), surgery, and iron supplementation or fortification. Ideally, foods rich in iron and foods that promote iron absorption should be consumed. In addition, contraceptives should be selected that decrease MBL, thereby reducing the risk of iron deficiency and anemia, as oral contraceptives and some hormonal IUDs now do.

Title: Effect of heat exposure on plasma composition in protein malnourished rats
Affiliations: Dept. Physiol., M.P. Shah Med. Coll., Jamnagar, India
Authors with affiliations: Jani, R., Dept. Physiol., M.P. Shah Med. Coll., Jamnagar, India
Abstract: The responses of normal (protein in diet 16 per cent) and protein malnourished (protein 1.3 per cent) rats to 50°C ambient temperature (15 min exposure) were compared. Hematocrit ratio, total serum proteins, serum albumin and K+ values increased significantly in normal hyperthermic animals. The increase in these parameters in malnourished hyperthermic animals was not significant. The increase in the level of serum globulins and decrease in serum sodium level was not significant in either hyperthermic group. On exposure to high temperature, malnourished animals showed a higher increase in rectal temperature and less evaporative water loss, as compared to normal animals. This could possibly be due to some atrophic changes in salivary glands leading to impairment of thermoregulatory efficiency, induced by prolonged protein malnutrition. The reduced subcutaneous fat and falling out of the fur cause a decrease in the thermal insulation and thus malnourished animals suffer from more heat storage as compared to normal animals.

Title: Cost of locomotion and heat balance during rest and runninng from 0 to 55°C in a patas monkey
Source title: Journal of Applied Physiology Respiratory Environmental and Exercise Physiology
Affiliations: Concord Field Stat., Harvard Univ., Bedford, Mass. 01730, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mahoney, S.A., Concord Field Stat., Harvard Univ., Bedford, Mass. 01730, United States
Abstract: A young patas monkey was run on a treadmill for 15-20 min at speeds in excess of 15 km·h-1 over a range of laboratory air temperatures from 0 to 55°C. Cost of locomotion for the monkey was 83% that predicted for a running mammal of similar weight, 4 kg. At the highest steady-state running speeds, the patas monkey's energy expenditure was 11 times the resting rate. Heat storage and respiratory evaporation during running each accounted for less than 16% of the heat production. Cutaneous evaporation, mainly sweating, was the major means of heat loss at high ambient temperatures and during heavy exercise. Maximum sweat rates of 0.5 mg·cm-2·min-1 found in these experiments approach the sweat rates of humans. Whole-body dry thermal conductance increased 2-3 times the rest value at a given temperature. Environmentally gained heat contributed about two-thirds of the total heat load on the patas monkey at rest at 53°C. At these same temperatures, environmental and metabolic heat loads were about equal when the animal ran at moderately high speeds (11-13.4 km·h-1).

Authors: Knight R.C., Dewhurst R.J., Ramsden S.A.
Title: Efficient burst-mode operation of a very high repetition-rate Nd:YAG laser
Source title: Journal of Physics E: Scientific Instruments
Affiliations: Dept. of Appl. Phys., Univ. of Hull, Hull, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Knight, R.C., Dept. of Appl. Phys., Univ. of Hull, Hull, United Kingdom; Dewhurst, R.J., Dept. of Appl. Phys., Univ. of Hull, Hull, United Kingdom; Ramsden, S.A., Dept. of Appl. Phys., Univ. of Hull, Hull, United Kingdom
Abstract: A Q-switched flashlamp-pumped Nd:YAG laser has been operated in a burst mode at repetition rates up to 1 kHz, and output energies up to 35 mJ obtained. Use of thyristor controlled resonant-charging techniques, electrolytic energy-storage capacitors and an efficient laser-pumping cavity allowed operation in bursts of up to 75 pulses. A drop in output energy of typically 12% occurred over a 40-pulse burst at 625 Hz. Mean power in the burst of approximately 20 W was obtained from a relatively compact system. Overall electrical efficiency was approximately 70%.
Index Keywords: LASERS

Authors: Blagodarov A.N., Zhuravov V.D., Kochnev I.V., Kunin V.Ya., Morozov S.F., Rodionov A.V., Fomichev V.I.
Title: Metal-insulator-semiconductor light modulators utilizing the Franz-Keldysh effect in gallium arsenide
Affiliations: M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Blagodarov, A.N., M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation; Zhuravov, V.D., M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation; Kochnev, I.V., M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation; Kunin, V.Ya., M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation; Morozov, S.F., M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation; Rodionov, A.V., M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation; Fomichev, V.I., M. I. Kalinin Polytechnic Institute, Leningrad, Russian Federation
Abstract: A study was made of the electroabsorption kinetics, as well as of the spectral and field dependences of the contrast and efficiency of modulation of light in Al-SiO2-GaAs-n+-GaP structures near the fundamental absorption edge of GaAs (875-910 nm). Values of the contrast amounting to 10-12 and the modulation efficiency of 30-40% were achieved. It was demonstrated that optical data storage was possible with the aid of an He-Ne laser. Optical memory was observed in Al-SiO2-(n-n+-GaAs structures on application of voltage pulses causing carrier accumulation; the effect was due to the capture of electrons at the SiO2-GaAs interface. The absorption edge of epitaxial GaAs films on GaP substrates had an exponential profile in the photon energy range 1.37≤hν≤1.40 eV infields 0≤E 5≤6.5·104 V/cm. An empirical relationship was obtained for the spectral and field dependences of the absorption coefficient. © 1981 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MIS; LIGHT

Title: Proton mobility in ice
Affiliations: Interuniversitair Reactor Instituut, 2629 JB Delft, Mekelweg 15, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kunst, M., Interuniversitair Reactor Instituut, 2629 JB Delft, Mekelweg 15, Netherlands; Warman, J.M., Interuniversitair Reactor Instituut, 2629 JB Delft, Mekelweg 15, Netherlands
Abstract: Ice is frequently taken as a model when factors controlling proton transport in hydrogen-bonded molecular networks are discussed. Such discussions have increased with the acknowledgement that proton transfer across cell membranes may play a significant part in energy conversion and storage in biological systems1-4 and that this transfer may involve hydrogen-bonded chains spanning the membrane5,6. However, there is still much uncertainty about the basic mode of proton displacement and the external factors which effect bulk proton transport in ice itself. We present here results of a microwave conductivity pulse radiolysis technique which has been used to determine the mobility of bare protons in ice, and thus reduce some of the uncertainty over proton mobility. © 1980 Nature Publishing Group.

Title: Direct atmosphere generation and control in heat treatment furnaces
Affiliations: Ipsen Industries, International GmbH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goehring, W., Ipsen Industries, International GmbH, United States; Luiten, C.H., Ipsen Industries, International GmbH, United States
Abstract: The processing methods described in the present article offer interesting possibilities for cost reduction by eliminating endogenerators, lower energy consumption and increased carburizing capacity. Compared to other new atmosphere generating systems with nitrogen carrier gas and additions of gaseous carburizing components, the costs of the nitrogen and its storage are saved. Also faster carburizing and improved uniformity are achieved. Recent field experience in both sealed quench units and return-pusher furnaces for carburizing, carbonitriding and neutral hardening has proved to be very satisfactory. Further process refinements, possible processing restrictions and operation at low temperatures, such as at 570 °C for nitrocarburizing, are being studied. © 1980 American Society for Metals.
Index Keywords: FURNACES, HEAT TREATING

Title: Influence of hydrogen on superconducting niobium cavities
Affiliations: National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Isagawa, S., National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: The influence of the solute hydrogen on rf properties of superconducting niobium cavities is investigated experimentally. Chemical polishing and too much electropolishing decrease the energy gap and rf breakdown fields. High-temperature vacuum firing in a UHV furnace decrease the residual loss and recovers the energy gap. Annealed cavities are, however, easily degraded not only by a short period of exposure to hydrogen, but also by a long term storage in air. Chemically polished cavities also show a great enhancement of the penetration depth λ0. These effects can be ascribed to hydrogen which is picked up from etchants or from atmosphere.
Index Keywords: RESONATORS, CAVITY; SUPERCONDUCTING CAVITIES; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES

Title: Design of single layer superconductive energy storage magnets
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Appl. Superconductivity Labs., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eyssa, Y.M., Appl. Superconductivity Labs., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States
Abstract: The concept of superconductive magnetic energy storage has been recently studied. It has been found that single layer solenoids buried in bedrock are economically more attractive than other configurations such as dipoles or toroids. The author presents relations that connect the energy stored and magnetic field to different cost related parameters. Analytical expressions for a variety of parameters such as magnetic fields, magnetic pressure, stresses, and forces are given, and the magnetics of single layer solenoids are reviewed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Authors: Waho T., Kuroda K., Ishida A.
Title: Aging phenomena of plasma oxidized Pb-alloy Josephson junctions
Affiliations: Musashino Electrical Communication Laboratory, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation, Midori-cho 3-9-11, Musashino, Tokyo 180, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Waho, T., Musashino Electrical Communication Laboratory, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation, Midori-cho 3-9-11, Musashino, Tokyo 180, Japan; Kuroda, K., Musashino Electrical Communication Laboratory, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation, Midori-cho 3-9-11, Musashino, Tokyo 180, Japan; Ishida, A., Musashino Electrical Communication Laboratory, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation, Midori-cho 3-9-11, Musashino, Tokyo 180, Japan
Abstract: Aging phenomena in I-V characteristics of plasma oxidized Pb-alloy Josephson junctions have been investigated. Aging effect, or decrease in tunneling resistance during room-temperature storage as long as 300 days, was found to be dominated by a single rate-controlling process of activation energy of 0.78 eV. Based on Auger analysis of tunneling layers, it was concluded that the aging effect can be attributed to the compositional variation in the tunneling oxide layer resulting from the conversion from a Pb- and In-oxide mixture into In oxide. A simple phenomenological model is proposed, which well explains the decrease in tunneling resistance upon aging.
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES
