Title: Properties of pulsed gas lasers pumped by LC inversion circuit made of BaTiO3 and SrTiO3 series ceramic capacitors
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi-cho, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama-shi, Japan; TDK. Electronics Co. Ltd., 1-13-1, Nihonbashi, Chuoo-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsumoto, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi-cho, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama-shi, Japan; Sueoka, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi-cho, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama-shi, Japan; Obara, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi-cho, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama-shi, Japan; Fujioka, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi-cho, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama-shi, Japan; Yamamoto, H., TDK. Electronics Co. Ltd., 1-13-1, Nihonbashi, Chuoo-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Properties of pulsed gas lasers pumped by LC inversion circuit made of BaTiO3 and SrTiO3 series ceramic capacitors were experimentally investigated. The effects of a decrease in capacitance at higher charging voltages on TEA CO2 and TE N2 laser performances were clarified in terms of discharge voltage, current, power pulse, real stored energy and the energy deposited into the discharge load. Laser performances of the TEA CO2 and TE N2 lasers with the SrTiO3 series capacitor used as an energy storage element of the LC inversion circuit were found to be superior to that of the BaTiO3 series capacitor used.
Index Keywords: LASERS, GAS

Title: ND : YAG regenerative amplifier
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murray, J.E., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Lowdermilk, W.H., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: The Nd : YAG regenerative amplifier produces short-duration, optical pulses with the stability and pulse width range characteristic of actively mode-locked lasers and the pulse energy characteristic of passively mode-locked lasers. Other important properties, including large amplification and optical pulse storage, have also been achieved.
Index Keywords: LASERS, SOLID STATE

Title: A study of segmented superconductive energy storage solenoids
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eyssa, Y.M., Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Hilal, M.A., Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States
Abstract: The concept and development of magnetic energy storage has been studied recently. It has been found that large single-layer superconductive energy storage solenoids are economically attractive if they are buried in tunnels in bedrock. The radial forces can be transferred directly through low-thermal-conductivity, high-compression stress struts. To reduce the cold structure required to support axial forces, the concept of segmented solenoids was proposed. The authors present a study of various cost parameters regarding the solenoid aspect ratio and the separation distances between tunnels. The amount of axial structure required is calculated by the virtual work method. To reduce the mechanical strain in the conductor, it has been suggested that the conductor be rippled: an analytical expression for the increase in the magnetic field due to rippling is derived.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONDUCTORS - Strain; SOLENOIDS; MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES

Authors: Pacala T.J., Laudenslager J.B., Christensen C.P.
Title: High-energy subnanosecond pulse amplification in XeCl
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91103, United States; National Science Foundation, Washington, DC 20550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pacala, T.J., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91103, United States; Laudenslager, J.B., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91103, United States; Christensen, C.P., National Science Foundation, Washington, DC 20550, United States
Abstract: Pulse slicing and two-pass amplification are investigated as a means of producing high-energy subnanosecond pulses in the near ultraviolet. A simple laboratory-scale XeCl oscillator-Pockels cell pulse slicer-amplifier system is used to produce 50-mJ pulses of subnanosecond duration at 308 nm. Comparison of multinanosecond and subnanosecond pulse amplification allows estimation of the amplifier energy storage time to be 5 ns and demonstrates nearly complete extraction of available stored energy by the subnanosecond pulse.

Title: Industrial applications of optical shaft encoders
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: BEI Electronics, Inc., Sales and Marketing Organization, P.O. Box 3838, Little Rock, 72203, United States
Authors with affiliations: Edmister, B.W., BEI Electronics, Inc., Sales and Marketing Organization, P.O. Box 3838, Little Rock, 72203, United States
Abstract: The development of the microprocessor and mini-computer for industrial process control has made the optical shaft angle encoder a natural choice for a position feedback transducer. Many of these applications, however, require the encoder to operate reliably in extremely hostile environments. In response to this, the encoder manufacturer has been faced with reliability problems which fall into the following general categories: 1. Exposure to weather 2. Wide operating and storage temperature range 3. Exposure to corrosive chemicals 4. Severe shock and vibration 5. High electrical noise levels 6. Severe blows to encoder housing 7. Operation in explosive atmospheres Three of these applications expose the encoder to most of these environmental conditions: 1. A jack-up control position feedback for an offshore oil well drilling rig 2. A depth measurement system for oil well logging instrumentation 3. Elevation and azimuth feedback for a solar power plant heliostat. © 1980 SPIE.
Index Keywords: CODES, SYMBOLIC - Encoding; COMPUTERS, MICROPROCESSOR - Applications; Feedback; Jack-up rigs; Minicomputers; Offshore oil well production; Oil well drilling; Oil well logging; Optical instruments; Optoelectronic devices; Signal encoding; Solar energy; Solar power plants; Well logging; OPTICAL SHAFT ENCODER; Corrosive chemicals; Environmental conditions; Explosive atmosphere; Hostile environments; Industrial process control; Optical shaft encoders; Reliability problems; Storage temperatures; Transducers; Offshore oil wells

Title: Iconic memory: A review and critique of the study of short-term visual storage
Affiliations: Villanova U
Authors with affiliations: Long, G.M., Villanova U
Abstract: Evaluates 5 types of experimental procedures that have been used to investigate iconic memory (IM) over the past 20 yrs: partial report, persistence of form, duration of stimulus, delay of masking effect, and successive field procedures. It is argued that in some cases these procedures are not equivalent methods for the investigation of IM and that alternate visual processes most likely underlie performance on certain tasks. To support this claim, the widely discrepant evidence concerning the effect of target energy on IM is reanalyzed in light of relative strengths and weaknesses of the various methodologies used. It is shown that the results obtained from a particular procedure, identified as especially sensitive to alternate interpretations, are consistently at odds with those obtained from theoretically purer iconic tasks. The remaining body of evidence presents a relatively integrated picture of an energy-dependent sensory trace following stimulus offset, much as predicted for a retinally based persistence phenomenon. (5 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: experimental procedures, investigation of iconic memory, literature review
Index Keywords: human; memory; perception; photostimulation; recall; review; short term memory; vision; Figural Aftereffect; Human; Memory; Memory, Short-Term; Mental Recall; Perceptual Masking; Photic Stimulation; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.; Visual Perception

Authors: Elias L.R., Madey J.M.J., Smith T.I.
Title: Monte carlo analysis of a free electron laser in a storage ring
Affiliations: High Energy Physics Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Elias, L.R., High Energy Physics Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States; Madey, J.M.J., High Energy Physics Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States; Smith, T.I., High Energy Physics Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States
Abstract: This paper contains studies of the operation of a one-dimensional storage ring free-electron laser (FEL) using a Monte Carlo technique to generate the electron energy fluctuations produced by the FEL. The energy and phase equations of motion have been numerically integrated to calculate equilibrium values of: a) electron energy spread, b) electron phase spread (e.g. electron bunch length), and c) efficiency of conversion of electron energy into laser radiation. The operation of the storage ring free-electron laser was studied for five different FEL magnet designs. It is found that a "one-dimensional" storage ring free-electron laser can operate on a steady-state basis only with reduced overall efficiency due to the inability of the system to damp effectively the electron energy fluctuations produced by the FEL. Results of operation of a SRFEL in a pulsed mode are also presented. © 1980 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: LASERS

Authors: Federici L., Giordano G., Matone G., Pasquariello G., Picozza P.G., Caloi R., Casano L., De Pascale M.P., Mattioli M., Poldi E., Schaerf C., Vanni M., Pelfer P., Prosperi D., Frullani S., Girolami B.
Title: Backward Compton scattering of laser light against high-energy electrons: the LADON photon beam at Frascati
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Frascati, Italy; Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, Roma, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, Napoli, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Napoli, Napoli, Italy; Istituto Superiore di Sanità, Roma, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione Sanità, Sanità, Italy

Abstract: In the present paper we present the experimental results obtained for the backscattering of laser light against the high-energy electrons stored in Adone with the laser cavity dumping technique. The characteristics of the obtained photon beam (LADON beam) are discussed and compared with the theoretical previsions given by the usual storage ring theory. © 1980 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Authors: Calvani M., de Felice F., Nobili L.
Title: Photon trajectories in the Kerr-Newman metric
Source title: Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General
Affiliations: Institute of Astronmy, University of Padova, Padova, Italy; Institute of Physics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Calvani, M., Institute of Astronmy, University of Padova, Padova, Italy; de Felice, F., Institute of Physics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy; Nobili, L., Institute of Physics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
Abstract: We gives a detailed description of the null trajectories in the Kerr-Newman metric. Interesting results which were not expected from what was known in the uncharged case are (a) a considerable enhancement of the energy storage in a restricted region around the source in the naked singularity case and (b) the singularity is completely disconnected from the asymptotic region in the sense that no photon can reach it even in the equatorial plane. © 1980 The Institute of Physics.

Title: Read-write-erasable thin film optical recording medium
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Research and Development Laboratories, Corning Glass Works, Hougton Park, Corning, NY  14830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Borrelli, N.F., Research and Development Laboratories, Corning Glass Works, Hougton Park, Corning, NY  14830, United States; Young, P.L., Research and Development Laboratories, Corning Glass Works, Hougton Park, Corning, NY  14830, United States
Abstract: The optical recording characteristics of a silver halide thin film structure were investigated with respect to its possible use as a read-write-erasable medium. Tracks of ~lym spots were recorded using a polarized He-Ne as the writing source. The recorded tracks were viewed with a GaAs laser between crossed polarizers; the writing energy density was determined to be ~0.2 joules/cm 2 in the transmission mode. Erasure was also demonstrated by re-exposing a portion of the recorded tracks with the defocused write laser with its polarization rotates by 45° from the original write polarization direction. © 1980 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Title: Volatile Ester Hydrolysis or Formation During Storage of Model Solutions and Wines
Source title: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
Affiliations: Department of Viticulture and Enology, University of California, 95616., Davis, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramey, D.D., Department of Viticulture and Enology, University of California, 95616., Davis, California, United States; Ough, C.S., Department of Viticulture and Enology, University of California, 95616., Davis, California, United States
Abstract: The effects of temperature, ethanol concentration, and pH on the rate of hydrolysis of common volatile esters of wine (ethyl butanoate, ethyl hexanoate, ethyl octanoate, ethyl decanoate, isobutyl acetate, isoamyl acetate, hexyl acetate, and 2-phenylethyl acetate) were investigated in model situations. The pseudo-first-order rate constants for temperature and pH effects were calculated as well as the second-order rate constants for [H+] effect on model solution ester hydrolysis. The effect of acid catalysis of species other than H+was calculated and found to be minor. Ethanol concentration differences in amounts of 10-14% v/v had little effect on the rates. Activation energies and thermodynamic activation constants were calculated for the esters. Several wines were also analyzed for changes in ester concentration with time at several different temperatures. © 1980, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Title: The United Kingdom concrete-in-the-oceans program
Source title: American Concrete Institute, ACI Special Publication
Affiliations: The UK Department of Energy's Marine Technology Support Unit, Harwell, United Kingdom; The Director of Research of the Construction Industry Research and Information Association
Authors with affiliations: Sharp, J.V., The UK Department of Energy's Marine Technology Support Unit, Harwell, United Kingdom; Pullar-Strecker, P., The Director of Research of the Construction Industry Research and Information Association
Abstract: Since March 1976 the UK Government Department of Energy and twenty-four industrial firms through CIRIA have jointly funded a £400,000 programme of seven projects aimed at providing additional knowledge to improve the design construction and long-term performance of concrete oil production platforms. The programme is managed by a three-man committee which represents the sponsors. Each sponsoring organisation also has a representative on one of three technical steering groups which advise on the work on the various projects. The projects are undertaken by research design or construction organisations under contract to CIRIA and cover the following topics: the fundamental mechanisms of the corrosion of reinforcement in concrete in seawater, the relationship between crack width and corrosion, corrosion and fatigue of pre-cracked reinforced concrete beams at 150-m depth in seawater and at the surface, surveys of the condition of reinforced concrete in existing maritime structures, the effect of temperature gradients on the walls of oil storage structures, the strength of large prestressed members in shear, and a study of the modes of failure of concrete platforms. Most of the work has been completed and more than twenty reports have been issued to the programme participants. A start has now been made on a further three-year programme estimated to cost £600,000. © 1980 American Concrete Institute. All rights reserved.

Title: Magnetohydrodynamic equilibrium and stability of pre-flare loops - Constant pitch field
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Astrophysics, Bangalore, 560034, India
Authors with affiliations: Hasan, S.S., Indian Institute of Astrophysics, Bangalore, 560034, India
Abstract: The equilibrium and stability of a loop in which energy storage occurs prior to a solar flare is discussed. Working on the hypothesis, that the onset of the flare begins only after sufficient magnetic energy has been stored in the loop typical values of parameters which describe the equilibrium are found for a magnetic field with a constant twist. The stability of this configuration is examined next and it is shown that for the force-free case, the structure is always unstable to kinking for any degree of twist. However, a slight deviation from the force-free configuration, through the presence of a small positive transverse pressure gradient, can stabilize the loops for moderate degrees of twist. The range of wave-numbers for which instability occurs and the maximum growth rates are also presented. Lastly, it is shown that the pressure gradients required to stabilize a pre-flare loop do not lead to conflict with observations. © 1980 D. Reidel Publishing Co.

Title: The effect of temperature on the supply of oxygen to embryos ofintact Acer pseudoplatanus L. seeds
Affiliations: Department of Botany, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1UG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dungey, N.O., Department of Botany, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1UG, United Kingdom; Pinfield, N.J.
Abstract: The effect of temperature on various factors affecting O2 supply to enclosed embryos of A. pseudoplatanus L. seeds was investigated using a simple model for O2 consumption by intact seeds. Low temperatures which induced germination had little effect on the diffusivity of the testa although an increase in diffusivity occurred immediately prior to radicle emergence. The O2 concentration surrounding an enclosed embryo was found to be 5-10% that of the solution bathing the seeds at storage temperatures. The respiratory capacity of the embryos was found to be strongly dependent on temperature and, largely as a result of this, at chilling temperatures the O2 concentration surrounding the enclosed embryo approached that in the ambient solution. The apparent Arrhenius activation energy for O2 consumption was considerably greater below 17 °C than above this temperature. Although insufficient evidence in themselves for a relationship between O2 availability and seed germination, the results do provide evidence for a mechanism by which such a relationship may be associated with seeds requiring chilling to induce germination. © 1980 Oxford University Press.

Title: Heat storage in eutectic alloys
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, 19711, DE, United States; E. I. duPont de Nemours and Co., Inc., Beaumont, 77704, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Birchenall, C.E., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, 19711, DE, United States; Riechman, A.F., E. I. duPont de Nemours and Co., Inc., Beaumont, 77704, TX, United States
Abstract: Classical thermodynamic equations based on the regular solution approximation yield enthalpic changes for eutectic transformation that agree roughly with values measured for several binary and ternary alloy systems by differential scanning calorimetry or differential thermal analysis. Restricting measurements to binary and ternary alloys of the relatively plentiful elements Al, Cu, Mg, Si and Zn, it has been verified that the best heat storage densities on a mass or volume basis are obtained with alloys rich in Si or Al, elements that have large heats of fusion. Several of these alloys have the highest heat-storage density reported for phase change materials that transform between 780 and 850 K. The Mg2Si-Si eutectic, which has outstanding storage density at 1219 K, illustrates the utility of ordered intermetallic phases with large heat of formation that dissolve in the eutectic liquid to contribute to the entropy change. © 1980 American society for metals and the metallurgical society of AIME.
Index Keywords: MAGNESIUM METALLOGRAPHY - Eutectics; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Resource allocation patterns of two California-Sonoran desert ephemerals
Affiliations: Department of Biological Sciences, California State University, Fullerton, 92634, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clark, D.D., Department of Biological Sciences, California State University, Fullerton, 92634, California, United States; Burk, J.H., Department of Biological Sciences, California State University, Fullerton, 92634, California, United States
Abstract: The patterns of allocation of structural and nonstructural carbon were followed in the co-occurring desert ephemerals Plantago insularis and Camissonia boothii. Patterns of biomass distribution were determined from material harvested at biweekly intervals as were levels of nonstructural sugar and starch. Seasonal patterns of growth and reproduction differed markedly with Plantago allocating significantly more structural and nonstructural carbon to reproduction early in the season. Plantago completed its life cycle in less than 60 days but Camissonia continued both vegetative and reproductive growth to over 100 days. The longer growing season of Camissonia was possible because more energy was allocated to vegetative tissues and storage presumably as investment toward longer life and higher levels of reproduction. © 1980 Springer-Verlag.

Title: The addition of Mn and Al to the hydriding compound FeTi: Range of homogeneity and lattice parameters
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dew-Hughes, D., Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Isothermal sections, at 1000 °C, of the Ti-rich corners of the Mn-Fe-Ti and Al-Fe-Ti ternary phase diagrams have been determined. Particular attention has been paid to the FeTi hydriding compound. Mn and Al both substitute for Fe in the compound; the former up to 27 at. pct, the latter up to 24 at. pct. Analysis of the lattice parameter data suggest that effective atomic radii, in the B2 structure, are Al: 1.38Å, Fe: 1.18Å, Mn: 1.22Å, and Ti: 1.40Å. © 1980 American society for metals and the metallurgical society of AIME.

Title: Endurance exercise training in the fast and slow muscles of a teleost fish (Pollachius virens)
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, University of St. Andrews, St. Andrews, Fife, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Johnston, I.A., Department of Physiology, University of St. Andrews, St. Andrews, Fife, United Kingdom; Moon, T.W., Department of Physiology, University of St. Andrews, St. Andrews, Fife, United Kingdom
Abstract: 1. The recruitment of muscle fibre types has been investigated in the coalfish (Pollachius virens) using electromyography. Red trunk muscles were active at all swimming speeds examined (0.25-3.6 lengths/s). Interestingly, white fibres were recruited at 0.8-2.0 lengths/s providing evidence that this muscle type is also used during sustained activity. 2. The effect of endurance exercise training on muscle fibre size and enzymes of energy metabolism has also been investigated. Fish were exercised continuously at 2.1 lengths/s for a period of three weeks in an experimental swimming chamber. This swimming speed represents a significant increase in work load relative to non-exercised fish as evidenced by muscle fibre hypertrophy and an increase in creatine kinase activities in both red (184%) and white (260%) muscles. 3. Glycogen storage levels increased to a greater extent in red (+520%) than white (+200%) muscles. Phosphofructokinase activity was eight times higher in the red muscle of exercised fish. In contrast, there was only a small increase in citrate synthetase (+30%) and no change in either hexokinase or cytochrome oxidase activities in the red muscle of trained fish. 4. Increased hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase activities in both muscle types indicate an enhanced capacity for fatty acid catabolism with training. 5. White muscle phosphofructokinase activities were not significantly different in trained and untrained fish. It is likely that the maximum potential of white muscle for anaerobic glycogenolysis is already sufficient to meet all its energy requirements at this swimming speed. 6. The results suggest that the capacity of coalfish red muscle to do aerobic work remains essentially unchanged by endurance exercise training and that any increase in the ability to produce ATP must be met anaerobically. © 1980 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Collins B.G., Cary G., Packard G.
Title: Energy assimilation, expenditure and storage by the brown honeyeater, Lichmera indistincta
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Bentley, 6102, Western Australia, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Collins, B.G., Department of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Bentley, 6102, Western Australia, Australia; Cary, G., Department of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Bentley, 6102, Western Australia, Australia; Packard, G., Department of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Bentley, 6102, Western Australia, Australia
Abstract: 1. Brown honeyeaters (Lichmera indistincta), maintained in the laboratory on artificial nectar (sucrose solution) at an environmental temperature of 20±1°C, drank nectar at a greater rate in the morning than later in the day. 2. Although only a small percentage of the total time between 0630 h (lights-on) and 1800 h (lightsout) was spent in flight, L. indistincta flew more in the morning than during the afternoon. 3. L. indistincta accumulated energy at a relatively steady rate during the day, with the total energy stored approximating that which had been expended the previous night. 4. When birds were switched from 1.6 M to 1.2 M or 0.8 M nectar, their rates of nectar intake increased. Despite variations in rates associated with different birds and times of day, L. indistincta compensated completely, on average, for calorific dilution of nectar. It is suggested that compensation may have been effected by increases in feeding bout frequency and total feeding time. 5. Nectar concentration did not significantly influence the proportion of time spent by birds in flight. Consequently, the mean masses of fat stored by L. indistincta maintained on different nectar regimes were not significantly different. © 1980 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Barendregt R.B., Van Den Berg P.J.
Title: The degradation of polyurethane
Affiliations: Prins Maurits Laboratory RVO-TNO, P.O. Box 45, 2280 AA Rijswijk (Z.H.), Netherlands; Laboratory of Chemical Technology, Delft University of Technology, Julianalaan 136, 2628 BL Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Barendregt, R.B., Prins Maurits Laboratory RVO-TNO, P.O. Box 45, 2280 AA Rijswijk (Z.H.), Netherlands; Van Den Berg, P.J., Laboratory of Chemical Technology, Delft University of Technology, Julianalaan 136, 2628 BL Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: The aging of polyurethane was investigated by means of the isothermal storage test, adiabatic storage test and differential thermal analysis. Experiments were done between 318 and 493 K. Depending on temperature and degree of conversion, two successive reactions played a role in the aging process. For both reactions the apparent activation energy as well as the frequency factor could be determined. The apparent activation energy was about equal, but the frequency factor differed by a factor of 104. For low temperatures (below 373 K) only the first reaction is important. This reaction is strongly accelerated by oxygen and water vapour. By means of gas chromatography carbon dioxide could be detected as the gaseous product of "dry" aging, whereas carbon dioxide and hydrogen were the degradation products of "wet" aging. By means of thin layer chromatography and nuclear magnetic resonance it could be proved that "wet" aging was accompanied by hydrolysis. © 1980.

Title: Photo-electron and ionization chamber position monitors for CHESS
Affiliations: Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tischler, J., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States; Hartman, P.L., Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, United States
Abstract: In order to provide positional information of the CHESS (Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source) photon beams, we have constructed two positionsensitive devices. The first, located approximately at the 7 m point in the ultra-high vacuum of CESR (Cornell Electron Storage Ring), is a split photoelectron detector. The second detector, which is located outside the CESR vacuum at approximately the 11 m point, will be in the helium-filled beam pipe. This is a split ionization chamber composed of two pairs of collector plates on either side of the 14 mrad beam. Positional sensitivity of the photoelectron monitor to better than 0.1 mm was demonstrated over a range of 2 mm. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Instruments; Ionization chambers; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; Photodetectors

Authors: Bonse U., Spieker P., Hein J.-T., Materlik G.
Title: Measurement of K-edge dispersion anomalies with the new X-ray interferometer at DORIS
Affiliations: Institut für Physik, Universität Dortmund, Postfach 50 05 00, D-4600 Dortmund 50, Germany; Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Notkestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bonse, U., Institut für Physik, Universität Dortmund, Postfach 50 05 00, D-4600 Dortmund 50, Germany; Spieker, P., Institut für Physik, Universität Dortmund, Postfach 50 05 00, D-4600 Dortmund 50, Germany; Hein, J.-T., Institut für Physik, Universität Dortmund, Postfach 50 05 00, D-4600 Dortmund 50, Germany; Materlik, G., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Notkestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Abstract: The new X-ray interferometer installed at the storage ring DORIS is described. Absorption coefficient μ(E) and anomalous dispersion correction f{hook}′(E) were measured simultaneously near the K-edge of Se, which, in the absorption spectrum, displays a narrow structure known as white line [1,2]. Preliminary measurements suggest a corresponding behaviour of f{hook}′(E). The unique properties of the source allow a resolution of typically E/ΔE {reversed tilde equals} 1.5 × 104 at 12.6 keV with counting rates of some 103 s-1 at 3 GeV electron energy and 90 mA electron current. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; X-rays; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; Interferometers

Title: Synchrotron radiation as an absolute standard source
Affiliations: Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, 1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Einfeld, D., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, 1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Stuck, D., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, 1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Abstract: One of the unique features of the radiation emitted by relativistic accelerated electrons is its calculability according to the Schwinger theory. If the experimental parameters (e.g. energy E, radius ρ{variant}) of the accelerator (storage ring or synchrotron) have been determined, as well as the circulating electron current i, then the synchrotron radiation can be utilized for radiometric purposes. Some of the sources of error affecting the calculated spectral radiant energy of a synchrotron passing a given aperture of an optical device will be discussed in more detail. © 1980.

Title: The first use of synchrotron radiation for vacuum ultraviolet circular dichroism measurements
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Florida Atlantic University Boca Raton, FL 33431, United States; The Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
Authors with affiliations: Snyder, P.A., Department of Chemistry, Florida Atlantic University Boca Raton, FL 33431, United States; Rowe, E.M., The Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation (SR) from modern electron storage rings is highly linearly polarized and more intense than conventional vacuum ultraviolet continuum sources. These unique properties make SR ideal for construction of a vacuum ultraviolet circular dichroism (CD) instrument. We report the first use of SR for CD measurements and describe the instrumental setup. These measurements were carried out in the wavelength range 1325-2050 Å on (+)-3-methylcyclopentanone at the Synchrotron Radiation Center of the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The signal to noise ratio, and therefore the resolution, was the best ever obtained for CD measurements in this wavelength range. This resulted in the observation of new structure and dramatic peak height changes in the CD spectrum. In addition, these measurements showed that the extension of CD measurements to higher energies is possible through the use of synchrotron radiation. © 1980.

Title: The importance of photospheric magnetic field complexity for coronal energy storage
Affiliations: The Astronomical Institute at Utrecht, Sterrewacht, Zonnenburg 2, Utrecht, 3512, NL, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Tend, W., The Astronomical Institute at Utrecht, Sterrewacht, Zonnenburg 2, Utrecht, 3512, NL, Netherlands
Abstract: Possibilities for the storage of energy in coronal electric currents in different magnetic background field configurations are investigated in the framework of the solar flare energy build-up model of Van Tend and Kuperus (1978). The results are compared to characteristics of filaments and X-ray loops. Empirical flare predictors are interpreted theoretically. © 1980 D. Reidel Publishing Co.

Authors: Schweppe F.C., Tabors R.D., Kirtley J.L., Jr., Outhred H.R., Pickel F.H., Cox A.J.
Title: Homeostatic utility control
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schweppe, F.C., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, United States; Tabors, R.D., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, United States; Kirtley, J.L., Jr., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, United States; Outhred, H.R., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, United States; Pickel, F.H., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, United States; Cox, A.J., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, United States
Abstract: Distribution Automation and Control (DAC) systems have potentially major effects on costs, social impacts, and even on the nature of the power system itself, especially as dispersed storage, generation, and customer interaction become more prevalent. However, at the present time, it is not clear which particular modes of control will best exploit the capabilities of DAC. Homeostatic Utility Control is an overall concept which tries to maintain an internal equilibrium between supply and demand. Equilibrating forces are obtained over longer time scales (5 minutes and up) by economic principles through an Energy Marketplace using time-varying spot prices. Faster supply-demand balancing is obtained by employing “governor-type” action on certain types of loads using a Frequency Adaptive Power Energy Rescheduler (FAPER) to assist or even replace conventional turbine-governed systems and spinning reserve. Conventional metering is replaced by a Marketing Interface to Customer (MIC) which, in addition to measuring power usage, multiplies that usage by posted price and records total cost. Customers retain the freedom to select their consumption patterns. Homeostatic control is a new, untried concept. It is discussed in this paper because its great potential makes it a vehicle for interesting discussions of where the future may actually evolve. Copyright © 1980 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Rates; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Authors: Yeo R.S., McBreen J., Tseung A.C.C., Srinivasan S., McElroy J.
Title: An electrochemically regenerative hydrogen-chlorine energy storage system: electrode kinetics and cell performance
Affiliations: Department of Energy and Environment, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, 11973, New York, United States; Department of Chemistry, The City University, London, United Kingdom; General Electric Company, 50 Fordham Road, Wilmington, 01887, Mass., United States
Authors with affiliations: Yeo, R.S., Department of Energy and Environment, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, 11973, New York, United States; McBreen, J., Department of Energy and Environment, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, 11973, New York, United States; Tseung, A.C.C., Department of Energy and Environment, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, 11973, New York, United States, Department of Chemistry, The City University, London, United Kingdom; Srinivasan, S., Department of Energy and Environment, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, 11973, New York, United States; McElroy, J., General Electric Company, 50 Fordham Road, Wilmington, 01887, Mass., United States
Abstract: The electrochemical oxidation and reduction of hydrogen and chlorine in hydrochloric acid has been investigated on graphite, ruthenized titanium and platinum electrodes. Both steady state and potentiostatic pulse methods were used. Cell studies were also carried out in cells with flow-by and flow-through chlorine electrodes. Results indicate that the electrode kinetics are fast and the electrolysis and fuel cell reactions can be carried out in the same cell with electric-to-electric efficiencies in excess of 75% at current densities of 300 mA cm-2. Mass transfer limitations at the chlorine electrode during discharge can be eliminated by cell pressurization and the use of flow-through electrodes. © 1980 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: CHLORINE; ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL; HYDROGEN; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: A first-order model of a photo-activated liquid crystal light valve
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of Southern California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Michaelson, J.D., University of Southern California, United States
Abstract: A first order theoretical model of a thin nematic liquid crystal layer mated to a CdS/CdTe heterojunction photosensor is presented. Uniform parallel alignment of the liquid crystal molecules with the light valve substrates is assumed. The response of the liquid crystals is predicted through minimization of the distortion free energy density and the operation of the photosensor is obtained by assuming it to be a back biased light activated charge storage diode. Measurements of an actual liquid crystal light valve response are presented to verify the model. © 1980 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Cadmium sulfide; Free energy; Heterojunctions; II-VI semiconductors; Liquid crystals; Optical sensors; Photosensitivity; First-order models; Liquid crystal layers; Liquid crystal light valve; Liquid crystal molecules; Measurements of; Parallel alignments; Photo-activated; Theoretical modeling; Optical signal processing

Authors: Kourkoumelis C., Resvanis L.K., Filippas T.A., Fokitis E., Cnops A.M., Cobb J.H., Hogue R., Iwata S., Palmer R.B., Rahm D.C., Rehak P., Stumer I., Fabjan C.W., Fields T., Lissauer D., Mannelli I., Mouzourakis P., Nakamura K., Nappi A., Struczinski W., Willis W.J., Goldberg M., Horwitz N., Moneti G.C., Lankford A.J.
Title: Study of massive electron pair production at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: University of Athens, Athens, Greece; National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the asupices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Syracuse University9 9 Work supported by the US National Science Foundation., Syracuse, NY, United States; Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States

Abstract: Data from a study of electron pairs produced in pp collisions (√s = 5 and 63 GeV) are used to extend measurements of the scaling function down to m/√s ≈ 0.07 (4.5 < m < 19 GeV). The dilepton continuum can be described by the scaling formula (fx475-1). The average transverse momentum of dielectrons was found to be 1.43 ± 0.07 GeV, independent of mass (in the range 4.5 < m < 8.7 GeV) and rising with √s. The angular decay distribution of the pairs was measured in the s-channel helicity system and found to behave like 1 + α cos2θ, where α = 1.15 ± 0.34. The angular decay of Υ{hooked} at the same energies was found to have α = 0.31 ± 0.35. © 1980.

Authors: Kourkoumelis C., Resvanis L., Filippas T.A., Fokitis E., Cnops A.M., Cobb J.H., Hogue R., Iwata S., Palmer R.B., Rahm D.C., Rehak P., Stumer I., Fabjan C.W., Fields T., Lissauer D., Mannelli I., Mouzourakis P., Nakamura K., Nappi A., Struczinski W., Willis W.J., Goldberg M., Horwitz N., Moneti G.C., Lankford A.J.
Title: Characteristics of J/ψ and ϒproduction at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: University of Athens, Athens, Greece; National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Syracuse University9 9 Work supported by the US National Science Foundation., Syracuse, NY, United States; Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kourkoumelis, C., University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Resvanis, L., University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Filippas, T.A., National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Fokitis, E., National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Cnops, A.M., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Cobb, J.H., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Hogue, R., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Iwata, S., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Palmer, R.B., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Rahm, D.C., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Rehak, P., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Stumer, I., Brookhaven National Laboratory3 3 Research under the auspices, ERDA., Upton, NY, United States; Fabjan, C.W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Fields, T., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lissauer, D., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mannelli, I., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mouzourakis, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nakamura, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nappi, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Struczinski, W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Willis, W.J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Goldberg, M., Syracuse University9 9 Work supported by the US National Science Foundation., Syracuse, NY, United States; Horwitz, N., Syracuse University9 9 Work supported by the US National Science Foundation., Syracuse, NY, United States; Moneti, G.C., Syracuse University9 9 Work supported by the US National Science Foundation., Syracuse, NY, United States; Lankford, A.J., Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States
Abstract: We present the B( dθ dy)y=0 for J/ψ over thefull range of ISR energies and for Υ{hooked} at √s = 53 and 63 GeV, using their dielectron decay mode. The average transverse momentum and the decay angles are presented. We found (pT) = 1.75 ± 0.19 GeV for Υ{hooked}, being higher than (pT) of the continuum and rising with √s. We present a comparison of the cross sections of J/ψ and Υ{hooked} with those of the continuum, at the same masses, as a function of √s. An appropriate scaling of the hadronic production of quark-antiquark narrow bound states involving ⋉, J/ψ, ψ′, Υ{hooked}, and Υ{hooked}′ is presented as a function of m/√s at y = 0, and is compared with Drell-Yan scaling. © 1980.

Authors: Diakonou M., Kourkoumelis C., Resvanis L.K., Filippas T.A., Fokitis E., Trakkas C., Cnops A.M., Fowler E.C., Hood D.M., Palmer R.B., Rahm D.C., Rehak P., Stumer I., Fabjan C.W., Fields T., Lissauer D., Mannelli I., Molzon W., Mouzourakis P., Willis W.J.
Title: A measurement of direct photon production at large pT at the CERN ISR
Affiliations: Athens University, Athens, Greece; National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Diakonou, M., Athens University, Athens, Greece; Kourkoumelis, C., Athens University, Athens, Greece; Resvanis, L.K., Athens University, Athens, Greece; Filippas, T.A., National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Fokitis, E., National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Trakkas, C., National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Cnops, A.M., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; Fowler, E.C., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; Hood, D.M., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; Palmer, R.B., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; Rahm, D.C., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; Rehak, P., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; Stumer, I., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, USA3 3 Research supported under auspices of the US Department of Energy.; Fabjan, C.W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Fields, T., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lissauer, D., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mannelli, I., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Molzon, W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mouzourakis, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Willis, W.J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: We have measured direct photon production in pp collisions at the CERN intersecting storage rings for c.m. energies 31 < √s < 63 GeV and transverse momenta up to 9GeV/c, using segmented lead/liquid-argon calorimeters. The ratio of direct photon to π0 production is significantly larger than zero, starting at pT ≈ 4 GeV/c and increasing to values of about 0.4 at 9GeV/c. No significant √s dependence is seen. © 1980.

Title: Investigation of oxidized aIIIBv surfaces by photoresponse
Affiliations: Research Institute for Technical Physics of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Újpest 1., Budapest, H-1325, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Somogyi, M., Research Institute for Technical Physics of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Újpest 1., Budapest, H-1325, Hungary
Abstract: The wavelength dependence of photoresponse was studied, observed in the sub band gap energy region of Au-GaP Schottky barriers. Anomalously high response was measured in this energy region if the metal layer was prepared immediately after chemical cleaning, just after etching. The high response diminished pronouncedly when electrodes were made onto surfaces oxidized during storage in air. The presence of a transparent layer on the surface could be established by electron diffraction and ellipsometry as well. The layer structure depended on surface treatment. It was concluded that the high response is located in the interface region, and is characteristic of the slightly oxidized surface. © 1980 with the authors.

Title: First results from PETRA provide new aspects of the basic structure of matter
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, and University, Hamburg, D-2000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schopper, H., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, and University, Hamburg, D-2000, Germany
Abstract: First experimental results from the new large positron-electron storage ring PETRA have been obtained during the first half of 1979. To describe these results a short summary of the present understanding of the basic structure of matter is given. The most recent results are compatible with the existence of gluons, the field quanta of the nuclear force. The possible existence of a quark-lepton-symmetry has led to search for a sixth quark, the t-quark, but no evidence has been seen up to the highest energies of 31.6 GeV. © 1980 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Kitagawa K., Suzuki M., Miyashita M.
Title: Anaerobic power output of young obese men: Comparison with non-obese men and the role of excess fat
Source title: European Journal of Applied Physiology and Occupational Physiology
Affiliations: Laboratory for Exercise Physiology and Biomechanics, Faculty of Education, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kitagawa, K., Laboratory for Exercise Physiology and Biomechanics, Faculty of Education, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan; Suzuki, M., Laboratory for Exercise Physiology and Biomechanics, Faculty of Education, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan; Miyashita, M., Laboratory for Exercise Physiology and Biomechanics, Faculty of Education, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Abstract: Anaerobic power output was measured by the staircase climb test in 14 obese, 16 lean, and 21 ordinary men aged from 18-22 years. Fat storage rate (%fat) was estimated by densitometry. The obese group ranked highest with an average power output of 1,012 W. This value was significantly higher than those of the other two groups, 890 W for lean subjects and 855 W for ordinary subjects. The power output per kilogram of lean body mass of the obese group was the highest also. However, the vertical velocity was the lowest although the difference among the three average values was not statistically significant. To investigate the effect of excess fat, eight non-obese subjects engaged in an added-weight experiment. The value obtained was almost the same as for the obese group. The added weights made the vertical velocity decrease but the power output increase. Consequently, it was obvious that the excess fat of an obese man played a role only as an inert mass in the power output measurement. A significantly higher power output of the obese group might be due to more excess fat, and obesity itself was an advantage in the staircase climb test. © 1980 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Added-weight experiment; Anaerobic power output; Obesity
Index Keywords: adipose tissue; anaerobic capacity; human cell; normal human; obesity; stair climbing; Adipose Tissue; Adolescent; Adult; Anaerobiosis; Body Composition; Body Weight; Comparative Study; Energy Metabolism; Human; Male; Metabolism; Obesity

Title: Marine macroalgae as foods for fishes: an evaluation of potential food quality
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, Arizona State University, Tempe, 85281, Arizona, United States
Authors with affiliations: Montgomery, W.L., Department of Zoology, Arizona State University, Tempe, 85281, Arizona, United States; Gerking, S.D., Department of Zoology, Arizona State University, Tempe, 85281, Arizona, United States
Abstract: A revitalized view of feeding by herbivorous marine fishes is sought through two questions. First, What characteristics of major taxa of algae identify them as predictably high or low quality foods? Second, are marine algae valuable foods for fishes which do not mechanically disrupt cell walls and do not harbor specialized enzymes or microbes capable of lysing cell walls? Energy, ash and nutrient content of 16 species of marine algae were employed to assess food quality of fleshy red, green, brown and calcareous red algae. On the basis of ash, calories, total protein and total lipid content, fleshy algae should be superior to calcareous algae as foods for fishes; in addition, green algae should be superior to brown algae and brown algae superior to red algae. When the probable digestibility of storage and extracellular carbohydrates is considered, green and red algae are predicted superior to brown algae as food. Two species of damselfishes (Pomacentridae) from the Gulf of California, Eupomacentrus rectifraenum and Microspathodon dorsalis, eat red and green algae and ignore brown and calcareous algae. They feed, therefore, in a fashion consistent with predictions based only on algal chemistry. These fishes absorb at least 20-24% of the biomass, 57-67% of the protein, 46-56% of the lipid and 37-44% of the carbohydrate contained in algae eaten in the wild. Since these damselfishes do not masticate their food, it appears that herbivorous fishes can digest major fractions of algal nutrients without mechanical destruction of algal cells. © 1980 Dr. W. Junk bv Publishers.
Author Keywords: Algal biochemistry; Carbohydrates; Damselfishes; Digestibility; Energy; Herbivores; Nutrients
