Title: An analysis of energy conservation possibilities in the residential sector in New Zealand
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, the University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Saha, G.P., Department of Mechanical Engineering, the University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Stephenson, J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, the University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: A model which simulates residential energy use in New Zealand until the year 2000 has been developed. This paper describes some of the energy conservation possibilities and their effect on energy use for space and water heating. an engineering analysis made to determine the effect of various factors on energy use for space heating is first described. the information gained from many computer simulations is used to develop a quantitative relationship between space heating energy and major determinants—climatic location, building type and intensity of use. Results from an engineering analysis of a water heating unit are used to establish the energy savings due to improved cylinder insulation and lower storage temperature. A solar space and water heating system is analysed to determine the fraction of total heating load that can be met by harnessing solar energy. the analyses demonstrate that the potential of conservation measures to reduce energy use can be substantial—by raising the insulation level on the building and on the water heating cylinder, by lowering the water storage temperature, and by installing an optimized solar heating system, the energy requirement can be reduced to 0·37 times what it is today for a typical uninsulated home. Copyright © 1980 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Conservation; Energy; Residential; Solar

Authors: Wenlock R.W., Buss D.H., Derry B.J., Dixon E.J.
Title: Household food wastage in Britain
Affiliations: Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, London SWI, United Kingdom; Laboratory of the Government Chemist, London SEI, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wenlock, R.W., Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, London SWI, United Kingdom; Buss, D.H., Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, London SWI, United Kingdom; Derry, B.J., Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, London SWI, United Kingdom; Dixon, E.J., Laboratory of the Government Chemist, London SEI, United Kingdom
Abstract: 1. The total food and drink available for human consumption in the United Kingdom would provide approximately 13 MJ (3100 kcal)/person per d, while the energy intake recommended for the population is approximately 9.6 MJ (2300 kcal)/person per d. A proportion of this substantial difference must be due to wastage in the home as well as in catering establishments and during the storage, distribution and processing of food. 2. As part of a general investigation of this problem, a representative sample of 1000 British households was asked to collect all the potentially-edible food wasted in their homes during 1 week, and to keep a record of the food, other than commercial pet food, which they gave to pets and wild birds. A total of 672 households co-operated fully, 338 in summer and 334 in winter. Each food sample received was weighed, and its energy content was determined calorimetrically. 3. Significantly more waste food was collected in summer than in winter, equivalent to 9.3 MJ (2220 kcal)/household per week and 7.1 MJ (1700 kcal)/household per week respectively. In terms of energy, cereals, fat and meat wastage predominated, while in terms of weight, milk was more important and fat less so. 4. Considerable quantities of otherwise edible food were also given to pets and birds, accounting on average for a further 2.4 MJ (570 kcal) and 3.0 MJ (710 kcal)/household per week in summer and winter respectively. The energy content of all food wasted in the home therefore averaged 11.7 MJ (2790 kcal)/household per week in summer and 10.1 MJ (2410 kcal)/household per week in winter, equivalent to 0.6 MJ (150 kcal) and 0.5 MJ (130 kcal)/person per d respectively. This is less than one-quarter of the gap between food supplies and the amount of food thought to be eaten in the UK. 5. Food wastage was significantly influenced by the composition of the family, with adults wasting more in absolute terms than children, and larger households wasting less per person than smaller households. However, with few exceptions, neither income nor geographical region significantly affected the total amount of food wasted in the home. 6. When assessed against the expected usage of food in the home, wastage accounted on average for 6.5% of the energy intake in summer and 5.4% in winter. © 1980, The Nutrition Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: family; methodology; normal human; nutrition; Adult; Animal Feed; Child; Energy Intake; Family Characteristics; Food; Food Analysis; Great Britain; Human; Income; Seasons; Waste Products

Title: Site-specific EIS ordered in injunction relief denied in nuclear waste storage case.
Authors with affiliations: Chavez, S.B.
Abstract: Although the US Energy Research and Development Administration did not have to obtain a construction certificate from the Nuclear Regulating Commission for nuclear waste storage tanks, it must supply a programmatic (i.e. generic) environmental impact statement. The EIS for the Hanford storage tanks in Washington was judged insufficient but an injunction against construction was denied on the grounds of the social and economic repercussions. -Timothy O'Riordan

Title: Heat exchanger for in-ground heat storage
Affiliations: Geotechnical Section, Division of Building Research, National Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, K1A 0R6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Svec, O.J., Geotechnical Section, Division of Building Research, National Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, K1A 0R6, Canada; Palmer, J.H.L., Geotechnical Section, Division of Building Research, National Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, K1A 0R6, Canada
Abstract: The first phase of a research project using undisturbed soil for sensible heat storage is described. A laboratory scale model of a heat exchange system was constructed and tested. Thermal charging and recovery rates, modes of heat transport and transient temperature conditions, as well as over-all heat storage performance of the unit are given. The experimental results are compared with predictions of a numerical model based on mass and heat transport. A prototype field installation has been constructed and preliminary results are presented. © 1980, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT STORAGE; HEAT EXCHANGERS

Title: Dealing with hazardous waste
Authors with affiliations: Leonard, L.V.
Abstract: Since November 19th, 1980 industry has been obliged to comply with tough new regulations regarding the handling and disposal of hazardous wastes as indicated by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). These regulations lay the foundation for the entire Federal hazardous waste regulatory programme by: defining hazardous waste; setting standards for generators and transporters of hazardous waste; setting standards for hazardous waste facilities; outlining permit requirements for treatment, storage, or disposal facilities; and providing guidelines for State hazardous waste programmes. For all industries, including metal working, the options for disposal of hazardous waste recommended by the EPA, in order of priority, are: minimize waste generation by modifying the industrial process used; transfer of waste to another industry that can utilise it; reprocess the waste to recover energy or materials; separate hazardous waste from nonhazardous waste at the source and concentrate it to reduce handling, transportation and disposal costs; incinerate the waste; disposal by landfill. The cradle to grave control of hazardous waste under the RCRA is based upon the reporting of hazardous waste through a manifest system. A manifest system is a shipping form that accompanies hazardous waste from generator to transporter and to offsite treatment, storage or disposal facilities. Once hazardous waste is ready for shipment, the generator is responsible for preparation of the manifest.
Index Keywords: dangerous goods; industrial waste; prevention; therapy; United States; waste management

Authors: Antman E.M., Stone P.H., Muller J.E., Braunwald E.
Title: Calcium channel blocking agents in the treatment of cardiovascular disorders. Part 1: Basic and clinical electrophysiologic effects
Affiliations: Cardiovasc. Div., Dept. Med., Peter Bent Brigham Hosp., Boston, Mass., United States
Authors with affiliations: Antman, E.M., Cardiovasc. Div., Dept. Med., Peter Bent Brigham Hosp., Boston, Mass., United States; Stone, P.H., Cardiovasc. Div., Dept. Med., Peter Bent Brigham Hosp., Boston, Mass., United States; Muller, J.E., Cardiovasc. Div., Dept. Med., Peter Bent Brigham Hosp., Boston, Mass., United States; Braunwald, E., Cardiovasc. Div., Dept. Med., Peter Bent Brigham Hosp., Boston, Mass., United States
Abstract: Calcium ions play an important role in the cardiovascular system. They are involved in electrophysiologic processes, link excitation to muscular contraction, control energy storage and utilization, and constrict vascular smooth muscle in coronary and systemic arteries. A new group of pharmacologic agents that block the passage of calcium ions across cell membranes has been developed. These agents act during the slow inward current of cellular depolarization. The most extensive clinical experience has been obtained with four of these agents: verapamil, nifedipine, perhexiline, and diltiazem. Verapamil, which has profound electrophysiologic effects on the slow inward current, is emerging as a valuable antiarrhythmic agent. Re-entrant supraventricular arrhythmias, such as paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, are particularly amenable to treatment with intravenous verapamil. Preliminary trials of long-term therapy with oral verapamil for control of atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia suggest that this agent is effective for therapy of these arrhythmias.
Index Keywords: blocking agent; calcium channel; diltiazem; gallopamil; nifedipine; perhexiline; prenylamine; quinidine; verapamil; cardiovascular disease; cardiovascular system; electrocardiography; electrophysiology; heart; heart muscle fiber membrane; heart muscle fiber membrane potential; heart supraventricular arrhythmia; review; therapy

Authors: Battistella P.A., Vergani L., Donzelli F., Rubaltelli F.F., Angel1ni C.
Title: Plasma and urine carnitine levels during development
Affiliations: Departments of Neurology and Pediatrics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Battistella, P.A., Departments of Neurology and Pediatrics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy; Vergani, L., Departments of Neurology and Pediatrics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy; Donzelli, F., Departments of Neurology and Pediatrics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy; Rubaltelli, F.F., Departments of Neurology and Pediatrics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy; Angel1ni, C., Departments of Neurology and Pediatrics, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
Abstract: Plasma and urine free carnitine concentration during human development was evaluated. A positive correlation was found between plasma level and body weight in premature neonates weighing between 1.15 and 1.80 kg. In full terms newborns, tbe free carnitine concentration (mean ± S.E., 31.2 ± 2.5. nmoles/ml) is similar to that of premature babies with 33 to 36 wk of gestational age (37.5 ±3.1 nmoles/ml) but significantly lower than that of premature babies aged 30 to 33 wk of gestation (43.0 ± 5.6 nmoles/ml). In the first 2 wk of life, free carnitine level showed a good correlation with age in the full-term newborns. Adult levels are reached by the end of the first 6 months. No sex related difference was observed in any of the different groups during growth. Urinary excretion of free carnitine per day is significantly lower in infants 0 to 3 years old (mean ± S.E., 15.5 ± 1.8 µmoles/24 hr) and in children 3 to 10 years old (115.3 ± 11.4 µmoles/24 hr) than in subjects ranging in age from 22 to 70 years (216.9 ± 20.6 µmoles/24 hr). We found no difference between day- and nighttime urinary excretion in newborns and infants. Speculation: The present observations suggest that fetal free carnitine storage mainly occurs during the 30th to 33rd wk of life. Because the fatty acids are the main energy fuel in the postnatal period and their β-oxidation is carnitine dependent, an exogenous source of this substance seems useful to maintain plasma levels similar to those found in the fetus. The lower free carnitine excretion observed in our children group compared to adult may be related to a smaller muscle mass, different kidney excretion, or reduced endogenous synthesis. © 1980 International Pediatric Research Foundation, Inc.

Title: Peripheral cytoplasmic shedding around hepatocytes — Apocrine secretion, pathological cell reaction or preparation artifact?
Affiliations: Department of Pathology, Karl Marx University, Leipzig
Authors with affiliations: Cossel, L., Department of Pathology, Karl Marx University, Leipzig
Abstract: Introduction. In electron microscopic investigations of human liver needle biopsies, sequestration of hepatocellular cytoplasm was found in healthy probands without liver disease. From this the question arises as to whether and to what an extent these findings are caused by preparation artifacts, or whether they are an expression of apocrine secretion mechanisms occurring in hepatocytes under normal conditions. We tried to answer this question by evaluating electron microscopic results obtained both in the healthy and in the diseased human liver. Material and methods. Liver needle biopsies from 33 healthy volunteers or patients with biochemical serum abnormalities without any clinical or morphologic evidence of liver disease and 13 liver diseased patients were studied by light and electron microscopy. For electron microscopy: fixation for 2 hours in ice cold 1% OsO4 solution (pH 7.2) (18 cases) or for 3-5 hours in 2.5% glutaraldehyde (pH 7.2) with postfixation for 2 hours in 1% OsO4 solution (28 cases). - Dehydration in an ascending acetone series. Embedding in Micropal. Post-contrast with lead nitrate and sodium citrate. Results. Besides microvilli, we found cytoplasmic protrusions in varying size, form, number and localization on the surfaces of the hepatocytes bodering Disse's space and the interparenchymal spaces, as well as the bile canaliculi (Figs. 1-4, 5b, 10). Hepatocellular cytoplasmic portions of this structure and microvilli are also freely located in Disse's (Figs. 6, 7, 10) and the interparenchymal (Figs. 2, 3, 8a) spaces, in the bile canaliculi (Figs. 4, 5a, 9) and in the sinusoids (Figs. 6, 8a). They were also observed partially or completely surrounded by the cytoplasm of the Kupffer cells (Fig. 8b). The cytoplasmic portions and protrusions differ from the hepatocellular cytoplasm only in their contents of cytoplasmic components and organelles or else there is no difference (cp. Figs. 1-12). On the connecting point of the protrusions to the hepatocytes, the cytoplasmic ground substance often is more electron dense (Figs. 4, 5b) or there are membrane-bound, predominantly electron-optically empty vacuoles arranged in rows with small cytoplasmic connecting bridges between them (Figs. 1, 2, 5b). Variously electron-dense - sometimes strongly osmiophilic, partly lamellar - structures are often seen in these extracellular spaces (Figs. 1, 2, 6, 9). The cytoplasmic portions located freely in the extracellular spaces - including those the size of the microvilli - may exhibit features of dissolution and degradation (Figs. 3, 5, 7, 9). Sequestration of cytoplasm was also observed in Kupffer cells and in lymphocytes within the sinusoidal lumen (Figs. 11, 12). - Differently developed and in varying localisations, these findings were present in 19 of 46 liver needle biopsies investigated. They were observed in 12 healthy probands and in patients with biochemical serum abnormalities without any clinical or light microscopic evidence of liver disease, but often with features of metabolic activation of the liver, and in 7 diseased livers (2 liver cirrhosis, 2 prolonged viral hepatitis, 2 persistent hepatitis, 1 cholesterol ester storage disease). The quantitative and qualitative appearance of these findings is stronger in diseased livers, especially in liver cirrhosis, than in healthy livers. In persons without liver disease, these alterations are localized almost exclusively in the periphery of liver lobules. There is no connection of these findings with icterus or cholestasis, and there are no quantitative and qualitative differences in their development relative to the fixation methods employed. Discussion. Shedding peripheral cytoplasm is caused mainly by energy insufficiency in the cell. The intravital development of this process is demonstrated by several observations under pathological conditions and by experimental investigation results as well. But energy insufficiency in cells may also be caused during preparation. Therefore the occurrence of this alteration as a preparation artifact is possible. - On the other hand these findings amount to three known electron microscopic equivalents of the apocrine secretion mechanism (micro- and macroapocrinia and secretion in “quanta”). Together with the observed evidence for dissolution and degradation in the sequestered cytoplasmic portions and the results obtained in pathologically altered livers, these findings militate in favour of the occurrence of apocrine mechanisms in the bile canaliculi, Disse's and the interparenchymal spaces in hepatocytes located at the periphery of liver lobules in normal and metabolically activated liver, as well as the sequestration of peripheral cytoplasm based on these mechanisms as an adaptative reaction of hepatocytes to pathological conditions. These findings may contribute to the explanation of normal and increased contents of cell enzymes and other substances located in the cytoplasm of the hepatocytes in the blood (serum) and in bile, they provide possibilities for the passage of whole lysosomes and also other cell organelles from cells into extracellular spaces, and under special conditions are the morphologic equivalents of the formal pathogenesis of atrophy and chronic, slowly-occurring necrobiosis of hepatocytes. - Evidence for processes of the same kind in macrophages (Kupffer cells) and lymphocytes in the liver stresses their possibly general pathologic importance, especially as extrusion mechanism for pathogenetically active cytoplasmic components and substances passing into the extracellular spaces. © 1980, Gustav Fischer Verlag · Stuttgart · New York. All rights reserved.

Title: Membrane stratified solar ponds
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Ames Laboratory-USDOE, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hull, J.R., Department of Physics, Ames Laboratory-USDOE, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Abstract: The membrane stratified solar pond is a body of liquid utilizing closely spaced transparent membranes to quench convective heat transfer in the top part of the pond. Membranes may be configured as horizontal sheets, vertical sheets or vertical tubes. Several suitable liquids and membrane materials are discussed. Conditions for suppression of convection are described, and transmission of solar radiation through the pond is discussed for each of the three membrane configurations. The steady state thermal efficiency is calculated for the horizontal sheet configuration. Thermal behavior is similar to that of salt gradient solar ponds, but much deeper heat storage layers are feasible. In some cases aquaculture farming may be suitable in the storage layer. © 1980.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MEMBRANES; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Computer modeling of a ventilated Trombe Wall-With actual performance results
Affiliations: Agricultural Engineering Dept., Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66502, United States
Authors with affiliations: Robbins, F.V., Agricultural Engineering Dept., Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66502, United States; Spillman, C.K., Agricultural Engineering Dept., Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66502, United States
Abstract: A mathematical simulation procedure developed for use with a digital computer to predict the daily performance of a ventilated Trombe Wall is described and documented with actual measured performance results. The solar collector-storage system is used to preheat the ventilating air required by animal confinement structures, and thus reduce their demand for fossil fuel energy. In this system, all collected energy is delivered to the heated space in the ventilating air. This air is drawn continuously through the concrete wall on its way to the building. Given hourly or daily total solar insolation on a horizontal surface and hourly or daily average ambient temperature, we first calculate the available energy at the vertical collector, and the amount transmitted through the transparent covers. Then the collection process is simulated, and we predict the total collected energy, the amount supplied to the building, and the portion retained in storage for each day. During the 1977-1978 heating season we analyzed performance data for 7 periods of approximately one month each. We also simulated system performance for these periods, and relative error between measured and simulated performance ranged from 0 to 12 per cent with all but one month within 6 per cent. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEATING - Solar; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FARM BUILDINGS

Title: Computer model for district energy system analysis.
Source title: Energy and community planning on the prairies
Affiliations: Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ontario KIA OM2, Canada., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Morofsky, E., Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ontario KIA OM2, Canada., Canada
Abstract: A district energy system, especially one employing a large heat storage facility, may be able to tap energy sources that would not otherwise be suitable owing to irregular occurrence or difficulty in transporting the energy to demand centres. To be viable as thermal energy for buildings, sources such as geothermal, solar, and nuclear energy (which is likely to be available in off-peak electrical demand periods) all require at least one of the following: an extensive network for distribution of the energy, large-scale demand applications, or large off-peak storage capacity. These requirements have hindered the use of these sources in individual buildings, but they are compatible with a district energy system. -from Author.

Authors: Busico V., Carfagna C., Salerno V., Vacatello M., Fittipaldi F.
Title: The layer perovskites as thermal energy storage systems
Affiliations: Istituto Chimico, Universita' di Napoli, Via Mezzocannone n.4, 80100 Napoli, Italy; Istituto di Fisica, Facolta' di Ingegneria, Piazzale Tecchio, 80100 Napoli, Italy, Italy

Abstract: A series of compounds of the general formula (n-CnH2n+1NH3)2MCl4 (where M is a divalent metal atom and 8 ≤ n ≤ 18) undergoing high enthalpy reversible solid-solid phase transitions is considered. Although their transition enthalpy values are lower than those of the corresponding normal paraffins, the advantage of remaining solid after the phase change, together with other properties, makes these compounds of potential interest in the field of thermal energy storage systems. © 1980.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Rodriguez R., Dishman J.M., Dickens F.T., Whelan E.W.
Title: Modeling of Two-Dimensional Spiral Inductors
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Components, Hybrids, and Manufacturing Technology
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Inc., Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ 07981, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rodriguez, R., Bell Laboratories, Inc., Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Dishman, J.M., Bell Laboratories, Inc., Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Dickens, F.T., Bell Laboratories, Inc., Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Whelan, E.W., Bell Laboratories, Inc., Whippany Rd., Whippany, NJ 07981, United States
Abstract: The trend toward size reduction of power-conditioning circuitry is increasing the use of higher switching frequencies (in the megahertz range) for dc-to-dc conversion. For power magnetic components this is requiring novel designs of energy-storage inductors. An investigation is reported of two-dimensional spiral wound air-core inductors. These inductors have the potential advantages of being printable as a thick-or thin-film circuit element and, therefore, inexpensive to manufacture. Via a simplifying approximation, one can reduce a formidable mathematical problem to one in which closed-form expressions can be written for the total inductance and the resistance. Our approximate expression for the resistance is meant to account for the skin effect exactly and for the proximity effect in an average way. A comparison is presented between the predicted and measured value of impedance as a function of frequency. Implications of these results and of modeling the effects of parasitic capacitance are discussed in the context of determining an optimized geometry and operating frequency. © 1980 IEEE.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INDUCTORS, POWER TYPE

Title: Electricity supply and demand in Devon and Cornwall ( UK).
Source title: Technical Report, UK South West Energy Group, Exeter
Authors with affiliations: Waller, R.G.
Abstract: Suggests that an acceptable solution to the problem of meeting demand can be achieved using local attributes to the full. An alternative to a large station would be to install a modest number of smaller plants. This could be a package consisting of 600 MWe of compressed air starage, 120 MWt (12-MWe) of combined heat and power at Plymouth, 100 MWt (20-30 MWe) of industrial CHP. This capacity would provide energy at a lower present cost than a nuclear station. Through the storage component it would make an additional nuclear station unnecessary elsewhere in the country. It would also obviate the need for reinforcement of the grid by bringing down the peak load much closer to the average. Large scale movement of fuel through the region would become unnecessary. -from CEGB Digest

Authors: D'Angiuro L., Cremonesi P., Mazzola G., Focher B., Vecchio G.
Title: Preparation and characterization of enzymes immobilized by graft copolymerization to different polysaccharides
Affiliations: Stazione Sperimentale per la Cellulosa, P. za Leonardo da Vinci, Milano, 26-20133, Italy; Italfarmaco, Viale Fulvio Testi, Milano, 330-20126, Italy; Laboratorio di Chimica degli Ormoni, C.N.R, Via Mario Bianco, Milano, 9−20131, Italy; Stazione Sperimentale per la Cellulosa, Milano, Italy; Loboratorio de Chimica degli Ormoni, C.N.R., Via Mario Bianco, Milano, 9−20131, Italy
Authors with affiliations: D'Angiuro, L., Stazione Sperimentale per la Cellulosa, P. za Leonardo da Vinci, Milano, 26-20133, Italy; Cremonesi, P., Italfarmaco, Viale Fulvio Testi, Milano, 330-20126, Italy; Mazzola, G., Laboratorio di Chimica degli Ormoni, C.N.R, Via Mario Bianco, Milano, 9−20131, Italy; Focher, B., Stazione Sperimentale per la Cellulosa, Milano, Italy; Vecchio, G., Loboratorio de Chimica degli Ormoni, C.N.R., Via Mario Bianco, Milano, 9−20131, Italy
Abstract: A method of enzyme immobilization by graft copolymerization on polysaccharides is reported. Glycidylmethacrylate was used as a vinylating reagent and the reaction product with enzymes (HRP, GOD, Am, ChT) was copolymerized with different matrices (cellulose, Sepharose, Sephadex, Starch). Various factors affect the final activity of copolymers; these include the redox system, the type of support, and the quantity and type of vinyl monomer added. Using a fixed quantity of enzyme and support (3 mg enzyme, 100 mg support), the coupling efficiency varied from 2 to 50%. The most important characteristics in these immobilized systems were tested (stability in continuous washing, kinetic characteristics, storage, thermal, and lyophilization stability). Immobilized‐enzyme graft copolymers have very similar kinetic behavior to that of the free enzyme. Diffusion is not seriously limited, as shown by kinetic parameters and energy activation values, and this indicates that the immobilization reaction does not alter the enzymatic activity. Copyright © 1980 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Title: ENERGY CONSUMPTION FOR REFRIGERATED, CANNED, AND FROZEN SNAP BEANS AND CORN
Affiliations: Institute of Food Science New York, Cornell University Geneva, State Agricultural Experiment Station, New York, 14456, United States
Authors with affiliations: RAO, M.A., Institute of Food Science New York, Cornell University Geneva, State Agricultural Experiment Station, New York, 14456, United States
Abstract: The energy inputs at different stages in the food cycle of corn and snap beans were estimated for refrigerated, canned, and frozen market forms. In the case of corn, the energy inputs totalled 3,146, 2,986, and 3,902 Btu/2.9 oz serving for canned, frozen, and refrigerated market forms. The corresponding figures (Btu/2.3 oz serving) for snap beans were 2,913, 2,715, and 2,134, respectively. The difference between the magnitudes for the canned and frozen forms is not significant. Further, because of the variability in the energy data for the different stages in the food cycle, magnitudes of energy consumption different than those listed may be obtained. The present and earlier studies on vegetables show that edible yield (number of servings) plays a major role in the energy consumed in the total cycle. Based on the present and previously published studies on energy consumption for vegetables, it appears that raw or refrigerated vegetables with yields more than about 40%will require less energy than other market forms. In this context, while most raw vegetables have yields higher than 40% they have short storage lives. Therefore, a large number of vegetables must be frozen or canned for long term availability. Copyright © 1980, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; FOOD PRODUCTS

Authors: Fouda A.E., Despault G.J.G., Taylor J.B., Capes C.E.
Title: Solar storage systems using salt hydrate latent heat and direct contact heat exchange-I preliminary design considerations
Affiliations: National Research Council of Canada, Division of Chemistry, Ottawa, K1A 0R9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Fouda, A.E., National Research Council of Canada, Division of Chemistry, Ottawa, K1A 0R9, Canada; Despault, G.J.G., National Research Council of Canada, Division of Chemistry, Ottawa, K1A 0R9, Canada; Taylor, J.B., National Research Council of Canada, Division of Chemistry, Ottawa, K1A 0R9, Canada; Capes, C.E., National Research Council of Canada, Division of Chemistry, Ottawa, K1A 0R9, Canada
Abstract: The operating characteristics of a salt hydrate latent heat storage system, using Glauber's salt and direct contact heat exchange through an immiscible heat transfer fluid, have been studied theoretically. Drop dynamics and heat transfer models from the literature were used to predict the system behaviour for a range of conditions involving heat transfer fluid inlet temperature and drop size, composition and crystallization temperature of the salt and vessel contact height. The results of these calculations are used to guide the specification of an approx. 1 10 scale pilot heat storage unit which has been constructed and operated successfully. © 1980.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; HEATING - Heat Storage; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Polivka W.M., Chetty P.R.K., Middlebrook R.D.
Title: State-Space Average modelling of converters with parasitics and storage-time modulation
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Polivka, W.M., California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States; Chetty, P.R.K., California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States; Middlebrook, R.D., California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States
Abstract: The State-Space, Averaging approach to modelling switching converter power stages is used to extend the analytical descriptions of the buck, boost, back-boost, and Cúk converters to include the effects of all parasitic resistances and transistor storage-time modulation. The analysis reveals for the first time a new and unexpected term in the line to output response of the Cúk converter. The new term contains a right half-plane zero produced by the energy transfer capacitance in combination with the duty-ratio-weighted sum of the on-resistances of the transistor and diode plus a non-dissipative ac resistance term due to transistor storage-time modulation. The conventional circuit model of the converter is modified to include the effects of the new term. The improved model permits an easy physical interpretation of the, new zero, which has been observed only in the Cúk converter. An extended analysis of storage-time modulation in bipolar transistor switches shows that the ac small-signal performance of a switching converter is highly dependent on the nature of the base drive. It is demonstrated that storage-time modulation in conjunction with a proportional base drive can produce instability in switching converters, even open-loop. The results of these analyses are verified experimentally and their impacts on practical converters are discussed. © 1980 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Energy transfer; Heterojunction bipolar transistors; Power converters; Time switches; Transistors; Analytical description; Conventional circuits; Parasitic resistances; Physical interpretation; Right half plane zero; Signal performance; State space average; Switching converter; Modulation; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS

Title: An investigation of the thermal energy storage capacity of Glauber's salt with respect to thermal cycling
Affiliations: Institute of Energy Conversion, University of Delaware, One Pike Creek Center, Wilmington, DE 19808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marks, S., Institute of Energy Conversion, University of Delaware, One Pike Creek Center, Wilmington, DE 19808, United States
Abstract: Calorimetric measurements have been performed on mixtures of Glauber's salt and borax and Glauber's salt, borax and attapulgite clay (the last serves as a thickener) in order to compare the thermal energy storage capacity of the unthickened mixture to the thickened as a function of thermal cycling. The results show a significant improvement in performance of the thickened mixture over that of the Glauber's salt and borax mixture. However, the thickened mixture shows a decline in performance with thermal cycling; several hypotheses to rationalize the decline are presented, tested and discussed. © 1980.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Kalanda B.D., Oke T.R., Spittlehouse D.L.
Title: Suburban energy balance estimates for Vancouver, B.C., using the Bowen ratio-energy balance approach.
Affiliations: Dept of Geog, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada V6T 1W5., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kalanda, B.D., Dept of Geog, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada V6T 1W5., Canada; Oke, T.R., Dept of Geog, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada V6T 1W5., Canada; Spittlehouse, D.L., Dept of Geog, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada V6T 1W5., Canada
Abstract: The balance is obtained from direct measurements of net radiation, parameterized heat storage and turbulent fluxes determined according to the Bowen ratio-energy balance method with reversing psychrometers. Evapotranspiration is always an important term in the balance. The role of urban irrigation and microscale heat advection in maintaining evapotranspiration rates is discussed. -from Authors

Title: Passive energy storage in greenhouses
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, The University of New South Wales, Sydney, 2033, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Morrison, G.L., Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, The University of New South Wales, Sydney, 2033, Australia
Abstract: A passive energy collection and storage system for greenhouses, based on the collection of energy from the greenhouse atmosphere and storage in the ground is investigated. A thermosyphon circulation system to transfer the energy from the moist air in the greenhouse to the ground is analysed, and preliminary experiments in a small greenhouse are reported. © 1980.
Index Keywords: GREENHOUSES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Structures, reduction potentials and absorption maxima of synthetic dyes of interest in photochemical solar-energy storage studies
Affiliations: Photochemistry Unit, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Ontario, London, Ont. N6A 5B7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Chan, M.S., Photochemistry Unit, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Ontario, London, Ont. N6A 5B7, Canada; Bolton, J.R., Photochemistry Unit, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Ontario, London, Ont. N6A 5B7, Canada
Abstract: The photochemical redox behaviour of synthetic dyes is governed by their excitation energies and gound-state redox potentials. We have tabulated the structures, reduction potentials and absorption maxima of 66 water-soluble synthetic dyes in 5 classes; namely, acridines, phenazines, oxazines, thiazines and xanthenes. The relevant references for certain other dyes of current interest to solar energy research are also included. Examples are given of how this table can be used. Solar scientists working with dye-sensitized systems such as photogalvanic cells, pigmented semiconductors or photochemical production of hydrogen gas should find this compilation useful. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Van Oudenhoven J.A.C.M., Angles M., De Roocker A.
Title: Disposal techniques for spilt oil
Affiliations: CONCAWE, Den Haag, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Oudenhoven, J.A.C.M., CONCAWE, Den Haag, Netherlands; Angles, M., CONCAWE, Den Haag, Netherlands; De Roocker, A., CONCAWE, Den Haag, Netherlands
Abstract: The various techniques which can be used to dispose of oil and oily debris, collected after major oil spills, are described. The report is intended to assist individuals and organisations concerned with this problem, including: National and local authorities; Compilers of contingency plans; Managers of disposal organisations; Oil spill clean-up supervisors; Industry personnel. The nature of the collected material, its transportation and storage, is outlined. The disposal techniques which are described result (in order of preference) in: recovery of oil for re-use, or stabilisation of the oily waste, or destruction or decomposition of the oil. Recovery techniques include gravity separation, emulsion-breaking and a variety of washing or extraction procedures. Oily waste may be stabilised through use in civil works or by a range of landfill procedures. Destructive techniques include biological degradation or heat treatment (which may permit heat recovery). Some indication of manpower requirements and costs is given, together with a 'desirability rating' for the various methods of disposal, although final choice of disposal method will always depend on local conditions and the legal constraints of each case. Close co-operation is urged between authorities and industry, before, during and after an oil spill, to ensure that collected oil is disposed of in an environmentally acceptable, cost-effective and energy-conserving manner. Recommendations are made for future developments in spilt oil disposal techniques.
Index Keywords: cost; oil spill; therapy

Title: General hazards and necessary precautions associated with the storage, handling and use of liquified petroleum gas fuel
Authors with affiliations: Purchon, D.W.
Abstract: Liquified petroleum gas (PPG) is a highly convenient fuel with a reasonable safety record. However, as with all fuels or energies, heavy penalties are occasionally paid by persons who fail to follow sound basic rules and precautions. It is necessary to keep in perspective the problems and potential hazards involved with LPG, especially when it is compared with other fuels. Commerce and industry have been using LPG for many years. It is a popular product in the catering industry, as a fuel for forklift trucks, taxis, delivery vans and as a convenient portable or mobile source of heat. In refined versions LPG is used as a carrier for aerosols and as cigarette lighter fuel etc. In industry it is very popular for its low pollution properties and from many process viewpoints it is a most satisfactory fuel. In the present paper an overview is presented of the physical and chemical properties of LPG having a bearing on safety and health. Two case studies are discussed. Several types of containers are described. Emergency guidelines for LPG are given.
Index Keywords: butane; liquefied petroleum gas; propane; industrial hygiene; liquid propane gas; prevention

Authors: Francey J.L.A., Golding P., Clarke R.
Title: Low-cost solar heating of community pools using pool covers
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Monash University, Clayton, Vic. 3168, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Francey, J.L.A., Department of Physics, Monash University, Clayton, Vic. 3168, Australia; Golding, P., Department of Physics, Monash University, Clayton, Vic. 3168, Australia; Clarke, R., Department of Physics, Monash University, Clayton, Vic. 3168, Australia
Abstract: Enormous energy savings may be obtained by incorporating solar pool blankets on community-size heated swimming pools. Installation of a removable, practicable cover can eliminate evaporation, which is by far the biggest heat loss factor. The cover also has a considerable effect in reducing convective heat losses. The large volume of water in swimming pools provides built-in thermal storage. The ability of the store to maintain standard comfort water temperatures over lengthy periods in various seasons is shown using the results of comparative thermal testing with two scaled systems, each of 4.71 m3 capacity and the applicability of these results to installed systems is reviewed. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY; SWIMMING POOLS - Heating; HEATING

Authors: Wyman C., Castle J., Kreith F.
Title: A review of collector and energy storage technology for intermediate temperature applications
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Boulevard, Golden, CO 80401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wyman, C., Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Boulevard, Golden, CO 80401, United States; Castle, J., Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Boulevard, Golden, CO 80401, United States; Kreith, F., Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Boulevard, Golden, CO 80401, United States
Abstract: The technology and thermal performance of intermediate temperature solar collectors is summarized and the status of thermal and thermo-chemical storage methods is reviewed. It is concluded that collector technology is commercially available to achieve delivery temperatures up to 350°F at averaged yearly efficiencies better than 30 per cent in good solar climates and that linear parabolic, single-axis tracking troughs are the best types of collectors currently available for intermediate temperature applications. On the other hand, energy storage options commercially available today are generally limited to sensible heat systems, which are bulky and expensive for long-term storage. More research is necessary to develop new storage concepts, such as intermediate temperature chemical heat pumps based on reversible reactions, suitable for intermediate temperature solar systems with significant storage capability. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: A convolution model of rock bed thermal storage units
Affiliations: California State University, Fullerton, CA 92634, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sowell, E.F., California State University, Fullerton, CA 92634, United States; Curry, R.L., California State University, Fullerton, CA 92634, United States
Abstract: A method is presented whereby a packed-bed thermal storage unit is dynamically modeled for bi-directional flow and arbitrary input flow stream temperature variations. The method is based on the principle of calculating the output temperature as the sum of earlier input temperatures, each multiplied by a predetemined "response factor", i.e. discrete convolution. A computer implementation of the scheme, in the form of a subroutine for a widely used solar simulation program (TRNSYS) is described and numerical results compared with other models. Also, a method for efficient computation of the required response factors is described; this solution is for a triangular input pulse, previously unreported, although the solution method is also applicable for other input functions. This solution requires a single integration of a known function which is easily carried out numerically to the required precision. © 1980.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Projection op tentative expiry date prom one-point accelerated stability testing
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Pharmacy, Massachusetts College of Pharmacy, Boston, MA, 02115, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, W.-H., Department of Industrial Pharmacy, Massachusetts College of Pharmacy, Boston, MA, 02115, United States; Roy, S.B., Department of Industrial Pharmacy, Massachusetts College of Pharmacy, Boston, MA, 02115, United States
Abstract: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is proposing that a satisfactory three-month stability testing of a drug product at 37 to 40 °C and 75% or higher relative humidity can be employed to project a tentative expiry date of two years from the date of manufacture. This proposal is theoretically analyzed and its limitation is established. A successful projection of the expiry date according to FDA's proposal depends on the drug level at the end of the accelerated stability testing, the activation energy, and the temperature of the accelerated condition and the normal storage condition. The applicability of this method in assessing the stability characteristics of pharmaceutical formulations in the development process is discussed. © 1980 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.
Index Keywords: ascorbic acid; atropine; paracetamol; procaine penicillin; drug analysis; drug stability; humidity; temperature; theoretical study

Title: Digester methane utilization can be optimized
Affiliations: Envirex Inc., Waukesha, Wis., United States
Authors with affiliations: Baumann, P.G., Envirex Inc., Waukesha, Wis., United States
Abstract: The expense of exploiting digester gas as an energy source can now be justified, especially if digester heating requirements are reduced. In the past the gas was seen as a free fuel source and little effort was made to reduce the energy required for digester heating. The small amount of gas available after meeting the digester heating requirements was not worth exploiting and was burned into the atmosphere. Depending on the utilization pattern (engines that drive process blowers, pumps, electric generators or boilers) digester heat requirements and incoming sludge requirements differ. Digester heat losses must be looked at if optimization is to be achieved; tank insulation and insulation of the tank-wall play an important part in minimising heat losses. Proper design of gas storage facilities also is important as is gas safety equipment and selection of standby heating capabilities for digester start up or for periods when the engines are down for servicing or repairs. A final paragraph on engine selection concludes the paper. Spark ignited and dual fuel engines are most commonly used for digester gas. A standby fuel supply ensures continuous engine operation during a period of digest gas production failure. Because of the condensation potential engines requiring high inlet gas pressure (turbocharged feed systems) should be avoided.
Index Keywords: methane; digestion; digestive system; methodology; prevention; sewage treatment; sludge; therapy

Title: Ferroelectricity in the arterial wall: A new physical component of atherosclerosis
Affiliations: Institute for Materials Research, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Boldrini, P., Institute for Materials Research, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: The appearance of two electric potentials in the aorta is explained by the blood pulse and the remote steps of atherosclerosis are elucidated from the physical point of view. When the first C-C-2W is deposited in the intimamedia, the primary cause of their retention is the stress-induced polarization of the membrane. C-C-2W possesses a permanent dipole moment which may be reversed by the field produced by the radial expansion/contraction of the arteries. The initial C-C-2W increases the polarization of the aorta walls, favoring accumulation of more oriented material on top of the first. C-C-2W is also ferroelectric and constitutes a polar continuum with the membranes. By the time fatty streaks appear, the entire aorta wall is ferroelectric and energy has been stored in the walls under the form of residual polarization. This storage gradually destroys the wall, leading to aneurism. The biological significance of the new theory is summarized in Table 2. © 1980, All rights reserved.

Title: Effects of accounting rules on utility choices of energy technologies in the United States.
Source title: Research Report, International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis
Affiliations: Nuclear Engineering Dept., Oregon State Univ.USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Spinrad, B.I., Nuclear Engineering Dept., Oregon State Univ.USA., United States
Abstract: Monetary inflation does not change the values of commodities relative to each other, therefore, it would be expected that a comparison of the cost of technological options would not be inflation-dependent. This is borne out by the fact that when systems are compared using three different methods. These three methods are used to compare five systems that supply electrical power: 1) Light-water reactors (LWR); 2) Liquid-metal fast-breeder reactors (LMFBR); 3) Coal plants, with scrubbers, burning low-sulfur or processed high-sulfur coal (CS); 4) Coal plants, with fluidized- bed combustion of high-sulfur coal (CFB); 5) Solar power plants with sufficient storage for base-load use (SS). The cost comparison shows that: 1) LWR has a decisive cost advantage over coal; 2) It target costs are met, LMFBR would be the cheapest system; 3) If target costs are met, SS is almost competitive with the nuclear systems, and is much cheaper than coal.-from Author

Title: Britain builds a new energy mountain ( HEP).
Authors with affiliations: Acker, F.
Abstract: An illustrated description of the Dinorwic pumped-storage scheme and discussion of the use of such schemes to provide peak-load generation both by CEGB and other utilties throughout the world. -from CEGB Digest
Index Keywords: Dinorwic pumped storage scheme; hydro electric power; UK

Title: Solar energy utilization by carbanion photolysis
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fox, M.A., Department of Chemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Singletary, N.J., Department of Chemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: Photolysis of a variety of hydrocarbon anions with visible or long wavelength UV light leads to several classes of photoreactions. Orbital topology-controlled anionic photorearrangements and the occurrence of photoinduced electron transfers may be general pathways for anionic excited states. These reactions find application in the utilization of solar energy either in photochemical energy storage reactions or in photoelectrochemical cells. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; PHOTOREACTIONS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: A study on hydrogen storage by use of cryoadsorbents
Affiliations: DFVLR-Institute for Technical Physics, Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Carpetis, C., DFVLR-Institute for Technical Physics, Stuttgart, Germany; Peschka, W., DFVLR-Institute for Technical Physics, Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: This paper reports investigations on the techniques and economics of hydrogen storage by means of cryoadsorption. Also a comparison with alternative storage methods is included. The hydrogen storage capacity of several adsorbents in the temperature range 65-150 K has been investigated experimentally. Based on these data, economics and operating conditions for minimum total costs of the system are calculated. Utilization-factor and capacity-factor parameters are shown to be decisive for outlining the favourable ranges of application for competitive hydrogen storage methods. © 1980.
Index Keywords: CRYOGENICS; ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROGEN

Authors: Di Mauro S., Trevisan C., Hays A.
Title: Disorders of lipid metabolism in muscle
Affiliations: H. Houston Merritt Clinical Research Center for Muscular Dystrophy and Related Diseases, Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Di Mauro, S., H. Houston Merritt Clinical Research Center for Muscular Dystrophy and Related Diseases, Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York, New York, United States; Trevisan, C., H. Houston Merritt Clinical Research Center for Muscular Dystrophy and Related Diseases, Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York, New York, United States; Hays, A., H. Houston Merritt Clinical Research Center for Muscular Dystrophy and Related Diseases, Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York, New York, United States
Abstract: At rest and during sustained exercise, lipids are the main source of energy for muscle. Free fatty acids become available to muscle from plasma free fatty acids and triglycerides, and from intracellular triglyceride lipid droplets. Transport of long‐chain fatty acyl groups into the mitochondria requires esterification and de‐esterification with carnitine by the “twin” enzymes carnitine palmityltransferase (CPT) I and II, bound to the outer and inner faces of the inner mitochondrial membrane. Carnitine deficiency occurs in two clinical syndromes. (1) In the myopathic form, there is weakness; muscle biopsy shows excessive accumulation of lipid droplets; and the carnitine concentration is markedly decreased in muscle but normal in plasma. (2) In the systemic form, there are weakness and recurrent episodes of hepatic encephalopathy; muscle biopsy shows lipid storage; and the carnitine concentration is decreased in muscle, liver, and plasma. The etiology of carnitine deficiency is not known in either the myopathic or the systemic form, but administration of carnitine or corticosteroids has been beneficial in some patients. “Secondary” carnitine deficiency may occur in patients with malnutrition, liver disease, chronic hemodialysis, and, possibly, mitochondrial disorders. CPT deficiency causes recurrent myoglobinuria, usually precipitated by prolonged exercise or fasting. Muscle biopsy may be normal or show varying degrees of lipid storage. Genetic transmission is probably autosomal recessive, but the great male predominance (20/21) remains unexplained. In many cases, lipid storage myopathy is not accompanied by carnitine or CPT deficiency, and the biochemical error remains to be identified. Copyright © 1980 Houghton Mifflin Professional Publishers
Index Keywords: carnitine palmitoyltransferase; carnitine deficiency; central nervous system; hepatic encephalopathy; lipid metabolism; liver; muscle; review; Acyl Coenzyme A; Adolescent; Adult; Carnitine; Carnitine O-Palmitoyltransferase; Exertion; Fasting; Fatty Acids, Nonesterified; Human; Lipid Metabolism, Inborn Errors; Muscles; Muscular Diseases; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: Stabilization of liposome bilayers to freezing and thawing: Effects of cryoprotective agents and membrane proteins
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Douglass College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, New Jersey, 08903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strauss, G., Department of Chemistry, Douglass College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, New Jersey, 08903, United States; Ingenito, E.P., Department of Chemistry, Douglass College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, New Jersey, 08903, United States
Abstract: Lipid bilayer vesicles (liposomes) with and without glycoprotein incorporated into the membranes were tested for stability during freezing and thawing, in presence and absence of the cryoprotective agents (CPA) glycerol and dimethyl sulfoxide. Changes in turbidity and loss of energy transfer between fluorescent probes present in the bilayers were used to estimate membrane integrity. Freezing caused a 30 to 40% destruction of protein-free liposomes, in absence of CPA. CPA at 10 to 20% concentration prevented such losses, but at higher concentrations destabilized liposomes even without freezing. Protein-containing liposomes suffered no loss on freezing in absence or presence of CPA at moderate concentrations. Lowering of the storage temperature of frozen samples within the range of −5 to −27 °C increased the freeze damage. Slower rates of cooling and warming caused a slightly greater loss. The results are interpreted in terms of the liquid mosaic model for lipid bilayers. CPA at higher concentrations destabilize bilayers by dissolving phospholipids. At moderate concentrations, however, they prevent the damaging effect of dehydration of the lipid on freezing. Proteins appear to stabilize bilayers by providing increased hydration at the membrane surface, and by additional hydrophobic binding in the membrane interior. © 1980, All rights reserved.

Title: Energy impact analysis in water project planning.
Source title: Journal of the Water Resources Planning and Management Division ASCE, 106(WR1), Proc. Paper
Authors with affiliations: Hagan, R.M.; Roberts, E.B.
Abstract: Energy analysis of water development and use projects should be an integral part of planning to avoid projects with unnecessarily high energy requirements. However, energy analyses need great care, taking into account the different boundaries that can be drawn around the problems the need to use consistent energy units, and the need to make a variety of assumptions where data are inadequate. Illustrates many problems and shows how different conclusions can be reached depending on the elements included in an analysis. Examples are presented of energy analyses of water storage and diversion projects, the effects of water quality, and wastewater treatment and reuse. -from ASCE Publications Abstracts

Title: International management of the Columbia ( United States).
Source title: Conflicts over the Columbia River. Proc. seminar, Water Resources Research Institute, Oregon State University, Corvallis, Spring 1980,
Authors with affiliations: Muckleston, K.W.
Abstract: An agreement between the US and Canada for the cooperative management of the Columbia River was developed over two decades, involving the provision and operation of storage reservoirs in Canada. By the early 1950's, it was evident that utilities in the Pacific Northwest would have difficulty meeting the growing peak demands for electrical energy during the fall and winter seasons. Shortfalls in the planned additional increments of upstream storage were at the root of the problem. In 1959, after 15 years of study, the International Joint commission presented alternative plans for development, noting that storage sites in Canada could be operated to the benefit of both countries. The Commission also calculated an apportionment of the costs/benefits to each country.-from Selected Water Resources Abstracts
Index Keywords: Canada; Pacific Northwest; US; water resource planning

Authors: Ozawa T., Kamimoto M., Sakamoto R., Takahashi Y., Kanari K.
Title: PRELIMINARY EXAMINATION OF LATENT HEAT-THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE MATERIALS - 2. SCREENING OF EUTECTIC MIXTURES OVER A RANGE FROM 80 degree C TO 500 degree C FROM VIEWPOINTS OF ENERGY DENSITY AND MATERIAL COST.
Source title: Bulletin of the Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tokyo
Authors with affiliations: Ozawa, T.; Kamimoto, M.; Sakamoto, R.; Takahashi, Y.; Kanari, K.
Abstract: This investigation of latent heat-thermal energy storage materials examines eutectic mixtures with large entropy of fusion over the range 80 degree C to 500 degree C. The latent heats of the mixtures are estimated on assumption of additivity of the entropy. The density and the cost are also estimated based on the additivity. Promising and inexpensive eutectic mixtures are selected by energy density and material cost criteria. These mixtures are mainly composed of chlorides or hydroxides. A list of references showing phase diagrams related to the promising materials is given.

Title: Tidal power from rectangular estuaries: tidal dynamics constraints.
Source title: Journal of the Hydraulics Division, ASCE
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, I.S.; Perry, J.M.
Abstract: A 1-dimensional analytical model of frictional tidal flow in rectangular uniform section estuaries is presented. The response of different lengths of estuary to given tidal forcing at the mouth is explored to obtain resonance curves, and the linearized friction coefficient appropriate to different tidal amplitudes is indicated. A permeable, energy extracting barrier is introduced and the optimum head/flow ratio is determined for maximum power generation with an ebb/flood operating scheme. Pumped energy storage is introdiced by allowing for a complex head/flow ratio and the maximum available net power at optimum design condition is shown to be very much greater than without pumping. The mouth is shown to be the best location. The energy available under various operating constraints, from estuaries of different lengths, is compared with the original energy dissipation in the estuaries. Finally the critical dependence of power output on the choice of barrier flow condition is explored. -from ASCE Publications Abstracts

Title: Strategic petroleum reserves: billion dollar project to provide energy security for USA, Part 1 and 2.
Authors with affiliations: Seltz-Petrash, A.E.
Abstract: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve, created in 1975, is intended to provide security to the US by storing 750 M barrels of crude oil in salt domes in Louisiana and Texas. Since 1976, 248 M barrels of storage have been created and withdrawal and distribution facilities built, and 91.7 M barrels of crude are in storage. Part 1 is an overview of engineering and construction highlights on this fast-track project. For example: how to store 75 M barrels of oil in an old salt mine while a new salt mine operates a few hundred feet away. Part 2: 'Mired Management Delays Oil Reserves,' explores project problems that resulted from confused management and an unclear perception of the magnitude of the project. Some of the problems include: substantial cost overruns, permitting problems, and schedule delays so serious that only 1.5 the projected storage capacity has been built. from ASCE Publications Abstracts
Index Keywords: crude oil; Louisiana; salt domes; Texas

Authors: Wang F.C., Odum H.T., Kangas P.C.
Title: Energy analysis for environmental impact assessment.
Source title: Journal of the Water Resources Planning and Management Division, ASCE, 106(WR2), Proc. Paper
Authors with affiliations: Wang, F.C.; Odum, H.T.; Kangas, P.C.
Abstract: Determining the environmental input to the economy can be viewed as a process of evaluating different kinds of energy inputs, and then converting them into an equivalent impact is aided by energy analysis method. The procedure is used to evaluate quantitatively the proposed changes in environmental conditions and distinguish between alternatives. A hypothetical power plant siting problem is chosen to illustrate used for ranking land use alternatives. The energy embodied in environmental flows is used as a measure of potential contribution to the economy; and the energy removed from environmental storages is considered as the energy required for replacement. Results of the quantitative assessment show that the preferable choice of plant location, based on economic potentials and depletion of natural resources is different. -from ASCE Publications Abstracts

Title: Load management economics with pumped storage ( energy- generation).
Source title: Journal of Energy Division, ASCE, 106(EY1), Proc. Paper
Authors with affiliations: Scherer, C.R.
Abstract: A general mixed-integer programming model of an electrical power generation system with several load and generation centers is formulated and used to analyze the impact of different levels of load management on the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation power system. The potential of load management for reducing the need for more power plant capacity and expensive fossil peaking fuel is well-established. For various levels of load management, the analysis provides quantitative estimates of the magnitude of reduction in systems average costs and also the degree of reduction in the role of pumped storage in the system. Model results are used in a benefit-cost analysis of different degrees of metering as a potential load management measure. The general model and analytical approach is suitable for application to other systems that include pumped storage facilities. -from ASCE Publications Abstracts

Title: A self-sustained oscillatory flow phenomenon in two-phase condensing flow systems
Affiliations: Oakland University, Rochester, MI, 48063, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhatt, B.L., Oakland University, Rochester, MI, 48063, United States; Wedekind, G.L., Oakland University, Rochester, MI, 48063, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of an experimental and theoretical investigation of an unstable flow phenomenon that leads to sustained limit-cycle type of oscillations of large amplitude, and which under certain conditions, can involve flow reversals. This unstable behavior normally exists for conditions of low outlet throttling. Upstream compressible volume and downstream inertia appear to be the dominant energy storage mechanisms for the self-sustained oscillations. A linearized analysis based on the system mean void fraction model successfully predicts the experimentally observed stability boundary. © 1980 by ASME.

Title: Design of Energy-Storage Reactors for Single-Winding Constant-Frequency DC-to-DC Converters Operating in the Discontinuous-Reactor-Current Mode

Abstract: This paper presents an algorithm and equations for designing the energy-storage reactor for dc-to-dc converters which are constrained to operate in the discontinuous-reactor-current mode. This design procedure applies to the three widely used single-winding configurations: the voltage step-up, the current step-up, and the voltage-or-current step-up converters. Abstract: The principle of converting solar energy directly into electricity is now practically feasible. In order to obtain a reliable source of power from such an intermittent power supply as the sun, some form of storage is necessary. Several methods of storage are reviewed. The particular advantages of using battery storage for solar systems are discussed and a method of designing such a system is analysed. The expected demands on such a battery are discussed, along with the battery developments needed in order to satisfactorily meet such demands. © 1980, All rights reserved.

Abstract: A computation method for determining the optimal size of a solar heating plant according to the criterion of minimising its total (capital plus running) cost is described. The resulting computer program calculates the energy output of a solar system as a function of the collector area and of the heat storage unit capacity, starting from daily averages of climatic data in the localities considered. It predicts the optimal configuration and provides for it an overall cost-benefit analysis. © 1980, All rights reserved.

Authors: Kaushik N.D., Bansal P.K., Sodha M.S.
Title: Partitioned solar pond collector/storage system
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushik, N.D., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Bansal, P.K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Sodha, M.S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of the performance of a partitioned solar pond as a large-scale solar energy collection and long-term storage system for power production, as well as other applications. The absorption of solar radiation as it passes through the pond water is considered and an evaluation is made of the resulting temperature and heat fluxes at various levels in the pond during its year-round operation by solving the Fourier heat conduction equation, with appropriate boundary conditions, in different zones of the pond. This evaluation, combined with energy balance considerations, enables an expression for the transient rate at which heat can be retrieved—in order to keep the temperature of the convective zone constant—to be derived. Numerical calculations, corresponding to solar heat flux and atmospheric air temperature measurements carried out in New Delhi during 1974, are made and the optimisation of the sizes of the non-convective and convective zones in the pond is investigated. Optimal heat retrieval efficiencies of 42%, 33·5%, 29·5% and 26·5% are predicted at extraction temperatures of 40°C, 60°C, 80°C and 100°C, respectively. However, the load levelling improves as the non-convective zone is oversized. A phase difference of about 30 to 45 days is also noted between the incident solar flux and the heat retrieved when the size of the non-convective zone is near its optimum. The efficiency of the solar-pond system for converting solar energy into mechanical work is also studied. This efficiency is found to increase with collection temperature and to tend to level off at collection temperatures above 90°C. © 1980, All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Henderson J.B., Wiebelt J.A., Parker J.D.
Title: Use of solar energy for heating asphalt in storage tanks

Abstract: A solar-heated asphalt storage system has been constructed and operated for two years. The solar radiation, asphalt and ambient temperatures, auxiliary heat and differential collector temperature were monitored for the first year of operation. From these data the daily fluctuation in the emulsion temperature, the daily total solar radiation and the daily total auxiliary heat were determined. © 1980, All rights reserved.

Authors: Ikeda H., Nishikawa K., Matsuo T.
Title: Feeding responses of Zucker fatty rat to 2-deoxy-D-glucose, norepinephrine, and insulin
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Endocrinology and Metabolism
Affiliations: Biol. Res. Lab., Cent. Res. Div., Takeda Chem. Indust., Osaka 532, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ikeda, H., Biol. Res. Lab., Cent. Res. Div., Takeda Chem. Indust., Osaka 532, Japan; Nishikawa, K., Biol. Res. Lab., Cent. Res. Div., Takeda Chem. Indust., Osaka 532, Japan; Matsuo, T., Biol. Res. Lab., Cent. Res. Div., Takeda Chem. Indust., Osaka 532, Japan
Abstract: From the pathophysiological viewpoint, feeding responses to various stimuli were examined in Zucker fatty rats and their lean littermates. Intraventricular administration of norepinephrine (NE, 10 μg/rat) stimulated food intake in both rats. Intraventricular administration of 2-deoxy-D-glucose (2DG, 3.8 mg/rat) induced hyperphagia and concomitant hyperglycemia in lean rats. However, in fatty rats, the blood glucose was elevated but food intake was unaltered after 2DG administration. Subcutaneous administration of insulin (2 or 8 U/kg) stimulated food intake of both rats. Streptozotocin (STZ)-induced hypoinsulinemia produced transient reduction of food intake followed by sustained diabetic hyperphagia in lean rats. In fatty rats, the experimental hypoinsulinemia caused transient aphagia but not sustained diabetic hyperphagia. Daily injection of insulin (5 U/rat) restored energy assimilation in both diabetic rats. An increase in food intake due to insulin injection was remarkable only in diabetic fatty rats. From these findings, the regulatory system of food intake in fatty rats appears to be sensitive to changes in the circulating insulin level but insensitive to either glucoprivation or changes in body storage of energy.
