Title: A heat pump and thermal storage system for solar heating and cooling based on the reaction of calcium chloride and methanol vapor
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: EIC Corporation, Newton, MA, 02158, United States; Sandia Laboratories, Livermore, CA, 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Offenhartz, P.O.D., EIC Corporation, Newton, MA, 02158, United States; Brown, F.C., EIC Corporation, Newton, MA, 02158, United States; Mar, R.W., Sandia Laboratories, Livermore, CA, 94550, United States; Carling, R.W., Sandia Laboratories, Livermore, CA, 94550, United States
Abstract: Thermodynamic, kinetic, heat transfer and mass transfer data are presented on the reaction of CaCl2 and CH3OH vapor to form solid-phase CaCl2˙2CH3OH. These data demonstrate the suitability of the reaction for storing solar energy, and for pumping heat, either for use in space heating (at a solar coefficient of performance > 1), air conditioning, or both. CaCl2reacts with CH3OH to form CaCl2˙2CH3OH with an enthalpy and entropy of reaction 51.7 kJ (mole CH3OH) -' and 126 J deg-1 (mole CH3OH)-1, respectively. Reaction kinetics close to equilibrium are complex, although the reaction is first order when the temperature of the reacting salt is far from equilibrium. Heat transfer through the salt appears to follow the Russel equation, and reaction rates are not limited by mass transfer in a well-designed system. In the heating mode, a solar coefficient of performance (COP) of about 1.6 should be achievable if the entire heat of CH3OH condensation is used; this could permit a substantial reduction in solar collector area for a given amount of heat delivered to the load. In the cooling mode, the COP should be about 0.6. The system should be capable of pumping heat from an ambient source of 0°C to an indoor air duct temperature above 40°C, or from an indoor chiller at 5°C to an outdoor ambient air sink. The required solar collector temperature is below 140° C, and the energy storage density is about 4 × 10s kJ m-3. © 1980 by ASME.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Parr A.D., Molz F.J., Anderson P.F.
Title: Hot-water aquifer storage: a field test.
Authors with affiliations: Parr, A.D.; Molz, F.J.; Anderson, P.F.
Abstract: The basic water injection cycle used in a large-scale field study of heat storage in a confined aquifer near Mobile , Alabama is described. (A)
Index Keywords: Energy storage

Title: Large wind turbine generators (WTGs) for electrical utility application.
Source title: IN: PROC. 11TH WORLD ENERGY CONF., (MUNICH, FED. REP. GERMANY: SEP.8-12, 1980)
Volume: 1 A, London, U.K., 11th World Energy Conf., 1980, Section 1.2, p.550-568.
Authors with affiliations: Quraeshi, S.
Abstract: Current trends in the design and development of large wind turbine generators were discussed. Requirements for electrical utility use were discussed in relation to the quality of electrical power generated, modes of application, energy storage and the amount of penetration permitted. Their operation and integration into utility networks and economic characteristics were also examined. (H.C.B.)
Index Keywords: Review

Title: A computer mathematical model for gas-particle two-phase flows.
Source title: IN: MULTIPHASE TRANSPORT: FUNDAMENTALS, REACTOR SAFETY, APPLICATIONS, T.N. VEZIROGLU (ED.)
Volume: 4 , Washington, U.S.A., Hemisphere Publishing Corp., 1980, p.2011-2026.
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, M.P.; Crowe, C.T.
Abstract: The analysis of two-phase flows is complicated by a number of physical and mathematical difficulties such as coupling of mass, momentum and energy transfers, complex set of governing equations, the questionable adequacy of the mathematics of continua, and the need for excessive storage requirements to account for a distribution of particle sizes. This paper describes a numerical model, PSI-Cell (Particle-Source-In-Cell) model, for steady two-dimensional two-phase turbulent flows which circumvents these problems and provides a solution procedure adequate for engineering applications. The model is applied to the flow of a gas-solid mixture through an orifice. The model can be easily extended to gas-droplet flow calculations. (from authors abstract)
Index Keywords: Numerical methods

Title: Testing rock salt for compressed air energy storage.
Abstract: R.L. Thoms Louisiana State Univ., U.S.A. Compressed air energy storage (CAES) in salt caverns, currently used in West Germany and also being considered in the United States, induces cyclic pressure and thermal effects in the salt surrounding the caverns. A testing program is described for determining long-term response of rock salt to the cyclic effects associated with typical CAES operating cycles. The program, now in progress, incorporates complementary laboratory and in-situ salt mine tests. Results test data will furnish a basis for long-term CAES cavern stability criteria. (A)

Title: ATP-induced hyperpolarization of smooth muscle cells of the guinea-pig coronary artery
Source title: Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics
Affiliations: Dept. Pharmacol., Fac. Med., Kyushu Univ., Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takata, Y., Dept. Pharmacol., Fac. Med., Kyushu Univ., Fukuoka, Japan; Kuriyama, H., Dept. Pharmacol., Fac. Med., Kyushu Univ., Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: ATP and AMP-PNP markedly hyperpolarized the muscle membrane of the coronary artery, although response was slight with AMP and nil with adenosine. The hyperpolarization might not be due to utilization of energy liberated by hydration of the energy-rich phosphate bond. In low [Na]0, the membrane was hyperpolarized and ATP induced hyperpolarization further, although in low [Ca]0, the membrane was depolarized and the amplitude of the ATP-induced hyperpolarization became less. In low [Cl]0, the membrane was hyperpolarized, but the peak amplitude of the ATP-induced hyperpolarization remained the same. In low [K]0, the membrane potential was not modified, but the peak amplitude of the ATP-induced hyperpolarization was markedly increased. The maximum slope of the membrane potential changes produced by 10-fold change in [K]0 plotted on a log scale was 31 mV in the presence of 3 x 10-4 M ATP, and this slope was 45 mV in 10-3 M ATP measured in the range of 5.9 to 23.6 mM. In high [K]0, ATP did not hyperpolarize the membrane. The reversal potential level for ATP was observed in the range of -71 to -75 mV. In low [Ca]0, the duration of the ATP-induced hyperpolarization was markedly reduced. The ATP-induced hyperpolarization was classified into two components; the fast phase being less sensitive to Ca and the subsequent slow Ca sensitive phase which was blocked in the presence of low [Ca]0 or MnCl2. ATP and adenosine relaxed the tissue in the presence of high [K]0 or acetylcholine. These results suggest that ATP mainly increases the K-conductance and in part the Na-conductance of the membrane. Presumably, ATP suppresses the Ca-mobilization from the storage site rather than the Ca-influx.
Index Keywords: acetylcholine; adenosine phosphate; adenosine triphosphate; adenylylimidodiphosphate; atropine; calcium; ouabain; propranolol; purine derivative; animal experiment; cardiovascular system; coronary artery; drug comparison; drug response; guinea pig; heart; in vitro study; smooth muscle fiber membrane potential; Acetylcholine; Adenosine; Adenosine Monophosphate; Adenosine Triphosphate; Adenylyl Imidodiphosphate; Animal; Calcium; Chlorides; Coronary Vessels; Female; Guinea Pigs; In Vitro; Male; Membrane Potentials; Muscle, Smooth, Vascular; Osmolar Concentration; Potassium; Sodium

Title: The prospects for solar energy use in industry within the United Kingdom
Affiliations: International Institute for Environment and Development, London, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, C.W., International Institute for Environment and Development, London, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: An assessment of the potential for solar energy applications within U.K. industry has been made, using a disaggregated breakdown of energy consumption in the eight industrial sectors by fuel and end-use, and taking account of solar collector performance under U.K. climatic conditions. Solar contributions of 35 per cent of process boiler heat up to a temperature of 80°C and 10 per cent in the 80-120°C range are considered feasible, along with 35 per cent of non-industrial water heating. After employing energy conservation techniques currently more cost-effective than solar systems, an additional 3.5 per cent of U.K. primary energy expended in manufacturing industry (excluding iron and steel production) could be contributed by solar. This represents 1 per cent of the U.K. national primary energy demand. Improvements in collector efficiency, less costly interseasonal energy storage systems, and the changing pattern of U.K. industry could increase this percentage considerably. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Energy storage in aquifers: a survey of recent theoretical studies.
Authors with affiliations: Tsang, C.F.; Claeson, J.
Abstract: The disparity between energy production and demand has led to increased research into the use of aquifers for the long-term, large-scale storage of thermal energy. Currently, there are several field experiments and feasibility studies under way in which the technical, economic, and environmental aspects storage are being researched. Recent theoretical efforts in aquifer storage research and the impact their results may have on these field projects are reviewed. Major work is highlighted according to three categories: (1) semianalytic studies, (2) numerical modeling studies, and (3) site-specific studies.

Authors: Williams G.T., Attwater C.R., Hooper F.C.
Title: A design method to determine the optimal distribution and amount of insulation for in-ground heat storage tanks
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Toronto, 5 King's College Rd, Toronto, Ont. M5S 1A4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Williams, G.T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Toronto, 5 King's College Rd, Toronto, Ont. M5S 1A4, Canada; Attwater, C.R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Toronto, 5 King's College Rd, Toronto, Ont. M5S 1A4, Canada; Hooper, F.C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Toronto, 5 King's College Rd, Toronto, Ont. M5S 1A4, Canada
Abstract: The seasonal sensible heat storage model developed by Hooper and Attwater [1] is modified to describe the thermal behaviour of the soil regime surrounding cylindrical, in-ground, heat storage tanks with optimally distributed insulation. The model assumes steady-state heat transfer, and the surrounding soil is considered to be homogeneous and isotropic. Changes in soil thermal properties due to moisture migration, whether driven by thermal or hydrostatic gradients, are assumed negligible [2]. The optimal distribution is determined using the method of Lagrange multipliers. It is shown that the marginal cost per unit of energy lost and per unit of tank surface area must be the same at all points on the surface of the tank as the condition for minimum total heat loss with a given total investment in insulation. This condition appears to apply for all axi-symmetric in-ground tank geometries. For a given volume of insulation, the incremental increase in storage efficiency with an optimal redistribution of the insulation is a function of tank geometry. The problem of determining the optimal total investment in insulation for a given marginal cost of fuel is described and a method of solution is outlined. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Mathematical Models; HEAT TRANSFER; SOLAR ENERGY; HEAT STORAGE TANKS; HEATING

Title: Ground‐Water Use for Cooling: Associated Aquifer Temperature Changes
Affiliations: Earth Sciences Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lippmann, M.J., Earth Sciences Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States; Tsang, C.F., Earth Sciences Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States
Abstract: In steam‐electric power plants, large volumes of surface waters are used for cooling the plant's condensers. There, approximately two‐thirds of the energy produced by the fuel is removed as waste heat. This heat is carried away by the cooling waters, is dispersed into the atmosphere or surface‐water bodies, and is lost for other potential uses. When condenser cooling systems such as towers or ponds are used, there is also a considerable net loss of water through evaporation. Injection and storage of spent cooling waters underground would reduce the evaporative (consumptive) losses to the atmosphere. Later, these waters could be recovered for use in heating and in industrial or agricultural applications. The resulting conservation of energy and water may make such a project economically feasible in the near future as the costs of water and fuel increase. In this paper, we review the use of ground water from a confined aquifer for this application and analyze a simple configuration of one withdrawal and one injection well to determine: (1) the areal extent of temperature changes caused by reinjection of spent cooling waters into the aquifer from which they originated; and (2) how long it would take for the water to become too hot to use for cooling. Copyright © 1980, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Index Keywords: Aquifers; WATER RESOURCES - Groundwater; Water wells; Water cooling systems

Title: Wind energy in Senegal: geographical repartition.
Authors with affiliations: Gourieres, D.
Abstract: The paper discusses wind energy in Senegal, focussing on wind velocity and direction, including maximum wind speeds, wind speed frequencies, and the variations of speed with altitude. The importance of calm spells is highlighted because the period must be covered by storage when the smaller wind driven plants are used autonomously. (R.M.)

Authors: Tsang C.F., Hopkins D., Hellstroem G.
Title: Aquifer thermal energy storage: a survey.
Authors with affiliations: Tsang, C.F.; Hopkins, D.; Hellstroem, G.
Abstract: The technical, economic, and environmental aspects of aquifer storage were investigated. The state of the art of various projects associated with aquifer storage technology were surveyed with emphasis on three broad categories: field experiments; feasibility studies; and theoretical and modeling studies.
Index Keywords: Energy storage

Title: Thermal energy storage design criteria.
Authors with affiliations: DeVries, J.
Abstract: This paper describes a follow-on effort to a study carried out by Hittman Associates, Inc', (HAI) , entitled Solar Application of Thermal Energy Storage' The current effort concentrates on design requirements of thermal storage subsystems for active solar cooling systems. Absorption, Rankine, and desiccant cooling technologies are being examined. The paper summarizes the results of the earlier study and describes the project methodology the current effort. (A)

Title: Small hydroelectric project manual for Appalachian New York.
Abstract: A major New York State energy goal is reducing dependence on expensive, imported oil. Through-out the Appalachian Region of New York State there are existing dam sites that have potential for development as small/low-head hydroelectric generating plants. These hydroelectric sites include those with abandoned generating facilities as well as those which were constructed for purposes such as flood control, navigation, and water storage. To encourage and assist efforts to develop these sites, this manual has been prepared to help identify those sites that have potential for hydroelectric power generation and to provide guide-lines for the performance of preliminary feasibility assessments of the sites. The manual guildelines will assist municipal officials, planners, and others who do not have hydroelectrical enegineering backgrounds in estimating the generating capacities and approximate power generating costs of small hydroelectic power installations. Legal, regulatory, and institutional issues affecting small hydroelectric power facilities have also been identified, and discussions of various approaches to these problems are included.

Authors: Menzies R.W., Mathur R.M., Bullock W.R.
Title: Alternator designs for direct coupling to remote wind energy systems.
Authors with affiliations: Menzies, R.W.; Mathur, R.M.; Bullock, W.R.
Abstract: The mechanical power available from the shaft of the wind turbine is not suitable for direct use by conventional alternators or generators. The reasons being that the shaft speed is very low, especially as the power rating increases, and the shaft power varies as the cube of the shaft speed. In the past, this problem has been solved by the use of gears and several alternators and/or generators to match and wide power range of the turbine. This has led to reduced efficiency and reliability of the overall system. This paper will examine the desirable performance specifications of direct-drive alternators suitable for meeting diverse load requirements and compare adaptations of several conventional generators/alternators with several novel designs. (A) Considerable research and development on the vertical axis wind turbine has taken place in Canada during the last decade. The applicability of such an energy source, especially in the Arctic, has been proven by such installations as the Beaufort Sea automatic meteorological station. The main application of these wind turbines appear to be in the supply of electrical energy either for storage or as the transmission link between the turbine and electric motors.

Authors: Edie D.D., Melsheimer S.S., Mills A.D.
Title: Extended cycling behavior of a direct contact-phase change TES storage.
Authors with affiliations: Edie, D.D.; Melsheimer, S.S.; Mills, A.D.
Abstract: The use of direct contact heat transfer in latent heat energy storage systems is proposed as a means of combating phase segregation problems and enhancing heat and mass transfer performance in such systems. Recent studies at Clemson University show that several salt hydrates perform satisfactorily, and that acceptable heat transfer fluids are available. Studies of system geometry and heat transfer performance, as well as of crystal growth velocity, are also performed. The results obtained on a 2001 prototype unit which provides performance information under realistic operating conditions are reported. (A)
Index Keywords: thermal energy storage

Title: Screw compressor or electric heat pump sytems for space conditioning applications.
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, D.N.
Abstract: The relationship between the screw compressor and various types of heat pump systems is discussed in detail. The operating characteristics of various screw compressor configurations are compared along with a discussion of the general application range of screw compressors both from the present day and future potential viewpoints. The Dunham-Bush multiple source heat pump rationale is discussed. A typical operating sequence covering both winter and summertime operation is described in a manner which clearly demonstrates the flexibility of the screw compressor in dealing with the various necessary modes of operation. The advantages accruing to thermal energy storage and the utilization of off-peak power is discussed during the multiple source sequence description. A limited discussion of a future speed modulated multiple slide screw compressor and its further advantages to various systems is described as well. (A)

Title: Comparison of solar heat pumps system to conventional methods for residential heating, cooling, and water heating, volume 2. Final report.
Source title: MCLEAN, U.S.A., SCI. APPL. INC., APR. 1980
Authors with affiliations: Hughes, P.J.; Morehouse, J.H.
Abstract: thermal comfort, models were formulated to force this requirement on all systems. The thermal performance maps (fraction of the load met with free energy versus collector area) presented include the effects of the comfort requirement and of parasitic energy consumption for blower and pump operation. Economic comparisons were made after sizing collectors and storage for the combined solar heat pump systems in a manner which was sensitive to climate as well as to the thermal and economic characteristics of each particular system. This, combined with life cycle cost analysis, allows collector cost goals to be established which if met will allow combined solar heat pump systems to compete with conventional alternatives. Since the purpose of space conditioning equipment is to provide

Title: A regional wind-hydro electricity supply system.
Authors with affiliations: Sorensen, B.
Abstract: The combination of a wind-based electricity generating system with a hydro-based system is investigated by use of a simulation model. The hydro-power system is an idealised version of the Norwegian system, and the wind-power system corresponds to generating all the electric power needed in Denmark by wind. A transmission capability between the two countries is assumed to allow a power transfer up to 2.5 times the maximum capacity of the present interconnections. The model has been used to simulate the performance of such a system, using wind and hydro data for the respective countries. Not only 'typical' or average years have been considered, but also the variations caused by exceptionally good or bad wind years or hydro years. It is concluded that the combined system is as dependable as the hydro system alone, and that the combination thus offers a way of large-scale electricity supply by use of wind energy, without backup or storage systems other than the hydro system. The extra transmission losses associated with the power exchange between the wind and the hydro system amounts to 8.9% of the wind energy production. (A)

Authors: Davidson B.J., Harman R.D., Hart A.B., Maddock B.J., Moffitt R.D., Newman V.G., Smith T.F., Worthington P.J., Wright J.K.
Title: Large scale energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Davidson, B.J.; Harman, R.D.; Hart, A.B.; Maddock, B.J.; Moffitt, R.D.; Newman, V.G.; Smith, T.F.; Worthington, P.J.; Wright, J.K.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: batteries; compressed-air storage; electrochemical; Flywheels; magnetic; pumped storage; Reviews

Title: Coal-fired fluid bed combustion - augmented compressed air energy storage power plants: A technical and economic assessment.
Authors with affiliations: Lessard, R.D.; Giramonti, A.J.
Abstract: This paper presents the highlights of an exploratory study program which was performed to assess the technical and economic feasibility of coal-fired fluid bed combustor (FBC) compressed ari energy storage (CAES) power plant concepts for generating peak-load electric power. Specifically, the paper reviews: the preliminary screening analyses performed to select a potentially attractive FBC/CAES system configuration; the conceptual design of a FBC/CAes power plant based upon the selected configuration; and the economic comparisons between the FBC,CAES power plant and competing alternative power plants. In addition, the paper presents results of the study program including the identification of an open-bed pressurized FBC/CAES system configuration as having the greatest near-term commercialization potential, and the indication that a power plant based upon this system configuration could produce competitive peak and mid-ranged electrical energy. (A)

Authors: Kamimoto M., Tanaka T., Tani T., Horigome T.
Title: Investigation of nitrate salts for solar latent heat storage
Affiliations: Energy Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, Japan, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kamimoto, M., Energy Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, Japan, 305, Japan; Tanaka, T., Energy Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, Japan, 305, Japan; Tani, T., Energy Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, Japan, 305, Japan; Horigome, T., Energy Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, Japan, 305, Japan
Abstract: Solar thermal applications require some means of thermal energy storage. Amongst several storage concepts, latent heat storage is quite suitable because of its high storage density and almost constant temperature during charging and discharging. The temperature range between 200 and 300°C is considered to be important for solar total energy systems. In this temperature range, sodium nitrate and its mixed salts with other nitrates including eutectic and off-eutectic salts are candidates. The present paper deals with heat transfer in a latent heat storage unit utilizing these salts. A method of rough estimation of the thermal conductivity of the storage materials is described, and the temperature history of the storage material experimentally obtained is compared with numerical solutions and found to be in reasonably good agreement. It is seen that the temperature of the heat transfer surface quickly drops soon after the appearance of a solid phase due to low thermal conductivity of these salts. Ways to avoid this temperature drop are discussed. © 1980.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; NITRATES; SOLAR ENERGY; NITRATE SALTS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Physiological control of energy balance
Affiliations: Univ. California Harbor Gen. Hosp., Torrance, Calif. 90509, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bray, G.A., Univ. California Harbor Gen. Hosp., Torrance, Calif. 90509, United States
Abstract: Physiological control of energy balance is reviewed in terms of food seeking and energy (food) intake, utilization and storage. In particular the role of hormonal and metabolic signals, as clarified by whole-body calorimetry and cellular studies, and the interaction of energy expenditure with the mechanism regulating intake are outlined.
Index Keywords: energy transfer; feeding behavior; human cell; normal human; Adolescent; Adult; Aged; Aging; Animal; Appetite Regulation; Body Weight; Calorimetry; Child; Child, Preschool; Diet; Energy Intake; Energy Metabolism; Exertion; Feeding Behavior; Female; Food; Gastrointestinal System; Hormones; Human; Hypothalamus; Male; Middle Age; Obesity

Title: Proceedings of the Materials Handling Conference on Unit and Bulk Materials Handling, held at San Francisco, U.S.A. on August 19-21, 1980.
Authors with affiliations: Loeffler, F.J.
Abstract: Subjects covered during the conference include transportation, storage, and energy related applications for bulk handling and the automation and simulation of unit handling systems. There is also a series of papers on pneumatic and slurry handling. Papers are indexed individually.

Title: Developments in solar technlogy.
Authors with affiliations: Smith, B.E.
Abstract: Solar heating in the UK; long term thermal energy storage; solar cooling, applications in lower latitude countries, and solar powered irrigation are all considered.
Index Keywords: heat engine; powered; Solar; Solar collectors

Title: More on dual purpose solar-electric power plants.
Authors with affiliations: Hall, F.F.
Abstract: Dual purpose solar-electric plants are discussed. The rationale for such plants is reviewed and plant elements are listed. Heat extraction, energy storage, and plant costs are discussed.

Title: L-180 Poseidon. A new system concept in vertical axis wind turbine technology.
Authors with affiliations: Ljungstrom, O.
Abstract: The 20 MW 'L-180 Poseidon' vertical axis wind turbine system, for Off-Shore-siting, is described, with major subsystems technology, system components weight estimate and investment cost, energy production (45 GWh/yr), total investment for Off-Shore system, 1200 MW group station 10 - 20 km from shore. For siting with median wind (at H 100 m rotor centre) 9 - 9.5 m/s, the cost of energy (electric, to shore network) is estimated at 4.3 - 4.0 c/kWh ( 1978 cost levels). A program for prototype development, ca 1/3 scale (linear) is proposed, type 'L-60', 2 MW. Modifications of the quite flexible L-180 machinery, with multiple output shafts, for alternative energy supply systems, such as mechanical (heat pumps, with heat storage, for domestic heating, combined with solar heat), air compressors, hydraulic pumps, are discussed. (A)

Title: Planning, design and operation of hydraulic machinery in the Italian energy system.
Source title: IN: IAHR 10TH SYMP. CONF. ON HYDRAULIC MACHINERY AND EQUIPMENT ASSOCIATED WITH ENERGY SYSTEMS IN THE NEW DECADE OF THE 1980'S
Authors with affiliations: Malquori, E.; Milanese, F.
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to present the more salient characteristics of hydraulic machinery in relation to both the Italian energy system and to the aggregate of hydro stations in operation, construction or planned for construction in the near future. After mentioning the evolution of hydrogeneration in Italy to date, the paper describes some interesting aspects of the design and construction of the hydraulic machinery, particularly that for pumped storage stations. A description follows of some of the major problems encountered in the operation of the hydraulic machinery and the provisions made to solve them. (A)
Index Keywords: Francis turbine; Kaplan turbine; Pelton turbine

Title: Availability of world energy resources. 2nd edn.
Authors with affiliations: Ion, D.C.
Abstract: Contents: Introduction ; resource definitions and measurement; resources; resources to reserves; proved reserves; pFoduction conversion; transportation and storage; demand; conclusions; index .

Title: Thermal energy storage systems using fluidized bed heat exchangers. Final report, Jan. 1979-Jan. 1980.
Authors with affiliations: Weast, T.; Shannon, L.
Abstract: A rotary cement kiln and an electric arc furnace were chosen for evaluation to determine the applicability of a fluid bed heat exchanger (FBHX) for thermal energy storage (TES). Multistage shallow bed FBHX's operating with high temperature differences were identified as the most suitable for TES applications. Analysis of the two selected conceptual systems included establishing a plant process flow configuration, an operational scenario, a preliminary FBHX/TES design, and parametric analysis. A computer model was developed to determine the effects of the number of stages, gas temperatures, gas flows, bed materials, charge and discharge time, and parasitic power required for operation. The maximum national energy conservation potential of the cement plant application with TES is 15.4 million barrels of oil or 3.9 million tons of coal per year. For the electric arc furnace application the maximum national conservation potential with TES is 4.5 million barrels of oil or 1.1 million tons of coal per year. Present time of day utility rates are near the breakeven point required for the TES system. Escalation of on-peak energy due to critical fuel shortages could make the FBHX/TES applications economically attractive in the future.

Title: Compressed air energy storage (CAES) environmental control concerns and program plan.
Authors with affiliations: Beckwith, M.A.; Boehm, D.W.
Abstract: Procedures, processes, systems, and strategies necessary to minimize adverse environmental impacts of compressed air energy storage are developed so as not to delay implementation of the technology. Compressed air energy storage technolgoy and the expected major environmental concerns of the technology are described. Ongoing or planned research in related programs and the applicability of results for these programs to CAES environmental research are discussed. The additional research and development required to provide the necessary environmental data base and resolve concerns in CAES are outlined. A program plan to carry out this research and development effort is presented.

Authors: Murphy L.M., Farrington R., Noreen D.
Title: Analysis of solar domestic hot water systems from a system perspective.
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, L.M.; Farrington, R.; Noreen, D.
Abstract: Six solar domestic hot water systems tested at the National Bureau of Standards have been analyzed. Results indicate that the thermosyphon system delivered the most solar energy to the load per dollar of initial investment (the air system delivered for the least) and that direct systems performed better than indirect systems. Storage losses from the double tank system were greater than expected, and this significantly reduced the relative performance of these systems. Further, the use of pumps, fans, controls, and solenoid valves in the pumped systems can reduce the net energy savings of the solar system by up to 30%. (A)

Authors: Iris P., de Marsily G., Cormary Y.
Title: Heat storage in a phreatic unconfined aquifer: the Campuget experiment.
Source title: IN: IECEC '80, PROC. 15TH INTERSOC. ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. ON ENERGY TO THE 21ST CENTURY, (SEATTLE, U.S.A.: AUG. 18-2
Volume: 2 , New York, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Aeronaut. & Astronaut., 1980, Paper No. 809249
Authors with affiliations: Iris, P.; de Marsily, G.; Cormary, Y.
Abstract: In 1977-78, 20,000 mSUB3 of water at 33SUPC were injected during the summer into a shallow phreatic aquifer at Campuget, in France, and then partly recovered to heat a greenhouse during the next winter. Although the efficiency of the recovery was low (20%), the experiment showed: - the technical difficulties associated with aquifer heat storage, and how to cope with them; - what parameters to measure and how to do it in order to predict the behaviour of any heat store in a given aquifer; - what parameters are essential when selecting a site. As a result of this research, a new method was developed which associates solar energy, heat pumps and aquifer storage for economically efficient space heating. This method is called 'heliogeothermy'.

Title: Central unresolved issues in thermal energy storage for building heating and cooling.
Authors with affiliations: Sivet, C.J.; Baylin, F.
Abstract: Issues related to applications included value-based ranking of storage concepts, temperature constraints, consistency of assumptions, nomenclature and taxomony, and screening criteria for materials. Issues related to technologies included assessing seasonal storage concepts, diurnal coolness storage, selection of hot-side storage concepts for cooling-only systems, phase-change storage in building materials, freeze protection for solar water heating systems, and justification of phase-change storage for active solar space heating.

Authors: Davison R.R., Harris W.B., Reddell D.L.
Title: Storage of cold water in aquifers.
Authors with affiliations: Davison, R.R.; Harris, W.B.; Reddell, D.L.
Abstract: The advantages and mechanism of storing winter produced cold water in an aquifer for use in summer for cooling is described. This includes computer simulation of ideal aquifers, and the results of one cycle of injection and withdrawal in an aquifer near the Texas A & M campus. Heat recovery was low because of regional flow, but otherwise performance was good. There was no evidence of well plugging, and the performance of the spray pond used to chill the water was excellent. (A)
Index Keywords: Energy storage

Title: The characteristics of liquid sloshing in a honeycomb storage tank.
Source title: RES. REP. FAC. ENGNG. MEIJI UNIV.
Authors with affiliations: Kuriyama, Y.; Fukuda, H.
Abstract: As the size of liquid storage tanks have become larger with a stronger demand for energy and an increased number of large-sized buildings, the natural periods of such tanks are closer to the predominant periods of seismic shock waves, and the possibility of resonance, liquid sloshing, with those periods gets bigger. For the purpose of preventing sloshing and momentary whole damage of the tank, a usual large tank was divided into a certain number of hexagonal tanks, each having an independent function, which were, then, integrated into a honeycomb type tank. The hexagonal tank was approximated by an inscribed cylindrical tank, and sloshing phenomena in the tank was analysed with the assumption that the liquid motion was in accordance with the velocity potential theory. The calculated values obtained by the analysis are in agreement with the experimental results responded to the sinusoidal input. (A)

Authors: Ortega J.K.E., Bingham C.E., Connolly J.M.
Title: Performance of storage walls with highly conductive covering plates and connecting films.
Authors with affiliations: Ortega, J.K.E.; Bingham, C.E.; Connolly, J.M.
Abstract: The thermal behaviour of a storage wall, constructed of concrete with highly conductive plates and connecting vertical fins, is investigated. The results demonstrate that, during the charging mode the amount of energy released from the front surface is significantly reduced. A portion of the saved energy is stored for future discharge, but a large portion is transferred to the back surface and released. A selective front surface reduces the energy released from the front surface, and this energy is stored. By properly selecting the fin spacing, plate-fin thickness, and plate fin thermal conductivity, the rate and direction of thermal discharge can be controlled. The improved heat transfer capability and added thermal control provide new alternatives for interzonal heat transfer and multizone passive building designs.

Title: South Africa - how they see it.
Authors with affiliations: Abbott, P.
Abstract: South Africans are aware that outside pressure could change their lifestyle considerably. The article examines the way in which the country is preparing to meet its energy demands from its own natural resources, with particular reference to the Sasol projects (fuel from coal), pumped storage schemes, transport and construction projects.
Index Keywords: power supply

Title: World oil industry.
Abstract: Contents : Energy management; Exploration; The Comapnies; State Corporations; U.S. Groups; The Independents; New Technology; Pipelines; Tankers; Distribution; Storage; Refineries; OPEC and The Spot Markets. (A.P.)

Title: Compressed air energy storage: preliminary design and site development program in an aquifer. Task 1: establish facility design criteria and utility benefits.
Abstract: Work performed in establishing facility design criteria for a CAES system with aquifer storage includes: determination of initial design bases; preliminary analysis of the CAES system; development of data for site-specific analysis of the CAES system; detailed analysis of the CAES system for three selected heat cycles; CAES power plant design; and an economic analysis of CAES.
Index Keywords: Compressed air; Energy storage

Authors: Svoboda J.V., Sankar S., Black W.
Title: Hybrid computer-aided design of a hydrostatic vehicle drive with energy accumulator.
Authors with affiliations: Svoboda, J.V.; Sankar, S.; Black, W.
Abstract: The use of the hybrid computing technique in the design and optimizaton of a novel hydrostatic drive for urban vehicles. The vehicle system is modelled on the analog computer whereas the optimization algorithm and overall control is performed in the digital section. The drive system consists of a small IC-engine, a hydrostatic transmission and a hydraulic accumulator energy storage. The hydraulic accumulator assists the engine during acceleration and allows for regenerative braking which results in a high overall efficiency in urban driving, where frequent stops occur. In the first stage of the design, the feasibility of the drive concept was evaluated. Thus preliminary designed systems is repeatedly 'driven' through a short driving cycle under the control of the digital computer. A direct search optimization routine evaluates the drive performance and readjusts four drive controller parameters. The objective of the optimization is to minimize the fuel consumption without any loss of drive dynamics. The comparison of the drive performance before and after optimization is presented and discussed. (A)

Title: Hydrogen technology : foreign, change 1. Report for period ending Feb. 1980.
Authors with affiliations: Busi, J.D.; Greenbaum, P.
Abstract: Hydrogen is both a promising medium for the efficient storage and transmission of energy and a potential alternate fuel. Hydrogen is not a primary energy source, however, since its production is dependent upon other energy sources (thermal, electrical, and radiant). To be practicable as a fuel, hydrogen must be produced in bulk quantities with a standardized purity that will satisfy consumer specifications. In addition, improved distribution systems must make hydrogen widely available to military, industrial, and domestic consumers if the successful evolution of a hydrogen economy is to occur. The greatest potential military impact of hydrogen lies in its use as an aviation fuel. Because of its high specific energy (124 kJ/kg--2.7 times greater than conventional aviation fuels), hydrogen has potential use as a fuel for subsonic transports, supersonic aircraft, and helicopters; however, safety measures, logistics, and storage and handling systems must be developed and standardized before this capability can be achieved. Initial experimental use of hydrogen in military aircraft may occur in the 1980s. A followup conversion and modification of aircraft and airports to hydrogen will require an additional 10 to 15 years. Secondary military interests include the use of hydrogen fuel cells for portable and transportable power generation, and its use as a propellant in aerospace applications.

Title: Underground space is our last resource.
Authors with affiliations: Donovan, P.
Abstract: A report on how Sweden is using underground space for water, oil and solar energy storage.

Authors: Famington R., Norean D., Murphy L.M.
Title: A comparing analysis of six generic solar domestic hot water systems.
Authors with affiliations: Famington, R.; Norean, D.; Murphy, L.M.
Abstract: Results are analysed from experiments on six types of solar domestic hot-water systems at the US National Bureau of Standards. Use of pumps, fans, controls and solenoid valves in the pumping systems resulted in high parasitic energy consumption. Storage losses from double-tank systems were greater than expected due to poor storage-tank insulation. Direct systems performed better than indirect systems as expected. The thermosyphon system delivered the most solar energy to the hot-water load for lowest initial cost. The air system performed poorly due to the parasitic energy consumption and poor heat transfer across the air-to-water heat exchanger. Reliable freeze protection needs to be developed for direct systems, especially thermosyphon systems, to take advantage of direct heat transfer.

Title: Chemical energy storage for solar thermal electric conversion.
Source title: IN: IECEC '80, PROC. 15TH INTERSOC. ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. ON ENERGY TO THE 21ST CENTURY, (SEATTLE, U.S.A.: AUG. 18-2
Volume: 2 , New York, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Aeronaut. & Astronaut., 1980, Paper No. 809049
Authors with affiliations: Smith, R.D.
Abstract: The technical and economic aspects of using reversible chemical reactions to store energy in Solar Thermal Electric Conversion (STEC) facilities have been studied. This paper describes the identification of nine promising chemical reactions from a list of over 550 candidates, preliminary process designs of energy storage subsystems based on these nine reactions, and comparison of cost and performance estimates based on these designs. The Chemical Energy Storage (CES) subsystems were designed for large (100 MWSUPe), central receiver STEC systems, with storage output temperatures for different storage subsystems ranging from 588K to 1,310K. (A)

Authors: Pahud P., Ravussin E., Acheson K.J., Jequier E.
Title: Energy expenditure during oxygen deficit of submaximal concentric and eccentric exercise
Source title: Journal of Applied Physiology Respiratory Environmental and Exercise Physiology
Affiliations: Inst. Physiol., Univ. Lausanne CHUV, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Pahud, P., Inst. Physiol., Univ. Lausanne CHUV, Switzerland; Ravussin, E., Inst. Physiol., Univ. Lausanne CHUV, Switzerland; Acheson, K.J., Inst. Physiol., Univ. Lausanne CHUV, Switzerland; Jequier, E., Inst. Physiol., Univ. Lausanne CHUV, Switzerland
Abstract: Aerobic (MR) and anaerobic (Ṁ(an)) energy production was determined in 5 subjects during the 1st min of concentric and eccentric exercise (steady-state energy expenditure approximately 415 W in both situations). Ṁ(an) was obtained by solving the heat balance equation, ṀR + Ṁ(an) - Ṡ = (Ṙ + Ċ + Ė) ± |Ẇ|, all other variables of which could be measured [Ṡ is heat storage; (Ṙ + Ċ +Ė) are the radiative, convective, and evaporative heat losses; and Ẇ is work output]. The size of the O2 deficit was similar whatever the type of exercise (99 ± 19 W concentric and 102 ± 19 W eccentric). ṀR + Ṁ(an) was lower than the steady-state ṀR in both types of exercise (concentric: 364 ± 19 and 407 ± 24 W, respectively, and eccentric: 346 ± 25 and 430 ± 21 W, respectively). The size of the O2 deficit during the 1st min of muscular exercise is imposed by the steady-state energy requirement whatever the type of exercise. The smaller energy expenditure during this phase is probably due to less energy being released when creatine phosphate is split without resynthesis (O2 deficit) than during splitting and resynthesis of high-energy phosphate bonds (steady state).
Index Keywords: aerobic capacity; anaerobic capacity; exercise; human cell; normal human; oxygen debt; thermometry

Title: Hydro-power: the use of water as an alternative source of energy.
Authors with affiliations: Simeons, C.
Abstract: Contents : Water and the energy gap; wave power; National wave power programmes; tidal power; tidal power development programmes; hydrogen; national hydrogen programmes; energy storage in Europe; hydro-electric schemes - Europe; Austrial-Asia and beyond hydro-electric schemes; Environmental Impact; Appendices; Bibliography; Index .

Title: Energy programs at the John Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory. Quarterly report, Oct.-Dec. 1979.
Abstract: Work in various tasks to develop energy resources, utilization concepts, and storage methods is summarized. Reports are presented in the following areas: geothermal prospecting; hydroelectric power generation in southeastern states; neotectonic investigations in Connecticut; ocean thermal energy conversion core unit testing and recovery of landfill methane; and uncoventional gas sources - Eastern devonian shales.

Authors: Prengle Jr. H.W., Hunt J.C., Mauk C.E., Sun E.C.-H.
Title: Solar energy with chemical storage for cogeneration of electric power and heat
Affiliations: Chemical Engineering Department, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Authors with affiliations: Prengle Jr., H.W., Chemical Engineering Department, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Hunt, J.C., Chemical Engineering Department, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Mauk, C.E., Chemical Engineering Department, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Sun, E.C.-H., Chemical Engineering Department, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Abstract: U.S.A. energy use by the year 2000 is estimated to be 116-130 quads, compared to 82 quads for 1978. Solar energy, utilized both at the individual residence-building level plus power plant level, along with all other conventional and new energy sources, will be needed to meet future energy demand. In order to make maximum utilization of energy sources to meet national energy-conservation and energy-economic policy, a power plant of the future must cogenerate electrical energy and heat medium, whether it burns fossil fuel or uses solar energy. A solar energy Central Receiver-AHS Chemical Storage cogeneration power plant can be configured to give complete flexibility for day-night and seasonal load combinations, with work efficiencies up to 46 per cent. Such a plant, as a stand-alone or network station, is a real possibility in the not too distant future. Electrical energy and heat medium produced therefrom will be competitive with fossil fuel powered generating plants. A 100 MWe Central Receiver-AHS Cycle cogeneration power plant is discussed in detail; cycle analysis, preliminary cost estimates, and unit energy costs are discussed. © 1980.

Title: Short term thermal energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Abhat, A.
Abstract: The present paper reviews the problem of short term thermal energy storage for low temperature solar heating applications. The techniques of sensible and latent heat storage are discussed, with particular emphasis on the latter. Requirements for hot water storage subsystems are provided and the importance of stratification in hot water storage tanks is described. Concerning latent heat storage, both material and heat exchanger aspects are considered in detail. The example of a passively operating latent heat store employing a finned heat pipe heat exchanger is used to elaborate upon the heat transfer problems in the generally poorly conducting phase change heat storage materials. Finally, some data pertaining to the current economics of heat storage are presented. (A)
Index Keywords: Latent heat; materials of construction; thermal storage

Title: Estimating sizes and outputs from wind energy systems.
Source title: TRANS. INST. ENGRS. AUST. ELECTR. ENGNG.
Authors with affiliations: van Leersum, J.
Abstract: A simple method for evaluating the annual energy output from wind turbo generators connected into an existing electrical network is given. A model for determining the relationship between load fraction supplied by wind and storage size is developed for wind energy conversion systems containing energy stores and auxiliary power supplies. Some general trends predicted by this model are given, and related conclusions drawn. (A)

Title: Thermal energy storage for solar thermal applications program. Progress reports, Oct. 1979-Mar. 1980.
Authors with affiliations: Radosevich, L.G.
Abstract: Developments in thermal energy storage technology are reported including (1) storage for water/steam cooled collector receiver; (2) storage for molten salt cooled sensible heat collector/receiver; (3) storage for liquid metal cooled sensible heat collector/receiver; (4) storage for gas cooled sensible heat collector receiver; (5) storage for organic or silicone fluid cooled sensible heat collector/receiver; and (6) dish mounted latent heat buffer storage.

Title: Acquifers for energy storage.
Abstract: The experimental usage of acquifers for seasonal thermal energy storage is outlined. This new research programme will demonstrate energy storage by pumping hot or cold water into acquifers, from which it could be retrieved for district heating. (A.P.)
Index Keywords: heat; sink

Title: System of storing energy as gas pressure.
Authors with affiliations: Ermini, A.
Abstract: A system for deriving energy from natural sources and storing it as gas pressure. It comprises a prime mover operated by the natural energy source and a compressed air reservoir. The prime mover may be a water turbine driving an air compressor which supplies compressed air to a storage tank from which it can be supplied to an air motor or turbine for driving an electrical generator. The compressor may be driven by a wind motor, an animal driven roundabout or treadmill, or a stationary bicycle-type pedalling system. (A)

Title: Electrical generation - the alternatives.
Abstract: Energy storage systems for electric utilities enable them to meet peak demands by drawing on energy stored during periods of low demand. Systems in use, or under consideration, include hydropower, compressed airstorage, fuel cells or even batteries.

Title: On the static deformation of a bow
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kooi, B.W., Department of Mathematics, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; Sparenberg, J.A., Department of Mathematics, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands
Abstract: The storage of deformation energy in a bow with or without recurve is considered. Some numerical examples are discussed. For a simple bow it is shown that theoretically a shooting efficiency of hundred percent is possible. © 1980 Sijthoff & Noordhoff International Publishers.
Index Keywords: ELASTICITY; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Numerical Methods; BOWS; ARCHES

Authors: Stockel J.F., Dunlopt J.D., Betz F.
Title: NTS-2 nickel-hydrogen battery performance
Affiliations: COMSAT laboratories, Electrophysical Devices Department, Applied Sciences Laboratory, Clarksburg, MD, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Spacecraft Technology Center, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stockel, J.F., COMSAT laboratories, Electrophysical Devices Department, Applied Sciences Laboratory, Clarksburg, MD, United States; Dunlopt, J.D., COMSAT laboratories, Electrophysical Devices Department, Applied Sciences Laboratory, Clarksburg, MD, United States; Betz, F., Naval Research Laboratory, Spacecraft Technology Center, WA, United States
Abstract: The nickel-hydrogen battery was first used for satellite energy storage aboard the U.S. Navy’s Navigation Technology Satellite-2 (NTS-2). A flight demonstration of this new battery was the prime object of the joint Navy/INTELSAT program. The battery’s successful performance proves its usefulness for future satellite applications. The nickel-hydrogen battery supplied spacecraft power for one 30-day eclipse season during which two eclipse periods occurred daily, lasting no longer than one hour. Its unique cell reversal feature was successfully demonstrated several times when the battery was inadvertently discharged completely because the solar array lost track of the sun. The nickel-hydrogen battery also uses a novel concept in which temperature is used for charge control. Strain gauges measure cell pressure, thereby providing information which permits a direct appraisal of the battery’s state of charge. The use of cell pressure to control the rate of charge also can be considered a suitable method. This paper describes the results of the environmental test program along with the prelaunch and orbital performance through one eclipse season. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1980, All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen and unique fuels; Spacecraft electric power
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; SATELLITES

Authors: Cooke W.B., Hardy R.H.S., Sulatisky M.T.
Title: Thermal Energy Storage in Forced-Air Electric Furnaces
Affiliations: Saskatchewan Power Corporation, Research and Development Centre, Regina, SK S4P 0S1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Cooke, W.B., Saskatchewan Power Corporation, Research and Development Centre, Regina, SK S4P 0S1, Canada; Hardy, R.H.S., Saskatchewan Power Corporation, Research and Development Centre, Regina, SK S4P 0S1, Canada; Sulatisky, M.T., Saskatchewan Power Corporation, Research and Development Centre, Regina, SK S4P 0S1, Canada
Abstract: Experimental data are presented for heat storage in forced-air electric furnaces using magnesite as the heat storage material. Charge and discharge data for temperature and flow, obtained in the laboratory, are compared with models used for the design of the furnace. Experience with the furnace operating in homes for a heating season and being charged during the off peak is also presented. A description of the furnace and the control system used to control air flow and temperature is given along with a brief summary of cost and market potential. The capability of sodium sulfate bricks as a replacement for the more expensive magnesite bricks is summarized. The results ofcycling tests that show its improved mechanical strength with the addition of binder materials are discussed. © 1980 IEEE
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; FURNACES, SPACE HEATING

Title: It looks as if biomass is the most feasible of all the alternative energies currently being proposed.
Authors with affiliations: Hall, D.O.
Abstract: As the natural process of photosynthesis fixes carbon at a rate 10 times the world's commercial energy use, it is not surprising that biomass studies (currently concentrated in North America and Brazil) are promoted strongly as a means of fuel diversification. Compared with alternative sources of energy, biomass systems offer concentrated fuel which is both capable of storage and is relatively inoffensive in an ecological sense. Major unresolved problems include land and other input requirements together with uncertainty of supply in early phases of activity.-C.Dean
Index Keywords: biomass studies; Brazil; energy use; fuel diversification; North America; photosynthesis

Title: Heat-transfer properties of a heat-of-fusion store based on CaCl2·6H2O
Affiliations: Division of Physical Chemistry, The Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44, Stockholm 70, Sweden, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Carlsson, B., Division of Physical Chemistry, The Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44, Stockholm 70, Sweden, Sweden; Wettermark, G., Division of Physical Chemistry, The Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44, Stockholm 70, Sweden, Sweden
Abstract: The heat-transfer processes during crystallization and melting of calcium chloride hexahydrate in a heat-storage unit were studied experimentally. The heat transfer through the solid phase is often a limiting factor for the rate of crystallization. For the melting process, convective heat transfer through the melt dominates. For calculating the performance of heat-of-fusion stores, simplified models are developed based on the experimental observations made. An example is given of how the model can be used when dimensioning a storage unit in a solar space-heating system. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT TRANSFER; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; HEAT STORAGE; HEATING

Title: Computer simulation of the performance of a solar pond in the southern part of Iran
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shiraz University, Shiraz, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Akbarzadeh, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shiraz University, Shiraz, Iran; Ahmadi, G., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shiraz University, Shiraz, Iran
Abstract: In this study a computer model of a solar pond to be built in the southern part of Iran is developed. The input to the program is the daily solar radiation, ambient temperature, evaporation rate, etc. The temperature rise of the pond for various rates of energy removal is the output of the program. A parametric study on such a computer simulation for optimization of performance of the actual solar pond is quite economical. Several computer experiments are carried out for various conditions of interest of the area around Shiraz in the southern part of Iran. Temperature rise of the bottom of the pond is calculated for different rates of energy removal. It is observed that after a few months of operation, the temperature of the bottom of the pond becomes sufficiently high to allow energy extraction from the pond. The temperature variation of the pond for different overall efficiencies of the pond under various conditions are also obtained and discussed. The response of the pond to several consecutive days of cloudiness is also studied. It is concluded that solar ponds are also reliable solar collector-storage systems for this part of the world. © 1980.
Index Keywords: solar storage; COMPUTER SIMULATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Gregg D.W., Aiman W.R., Otsuki H.H., Thorsness C.B.
Title: Solar coal gasification
Affiliations: University of California, Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gregg, D.W., University of California, Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Aiman, W.R., University of California, Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Otsuki, H.H., University of California, Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Thorsness, C.B., University of California, Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: A preliminary evaluation of the technical and economic feasibility of solar coal gasification has been performed. The analysis indicates that the medium-Btu product gas from a solar coal-gasification plant would not only be less expensive than that from a Lurgi coal-gasification plant but also would need considerably less coal to produce the same amount of gas. A number of possible designs for solar coal-gasification reactors are presented. These designs allow solar energy to be chemically stored while at the same time coal is converted to a clean-burning medium-Btu gas. © 1980.
Index Keywords: COAL GASIFICATION - Costs; ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Raftery A., Shier P., Obilade T.
Title: Domestic space‐heating and solar energy in Ireland
Affiliations: Department of Statistics, Trinity College, Dublin, Ireland; Laboratoire de Statistique, Universite de VI, Paris, France; Friends' Provident Life Office, Dorking, Surrey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Raftery, A., Department of Statistics, Trinity College, Dublin, Ireland, Laboratoire de Statistique, Universite de VI, Paris, France; Shier, P., Department of Statistics, Trinity College, Dublin, Ireland, Friends' Provident Life Office, Dorking, Surrey, United Kingdom; Obilade, T., Department of Statistics, Trinity College, Dublin, Ireland
Abstract: Five systems which use solar energy to heat houses are discussed and evaluated for thermal performance and cost‐effectiveness by the use of a computer simulation model based on a typical Irish house. It is shown that such systems are currently unviable when compared with systems using oil, gas and off‐peak electricity. the most economic solar system is that which uses rock as storage medium. Further, it is demonstrated that thermal performance is relatively insensitive to changes in storage volume. Copyright © 1980 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Cost‐effectiveness; Domestic space‐heating; Solar energy; Thermal performance
Index Keywords: cost effectiveness; Irish house; rock as storage medium; solar heating; thermal performance; COMPUTER SIMULATION - Applications; HOUSES - Ireland; METEOROLOGY - Ireland; ROCK - Energy Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; COST EFFECTIVENESS; INSOLATION; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Authors: Leidenfrost W., Lee K.H., Korenic B.
Title: Conservation of energy estimated by second law analysis of a power-consuming process
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leidenfrost, W., School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Lee, K.H., School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Korenic, B., School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Abstract: A refrigeration system removing heat from a cold storage is analyzed to determine exergetic losses of the thermodynamic cycle and the power needed for the flows of the refrigerant and the media transferring heat at a specified temperature. How much the overall power consumption of the system can be decreased by lowering the condensing temperature, by either increasing the external heat transfer at the condenser or by lowering the inlet temperature of the heat exchanging media, is investigated. The latter depends on the relative humidity of the air. The performance of air, water and evaporative-cooled condensers are evaluated as a function of relative humidity of the ambient air. It is shown that the evaporative condenser operates at the lowest condensing temperature and, therefore, the least power consumption of the total system is achieved. Wetting the condenser with water requires only 1% of the overall power consumption but reduces the consumption by 30% as compared with the air-cooled condenser. Precooling the air by a water spray before it enters an air-cooled condenser is of benefit only at relative humidities of 65% or less. At other state conditions of the air, a higher power consumption will result. Lowering the temperature of the surroundings lowers Prev and the second law efficiency must be properly defined so that, for cases of lowest power consumption, highest values of the efficiency will be obtained. Means for the design of least power-consuming air-conditioners are briefly stated, as well as the advantages of evaporative condensers for fog-free operation. © 1980.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Cooling; THERMODYNAMICS - Applications; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY

Title: Energy resource requirements of a solar heating system
Affiliations: Energy Project, National Research Council, Ottawa, Canada K1A OR6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Rogers, D.W.O., Energy Project, National Research Council, Ottawa, Canada K1A OR6, Canada
Abstract: The methods of energy analysis have been applied to a liquid-based, short-term storage solar space and water heating system suitable for a single family dwelling in Toronto. This system, which in many respects represents a worst case for solar heating, takes 1.0-3.5 years of operation to conserve the energy resources required to build, operate and maintain the system. Alternatively, over the twenty year lifetime of the system, the energy resources used indirectly by the solar heating system amount to between 6 and 24% of the direct energy resources conserved by the system. These considerations do not significantly alter the energy-conservation characteristics of the solar heating system unless thermally-generated electricity is used as backup for a 50% solar heating system which replaces oil or gas heating; in this case, only 4-9% of the energy resources are conserved by the solar system. A factor of three variation in energy resource use in collector materials was found in a sample of 7 flat-plate collectors with steel-based collectors using the least. The total energy embodied in the collector was about double that found in the materials alone. The collectors and annual operating energy for the pumps were found to be the two most significant factors in the analysis. An appendix summarizes the energy resource requirements embodied in the materials used for collectors. © 1980.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES - Analysis; PUMPS - Energy Utilization; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS - Solar; NET ENERGY ANALYSIS; HEATING

Authors: Stainbsy W.N., Gladden L.B., Barclay J.K., Wilson B.A.
Title: Exercise efficiency: Validity of base-line subtractions
Source title: Journal of Applied Physiology Respiratory Environmental and Exercise Physiology
Affiliations: Dept. Physiol., Coll. Med., Univ. Florida, Gainesville, Fla. 32610, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stainbsy, W.N., Dept. Physiol., Coll. Med., Univ. Florida, Gainesville, Fla. 32610, United States; Gladden, L.B., Dept. Physiol., Coll. Med., Univ. Florida, Gainesville, Fla. 32610, United States; Barclay, J.K., Dept. Physiol., Coll. Med., Univ. Florida, Gainesville, Fla. 32610, United States; Wilson, B.A., Dept. Physiol., Coll. Med., Univ. Florida, Gainesville, Fla. 32610, United States
Abstract: In evaluating the efficiency of humans performing exercise, base-line subtractions have been used in an attempt to determine the efficiency of the muscles in performing the external work. Despite the fact that base lines have been criticized previously, they have been widely used without adequate analysis of the implications involved. Calculations of efficiencies using data available in the literature for isolated muscle preparations revealed that baseline subtractions result in unreasonably high efficiencies. This suggests strongly that the base lines are invalid. To be valid, a base line must continue unchanged under all the conditions in which it is applied. Previously published data indicate clearly that exercise base lines change with increasing work rate and are therefore invalid. The use of base lines is further complicated by elastic energy storage in some types of exercise. Although exercise efficiencies using base line subtractions may be useful, they do not indicate muscle efficiency. Perhaps future studies of exercise metabolism should be directed less at refining base lines and more toward describing and quantifying the determinants of energy expenditure.
Index Keywords: elasticity; energy expenditure; exercise; human cell; muscle contraction; normal human; work efficiency

Authors: Ahuja S.D., Stroup S.L., Bolin M.G.
Title: SemiÃ¢â¬Âempirical model for depth dose distributions of megavoltage xÃ¢â¬Âray beams
Affiliations: Division of Radiation Oncology, Department of Radiology and Radiological Sciences, Vanderbilt University Medical School, Nashville, Tennessee 37232, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ahuja, S.D., Division of Radiation Oncology, Department of Radiology and Radiological Sciences, Vanderbilt University Medical School, Nashville, Tennessee 37232, United States; Stroup, S.L., Division of Radiation Oncology, Department of Radiology and Radiological Sciences, Vanderbilt University Medical School, Nashville, Tennessee 37232, United States; Bolin, M.G., Division of Radiation Oncology, Department of Radiology and Radiological Sciences, Vanderbilt University Medical School, Nashville, Tennessee 37232, United States
Abstract: The dose distribution due to absorption of photon energy fluence in a homogeneous water phantom irradiated by megavoltage xÃ¢â‚¬Âray beams has been analyzed with a semiempirical model. The method generalizes an analytical formalism for the scattering component of dose within a water phantom which was developed recently for monoenergetic photon beams. Contributions to dose via Compton interaction and pair creation form the essential structure of the secondary component formula. Both the centralÃ¢â‚¬Âaxis percent depth dose and offÃ¢â‚¬ÂcentralÃ¢â‚¬Âaxis ratios can be determined for beams of different sizes, used at any value of source to surface distance. The input data include the values of linear attenuation and energyÃ¢â‚¬Âabsorption coefficients in water at energies between 10 keV and the equivalent energy of the beam. Predicted values of the centralÃ¢â‚¬Âaxis percent depth dose and the offÃ¢â‚¬ÂcentralÃ¢â‚¬Âaxis ratios are compared with the measured data for 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 14, 20, 35, 45, and 70 MVp xÃ¢â‚¬Âray beams. For the centralÃ¢â‚¬Âaxis percent depth dose, agreement is within 3% for fields of sizes between 5Ãƒâ€”5 and 20Ãƒâ€”20 cm2, and 5% for larger fields, for beams of MVp up to 20. For higher energy beams, comparison was made only for the 10Ãƒâ€”10 cm2 fields and the discrepancies were within 3%. For the offÃ¢â‚¬ÂcentralÃ¢â‚¬Âaxis ratios, agreement between the predicted and measured values is within 5% over the umbra region but worsens in the penumbra region and geometrical shadow. This formalism requires large computer storage for generating data for all realistic beams irradiating normalÃ¢â‚¬Âsize phantoms. © 1980, American Association of Physicists in Medicine. All rights reserved.

Title: Anoxic energy production and contractile activity in mammalian cardiac muscle.
Authors with affiliations: Siess, M.; Seifart, H.I.
Abstract: Contractile activity of electrically driven left atria of guinea pigs was measured auxotonically under normoxic and anoxic conditions at various frequencies and temperatures in Krebs-Henseleit solution containing 15 mM glucose. At 35 degrees C, a frequency of 0.5 Hz and anoxia ("anoxia test") reduced contractile activity was observed, lasting 6.6 +/- 1.55 hr. Under normoxic conditions at 0.5 Hz and 35 degrees C the contractile work per beat (cwb) amounts to 35% of the maximum reached at 1.5 Hz, according to the force-frequency relationship. The total contractile work per hr only comes up to 5% of the maximum reached at 4.0 Hz. The oxygen consumption at 0.5 Hz only exceeds the value of resting atria by 10%. A positive inotropic peak of short duration observed directly after acute anoxia can be antagonized by beta-receptor blockade. Then contractile activity decreases during the first half hr of anoxia to around 20%-30% of the initial value under oxygen. In the second phase, the reduced contractile activity recovers and is stabilized at a level between 50%-80% of the control value during the first and second hour of anoxia and then decreases slowly during the following hours. The recovery period of anoxic contractile activity coincides with the time-dependent increase of the lactic acid production rate which reaches a maximum after around 1 hr of anoxia. This can also explain why the rapid decrease of ATP (30%) and creatine phosphate (CP) (90%) during the first 20 min is stabilized at this reduced value during the 2 hr of anoxia studied. Related to the measured oxygen consumption during normoxia, the glucose consumption increases during anoxia in resting atria approximately 300% and, in beating atria, approximately 650%, representing an ATP production rate of approximately 20% and approximately 50%, respectively, related to aerobic conditions. G-strophanthin enhances anoxic contractile activity up to 200% of the aerobic initial control value and prolongs the anoxic tolerance from 6.6 +/- 1.55 to 21.2 +/- 3.3 hr without significant additional increase of glycolysis or a further decrease of energy-rich phosphates. Addition of adenine and ribose as precursors of the adenine nucleotide pool during the first and second hours of anoxia increases anoxic contractile activity and avoids loss of ATP, ADP, and CP, without enhancemnt of glycolysis. The importance of these findings for anoxic survival of cardiac tissue is discussed. This "anoxia test" can be used to check influence on: 1) force and duration of anoxic contractile activity as well as anoxic arrhythmias (anoxic energy consumption), 2) the rate of anaerobic glycolysis (anoxic energy production), and 3) the concentration of energy-rich phosphates (energy storage).

Title: The reliability of histochemical fibre typing of human necropsy muscles
Affiliations: Department of Stomatognathic Physiology, University of Umeå, Umeå, S-901 87, Sweden; Institutes of Pathology and Forensic Medicine, University of Umeå, Umeå, S-901 87, Sweden; Institute of Anatomy, University of Umeå, Umeå, S-901 87, Sweden

Abstract: The reliability of muscle fibre typing of post mortem specimens was investigated with special reference to the influence of time and temperature. In specimens stored at +4° C, muscle fibre typing could be reliably performed up to at least ten and fifteen days post mortem for the masseter and biceps brachii muscles respectively. The corresponding figures for storage at room temperature were three and six days. The difference in the preservation of enzyme activity between masticatory and limb muscles might be related to the demonstrated difference in the fibre type composition and thus the enzyme content and energy sources. © 1980 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: UMANSKY S.R., MATINYAN K.S., TOKARSKAYA V.I.
Title: Polypeptide‐Synthesizing Activity of Eukaryotic: Chromatin Properties, Dependence on Poly(ADP‐ribose) and Connection with the Cell Cycle
Affiliations: Institut Biologicheskoj Fiziki, Akademia Nauk S. S. S. R., Pushchino, Moskovskaya, 142292
Authors with affiliations: UMANSKY, S.R., Institut Biologicheskoj Fiziki, Akademia Nauk S. S. S. R., Pushchino, Moskovskaya, 142292; MATINYAN, K.S., Institut Biologicheskoj Fiziki, Akademia Nauk S. S. S. R., Pushchino, Moskovskaya, 142292; TOKARSKAYA, V.I., Institut Biologicheskoj Fiziki, Akademia Nauk S. S. S. R., Pushchino, Moskovskaya, 142292
Abstract: Isolated nuclei incubated with [14C] protein hydrolysate are shown to incorporate labelled amino acids into the acid‐insoluble fraction. Purified chromatin and the complex of DNA with firmly bound proteins possess similar ability. The optimum pH of the reaction is 6.5‐7.0, 2 mM MgCl2 stimulates incorporation, the temperature optimum is 37‐40°C. Chloramphenicol depresses incorporation by 70%, puromycin by 40%, cycloheximide does not affect the chromatin activity. Incorporation does not depend on the presence of ATP or GTP, and is substantially inhibited by deoxyribonuclease but not by ribonuclease treatment of chromatin or of the nuclei. Specific activity of firmly bound chromatin non‐histone proteins is higher than that of labile bound ones; histones are not labelled. After pronase treatment of proteins radioactivity changes to an acid‐soluble state. The molecular weight of isolated labelled polypeptides is about 6000 as shown by gel filtration and the ánalysis of NH2‐terminal amino acids. Labelled polypeptides firmly bound to DNA consist of 7‐10 amino acids. Specific activity of proteins firmly bound to DNA increases linearly with the time of incubation of chromatin with [14C] protein hydrolysate, the activity curve of labile bound non‐histone proteins has a distinct sygmoid character. The polypeptide‐synthesizing activity of rat liver chromatin increases between 9 h and 21 h after partial hepatectomy. Irradiation with 800 rads 30 min before the operation prevents activation of amino acid incorporation. From nine amino acids studied alanine, methionine, lysine, tyrosine and arginine are not incorported in the system described. Glutamic acid is polymerized most effectively. Glutamine, asparagine and glycine are incorporated 7‐8 times less. The data are given indicating that the incorporation is not random when an amino acid mixture is present. Preincubation of chromatin with NAD+ but not with its analogues increases the polypeptide‐synthesizing activity of chromatin. The activation is prevented by thymidine and nicotinamide. Storage (18 h at 2‐4°C) brings about a complete loss of the polypeptide‐synthesizing activity of chromatin. The ability of ‘old’ chromatin to incorporate amino acids can be restored by preincubating it with NAD+. Storage of chromatin in the presence of 5 mM adenosine 3′, 5′‐monophosphate (cAMP) does not result in decrease of the polypeptide‐synthesizing activity. It is assumed that poly‐(ADP‐ribose) is the energy source for amino acid activation in the system described. Copyright © 1980, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
